In the end everyone paid $12.10 per person, including tax and 20% tip. Weighing in on the price and value, this is by far the best tasting and most affordable private UYE I've organized to date.

Since the event, people are still telling me that they are expecting to revisit Mi Lindo Peru on their own in the near future, which says a lot about their first rate culinary acumen, décor, price, portions, and service. I too, expect to return to this beautiful restaurant which I call Nuestro Muy Lindo Peru.

I invite everyone to check out Philip W's review for the wonderful photos taken at the event.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I'd love to give 5 stars, but THEIR MENU says HALF CHICKEN I got two small Chicken breast and I lost my appetite....
I asked the server, is this a half chicken?
"He said yes". I was hungry and I didn't want to cause drama.. I don't  want to blame the sever,but I think their manager or owner doesn't have a clue whatsoever offering half chicken and serving me the wrong thing:(
author: Pedro D.

description: Delicious food. Soft bread and great salteados. This is the shrimp salteado and I absolutely loved it and would totally recommend it :) I will be coming back again.
author: Marisol S.

description:
There are a number of Peruvian restaurants to choose from in the Bay Area. As someone who grew up with home cooked Peruvian food, this is hands down the closest you will come to authentic comida peruana (Peruvian food).

The service is friendly and generally prompt. They do get quite busy, so don't expect not to wait during dinner times, especially on the weekends.

The food is fresh and the serving sizes are generous. My standards which never let me down are Papa a la Huancaina (boiled potatoes on a bed of lettuce with hard boiled egg slices and some olives, covered in a spicy cheese sauce), Lomo Saltado (comparable to a stir fry, but the rice is served separately from the strips of beef that are cooked with tomatoes, onions and french fried potatoes), with some chicha morada (a flavorful purple corn drink). The yucca (boiled or fried) is great. The anticuchos are also very good. I'm sure I've sampled most everything on the menu and am rarely disappointed.

I'm look forward to my next time dining there!
author: Laura P.

description: This place is fantastic. The rocoto is spicy as hell! Perfect! And the lomo is amazing. Great spot!
author: Joaquin C.

description:
Well since i'm Peruvian myself and love to cook my ethnic food then i guess i have the right to be picky when it comes down to this type of food. The restaurant is small bu cozy. Amost like a hole in the wall but not that discouraging to look at.

Must try:

lomo saltado (famous Peruvian dish)

bistek a lo pobre (one of my favs, comes with plantains, fried egg over fried rice with french fries on the side and a piece fried yuca. hmmm!)

anticuchos ( beef hearts) you wont regret it, i promise!
author: Migz T.

description:
Food: it was ok, on par with other peruvian, not particularly better.  I tried the lomo saltado and paella de verduras.  Actually i thought it was cool that they offered a vegetarian paella.  The paella was much too moist.

Service: i think because we sat behind a post they may have forgotten about us a little so it took a while for them to ask for our order and get the check.  However, they did graciously refill the complimentary bread at our request while we waited for our food since we had finished all the bread before they came to take our order.

Atmosphere: a little nicer than casual during lunch. Not particularly romantic.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
I like the selection of food here. They serve many popular Peruvian meals. It seems to be mostly authentic, but it is slightly Americanized. That's not necessarily a good or bad thing. The restaurant has a nice Peruvian atmosphere. My wife says it's not that nice, but I like it.

Lomo Saltado was great. So was the Bistec a lo Pobre. All the food is pretty good. It may be lacking flavor... Something seems to be missing in this restaurant. It's like it's missing that magic ingredient that could make it great. I can't quite put a finger on what that is though....
author: Nathan H.

description:
This place was recommended by a friend and we tried it not knowing what to expect... Oh my gosh! Let's just say that the first impression is very unassuming... What kept me inside was the fact that most patrons seem South American... The second thing was the incredible smell of roasted garlic and plantas... You HAVE to try the home made sangria... Simply amazing! The calamaris are to die for... We all had to share our orders because it was all delicious...
I can't recall being that excited about trying a new restaurant in a long time... Hope you enjoy it as much...
author: Bruno L.

description: The best Peruvian food I've had!  I have been to a fancy Peru restaurant before and I don't know what Peruvians think is authentic but I love the food here better than the fancier places. The shrimp soup is amazing and the steak with plantains is awesome!  Thanks Yelpers for finding this place.
author: Steve T.

description:
I heard this place was really good and while I was in town visiting from Seattle I decided to try it out. I came with 2 of my girlfriends, and we all got one dish each and shared. The server was very helpful and pointed out the most popular dishes. We ordered the Lomo Saltado, which was beef with rice and fries, Arroz con Pollo, which was chicken, rice and peas in a cilantro sauce and the Aguadito de Mariscos which is a seafood soup.

The Lomo Saltado & Arroz con Pollo were amazing!!!! Full of flavor. The soup was okay, I felt that it needed a little bit more flavor but it was still good.

I plan on coming back and trying different dishes!
author: Jazeleene G.

description: A great Peruvian restaurant. The ceviche is delicious, the prices are very competitive, and the staff is truly friendly. It's a small restaurant though, so you may have to wait a little bit for a table. It's within walking distance from the 24th street & Mission BART station, but it's a bit off the beaten path compared to other restaurants in the Mission. Still, I think the dishes are more authentic and it's definitely a great place to have Peruvian food!
author: Sebastien C.

description:
The example text fits perfectly here, especially at this price point. Anticuchos lacked flavor and the lomo saltado was dry af.

 "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Neftalí J.

description:
Ive been coming here for years and out of all the Peruvian restaurants, this is the best.

I love their lomo saltado! Their rice with corn is the best I've had and even when I try to make it myself, it never turns out as good as mi lindo peru's.

Service is always pleasant and attentive.

Good food + good service = happy customer
author: Rob B.

description: Went here for the second time yesterday and it was just as I remembered. Delicious! We ordered the fried plantains, garlic shrimp, and the lomo saltado. Perfect amount for two people and sooo good!!
author: Nikki V.

description:
I married into a Peruvian family and this is by far our favorite restaurant in the Bay Area!  We get takeout from here on our way home from SF every time.

Favorites are Arroz con Pollo, Jalea, and Lomo Saltado.

The only dish that disappoints us is the Papa a la Huancaina :(

Just had a New Years Eve feast and was motivated to finally write a review :)
author: Gurdeep D.

description: The lomo Saltado is a must at this place. You can also get it a lo pobre which is is a serving of egg and fried banana on the side. Their food is flavorful and large portions.
author: Chiara M.

description: It's ok. I think that their "Jalea" is ok but it's not the best. I recommend it if your not trying to spend a lot of money($).
author: Marilynnn G.

description: This place hasn't changed.  Great Peruvian.  We had anticuchos, calamari, lomo saltado, pollo saltado and pescado a lo macho.  Even my 3 year old daughter ate the shrimp and calamari. Pricy but well worth it.  Excellent food.  Excellent service.
author: David Joseph S.

description:
I've been eating Peruvian food my whole life so any Peruvian restaurant is gonna get a little tough love..

Mi Lindo Peru is ok. 
The positives are the serving size and price are decent. 
The service is great! Very friendly and attentive.
They also have a yummy salad with a citrus dressing and potatoes.
Their lomo is decent, not soy sauce heavy like many other restaurants, they even make a Saltado de camarones for the pescatarians out there. They also make a pretty good Pisco Sour.

Mi Lindo Peru is a good place for a casual Peruvian.
author: Luz T.

description:
I'm still Peruvian and the food still isn't very good.

DW got us some dinner to go. I had the Aji de Gallina and this version was about 10 notches below my aunt's. Shredded chicken in a yellow sauce with barely any flavor. The yuca a la huancaina was dried out and came with barely a thimble of sauce and said sauce barely had any cheese flavor or heat.

DW had the arroz con mariscos which she liked. She also got the platanos maduros and they were OK but deep fried.
author: Marco M.

description: We had a large party here and they did a good job considering. I just didn't feel the quality of the food was as good as some of the other Peruvian restaurants in the area. I am also not an expert when it comes to Peruvian food so this place maybe very authentic.
author: Paul D.

description:
I had never eaten Peruvian food before coming to Mi Lindo Peru, but now I'm hooked. Due to immigration of Chinese and Japanese to Peru during the twentieth century, Peruvian cuisine has a natural Latin/Asian fusion to it. This is particularly evident with Peruvian fried rice. The lomo saltado here is AMAZING in addition to the fried yuca. But the thing to really come here for is the purple corn juice! It's quite possibly the strangest thing to look at, but it's such a nice light sweet drink to go with the meal. 

If I'm ever in Bernal Heights, this is one of the restaurants I always suggest my friends and I go to.
author: Tony H.

description:
I am Peruvian so I took a few friends to this restaurant on the recommendation of another non-peruvian friend.  My review is based on the quality of the food and I think it is valid whether or not you had ever had Peruvian food before.  In brief, I am unsure how this restaurant stays open in a city known for its food.  I'd get it if there were no other Peruvian restaurants but that is no longer the case.  

Bottom line:  Go anywhere else but here.  

The Good:
1.  The servers were nice
2.  We went early in the evening and were seated immediately.
3.  The fried calamari was good as was the pescado a lo macho.

The Bad:
1.  The pisco sours tasted like they were made with that lemon that comes in plastic lemon containers at Safeway.  They were too sweet and may not have had blended egg yolk.  They were passable but not as a pisco sour.

2.  The ceviche was made with red snapper.  What??!?  Yes.  And the outcome was not good.  Again, are they scared of fresh lemons?  This hardly had the lemony flavor I'm used to and the consistency was odd.  Not a yummy dish by any standards.

3. Three of us go really sick about 5 hours after dinner.  My boyfriend and I woke up at the exact same time and I had to get sick.  My other friend had horrid stomach pains.  I need to check with the others in my party but this is more than coincidence.  After four days, I am starting to eat again.  I suspect that the fish in the ceviche was not processed well.  And, the lack of lemon took its toll.

I will never go back.
author: Francesca A.

description: Some nights the dining is all about the atmospher and the company the you keep. This was one of those nights. The food here was delicious but it was the light life experience that was so memorable. Mi Lindo Peru is a prime example of the electric nightlife that has flourished in the Bernal Heights - crowded and intense atmosphere that is at the same time chill.  The eight of us rolled into this small peruvian restaurant and squeezed into an even smaller table - we didn't mind. We spent the rest of the evening enjoying our meal, our wine, and each other's company - thanks to the great service of Mi Lindo Peru.
author: Eddie C.

description: been looking for a peruvian spot up here and found it! so delicious. i ordered the shrimp saltado and chicken chicharrones- OMG. delicious. service was also muy excelente!
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Got some plantains and had the bread to start--bad idea, because the portion of arroz con pollo was huge, yet I still killed everything. All was good, just a bit expensive for what it is. I did walk out completely stuffed (shocking, I know).
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Great service- friendly and attentive staff.
Food- ordered Lomo Saltado, Bistec a lo Pobre, fried plantains and sangria. Everything was was exceptional, delicious, and perfectly prepared! Prices are very reasonable, about $13-15 per plate, and the portions are large.
Will definitely be coming back!
author: Priscila A.

description:
I like experimenting with different, more modern type Peruvian restaurants, but when I just wanna have a decently priced, delicious plate of Lomo Saltado, with a generous portion, I ALWAYS go to Me Lindo Peru. 

One of the BEST traditional peruvian places in SF. 

Things I recommend to order.. 

Drink: Inca Cola (Satisfying bubble gum tasting soda! Tastes so much better than it sounds!)

Appetizers:
-Causa
-Jalea
-Anticuchos (Cooked well)
-Papa a la Huancaína. Wait. Let me say something real quick, Me Lindo has the BEST Huancaína sauce. YEAH. Quote it. 

Entree:
-Lomo Saltado. 

They also give you bread & butter. Also, the MOST delicious Aji sauce. mmmmmm.
author: Katelyn C.

description:
Been here twice. 

Pros:
- Aji de Gallina (shredded chicken w/ spicy yellow sauce and potatoes) was really good
- food is filling
- service was good

Cons:
- most dishes are too pricey for what it is
author: Wendy T.

description: Good food but would not come back. Would rather go to nicer Peruvian restaurants for the same money. I thought it was a little overpriced  for a casual restaurant in that neiborhood.
author: C-R-I-S-T-I-N-A C.

description: The portions here are quite large, so be mindful.  We were seated right as we walked in without reservations; service was friendly and attentive.  The two of us ordered the Ceviche Mixto, Saltado De Pollo, and Parihuela (seafood soup) - all very good and we were stuffed midway through.  The house sangria was pretty decent as well.
author: Leland H.

description:
We were a party of 12. There was another big party at same time. All other tables were packed. Service was a tad slow, we had the menus for a half hour before someone came to take the order. And, drinks came slowly too. However, after we ordered the food came out very quickly!

We really enjoyed the mushroom appetizer - so delicious. The ceviche and the calamari were also very tasty, but we thought the mushrooms were special.

Everyone enjoyed their food. 8 adults all ordered different items and everyone was satisfied. Portions are generous. The four kids split two dishes and had plenty - even leftovers.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Ceviche pescado is pure garbage. $18 for the absolute worse ceviche I've ever had. Very disappointed and unsatisfied. Ambiance sucks, overpriced, and no parking. Definitely will not ever be back. Waiter came to our table two times...to take our order and bring the check. Never checked on us.
author: Yung C.

description:
The saltado dishes (lomo/beef or pollo/chicken) = Parade in my MOUTH. You get a choice of chicken or beef sirloin, which is sauteed with tomato, onion, and cilantro tossed with fries. Very tasty. It comes with a side of rice or salad, but get the rice cuz it has corn in it -YUM.


The sangria is off the hook; however, for $6.50, I really wish it came in a bigger glass.


The service was fair. Our waiter tapped me with a pen and jokingly asked me to "Stop it, with the bread." What? Am I eating too much, or something? I couldn't help but think about his joke while I was looking at my menu; and I have to admit that I was slightly offended.
author: Tricia A.

description:
Seriously Guys get your Empanada Act together! 

I'm a Peruvian food snob. I think it's the best cuisine out there and I always....always order one of their staple dishes anywhere I go (Lomo Saltada & Ceviche Mixto). From that I determine if this place is authentic, having a bad day, having a bad year, shouldn't exist at all etc etc etc ( I'm pretty sure I contributed to putting a Peruvian Restaurant in Kansas City out of business).

I'm going to give them the benefit of the doubt and say Lindo Peru was having a bad day, however, their empanadas now twice have disappointed. These Saugy lumps of Masa, need a makeover. 

The positive side is the atmosphere is always nice, people seem to be smiling and and enjoying their dinners. The waiters look as if the enjoy their job. 

The Bad news.....you lost me =(.
author: Lannette G.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru is a neighborhood gem!  I have been there three times now and have enjoyed myself each time.  The restaurant is cozy and the staff friendly.  They have a great range of dishes from meat heavy to totally seafood to vegetarian - so anyone who comes will be happy!

My favorite dish to get there is lomo saltado!  The beef plus grilled onions & tomatoes and fries with rice on the side is AMAZING.  They also have delicious sangria by the glass or carafe.  PLUS I have never had trouble getting a table (shhhh... don't tell anyone about our secret :P)
author: Liz H.

description:
Saltado me up! 

Mi Lindo Peru reminds me of all the things I loved about travelling to Peru:

-Friendly people
-Colorful, welcoming decor
-Delicious food

As we were cooking steak for dinner that night, we decided to veer away from the ultimate Peruvian classic: Lomo Saltado. I tried the Saltado de Camarones (shrimp sauteed w/ onions, tomatoes, herbs & french fries) and my fiance tried the Saltado al Pollo (chicken sauteed w/ onions, tomatoes, herbs & french fries). 

The entrees come with rice and a side of salad. We opted to substitute the rice with more salad for a healthy option. 

Both styles of saltado were really tasting and generously portioned. The chicken breast in the saltado al pollo was surprisingly juicy. I was disappointed with the size of the shrimp in my saltado de camarones, but the generous portion of shrimp in the dish made up for it. The saltados and salads had an umami-quality to them.. a subtle herbaceous quality that I could not name, but that was delicious! 

Definitely coming back to try the Ceviche and Lomo Saltado and see how it compares to what we've had in Peru... but overall, a very solid choice for reasonably priced Peruvian food in Bernal Heights!
author: Monelle A.

description: I had one of the fish ceviche appetizers, garlic chicken wings, and the lomo saltado with a fried egg and sweet plantains. The chicken wings were a huge disappointment - they were super greasy and didn't taste much like garlic. The ceviche and steak dish were both flavorful and seemed authentic. This place doesn't have much going for it for atmosphere, so next time I'll order the lomo saltado for take out.
author: Amin S.

description: There food is pretty good.  Have been a long time customer but there prices have skyrocketed and portions have gotten way smaller. Will not be returning.
author: G R.

description:
An amazingly friendly little joint nestled in amongst all the other restaurants of Mission Street.

Stopped in here for lunch - split the fried snapper and the lomo saltado (one of my favorite dishes - steak, fries, grilled onions, pan juice). Not a big cooked fish fan, but the snapper was gobbled up in minutes - nom! About $10 each at lunch. Peruvian food isn't necessarily as "cheap" as other cuisines of Central/South America, but I just think the cuisine is so darn exciting...

The waitstaff is really attentive and kind (always smiling), and I really left wanting to come back because I felt so welcomed. And I will.

Food is 4 stars, service going the extra mile really brought it up to a 5.
author: Conrad B.

description:
Chef here is of Japanese background --- my (uncreative) guess is that he is Japanese-Peruvian. Maybe because of this, or simply due to the nature of Peruvian food, Japanese people tend to like Peruvian restaurants.

FOOD: A group of us shared a bunch of dishes which I could not pronounce, so I do not remember all that I had, but all dishes were excellent. Good sangria.

DECOR: Non existent. Nothing like Mochica (http://www.yelp.com/biz/VG4tugriIkPpT8RmVe2LGg) or Limon (http://www.yelp.com/biz/chWLsfWUJ5k8-73t9FOM9A).

PRICES: More expensive than other below $10 ethnic alternatives in the area, but much cheaper than Limon.  Expect to pay around $20-25/person. Come here for quality food without fancy lighting or service.

I really like this segment of Mission Street with three excellent restaurants in the same block (Blue Plate (http://www.yelp.com/biz/rxY7canIJeXtICb6lprUcQ), GFC (http://www.yelp.com/biz/8TSk-heAZkXC2vO0yV0CQg), and Mi Lindo Peru). Street parking is not easy, but I usually find one eventually, so I have not had to dish out $7 at the lot.

I have never been to Mi Lindo Peru #2 (http://www.yelp.com/biz/eHwXeRB9Bw-hy9q37RLmIQ) in Marina, so I have no idea why they have poor Yelp rating.
author: トモ T.

description: The sweetness of the purple-pink Chicha Morada could not wash away the taste of the fishy mussels, dry shrimp, and rubbery squid of the Saltado De Mariscos.
author: Amy C.

description:
It's funny how this Peruvian restaurant is squeezed between one of my favorite Mexican places, the decidedly downscale El Zocalo, and the yuppie-magnet Blue Plate. Funny because there is a little bit of both in Mi Lindo Peru as if done by osmosis. I love Peru, and my most vivid memory of my trip there, other than being in a Pisco Sour stupor, is the grilled guinea pig on a skewer. They splay out the little critters post-mortem in an outstretched fashion much like the airport hostages on "24". I didn't see this Hartz Mountain-fed delicacy at this place, but there are other pleasures to be had.

I had the Pollo al Jerez ($9.95), which was slices of chicken breast and yams bathing in a saffron sauce and cherry wine. It was deliciously tangy with a generous scoop of rice to sop up all the sauce. My friend had the $10.95 Lomo Saltado, which was beef strips sauteed in tomatoes and onions. He also got the big rice scoop and a pile of fries to boot. We shared an appetizer, the Anticuhos, which were two skewers of --- brace yourself --- beef hearts, served with one grilled potato chunk. I loves me some internal organs...with fava beans and a nice Chianti (cue for Hannibal Lecter slurping noise).

It was pretty crowded, but the waitress was always attentive without being intrusive. The rest of the menu, especially the seafood, looks too inviting not to come back. I think along with Fina Estampa in Van Ness, I will get over my nightmares of little guinea pigs with their feet tied to the rotisserie over an open fire.

FOOD - 4 stars...no guineas pigs and portions are quite generous
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...middle-of-the road 
SERVICE - 4 stars...attentive to the max
OVERALL - 4 stars...another Peruvian jewel in SF without the pretense of other places that shall remain nameless...(cough) Limon (cough)
author: Ed U.

description:
Swing dancing to KMFDM and Sisters of Mercy, with a dollop of Morrisey thrown in.  Such pleasures in life are rare and few, but last night shone like a beacon in my small, super busy existence.  However, that's a story for another time.

A girl's gotta eat substantially prior to a dizzying night of rock steps, twirls and tosses.  As such, C_ and I ventured to this establishment for some good Peruvian foods to sustain our pending boisterous activities.  This was my very first venture into this cuisine, and we couldn't have picked a better place for me to start.  It was heaven on the tongue.  Here's the 411 -

Decor, I give 5 stars:  The restaurant is small and cozy; I would say there's seating for perhaps 30'ish peeps should the place be packed.  Last night was half-filled, a good sign on a chilly Tuesday night.  The lights were muted, which is something I adore, and the walls painted in happy ambience.  The ceiling sconces were delightful to look at, resembling clam shells or tortillas, however you wish to view them.  The only downside I would say is that the door was one of those double-swing doors that, if not closed properly, allowed the freezing outside in.

Food, I give 5 stars:  We ordered 3 items to share family style - Champinones Al Ajillo, Lomo Saltado and the Arroz con Pollo (http://www.menupix.com/menudirectory/menu.php?id=100727).  The mushrooms were tender and super garlicky, which I loved.  The two main dishes were super yummy too, and we took leftovers home to enjoy once more after.  I also loved their bread with the salsa.  Not too spicy (cus I'm a wuss, I admit it), the two were so good together, even more so once I added the mushrooms on top.  I'm drooling thinking about it as I type.

Service, I give 5 stars:  Attentive, yet not obtrusive.  We didn't need to wait long for anything, and we were in and out right on schedule.

Patronage:  Like I stated earlier, the place was half-full by the time we left, and of people of various ethnicities.  You'll feel right at home here.

Overall, I truly enjoyed my first visit down the Peruvian lane.  This place is definitely a place I'd come back to.  Perhaps we'll see you there next time.
author: Lorrayne L.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru is a very good restaruant to eat very good peruvian food.  The Service is very good and very attentive.  i recommend getting 
Papa La Huanciana
Lomo Saltado
Sopa a la Criolla 
Chicharron de ajo

Overall this place is a near 5 star to me its a good 4.5 stars.

If you never tried peruvian food Please try it your won't regret it.
author: Henry G.

description:
I decided to come here on the whim of being starved in the middle of the day at work. I don't really have that much Peruvian food but I figured this would be a great place to try it out, with its high reviews. I definitely was not disappointed. 

Tallarin de marscos (seafood spaghetti) is now my new favorite dish.
It was essentially everything I loved in one dish (seafood, noodles with a kick). The spaghetti came piping out and had a great al-denta taste with seafood flavors. Normally, I don't care too much for onions and cilantro but I really enjoyed it with this dish. The order included a small container for the spicy sauce (which was BOMB) and some bread.  Within a matter of minutes, l scarfed down the spaghetti like no other..and despite being full, I was kind of sad that there wasn't anymore left.. 

What puts this place over the top was how friendly the staff members were while letting me order take out despite showing up a few minutes late from the lunch hour... During the time I was waiting for the order, they were very hospitable and friendly by offering me a glass of water. 

I shall be back to try more. yummmmmmm.
author: Jennifer W.

description: We love this place! It is, in our opinion, the best Peruvian restaurant in the city. The people are attentive, very welcoming, and friendly. I've taken friends, family, and work colleagues here and everyone loves it!!
author: LoveAlways J.

description:
An excellent date night out. Very friendly service and a casual, relaxed environment. There were only two servers and they both juggled a lot of tables, and still managed to bring everything in a timely manner and take the time to have a conversation. 

I got the pescado al ajo, a white fish fried in a minced garlic breading. If you are a garlic lover this is heaven in your mouth. You can also get it without the breading for a healthier option. The plate came with rice and potatoes so be prepared to be full. They also bring you bread beforehand, with the delicious chili dipping sauce which we heaped on nearly everything on our plates because it was so good with anything. 

A word of warning with the pescado al ajo... you will be excreting garlic for at least one whole day. It's a little awkward to pass gas and mistake it for something cooking.... yeah that's no joke. But it's so worth it!

My girlfriend got the mar y tierra, which was grilled prawns and steak. I tried some of her steak and it was perfectly juicy and tender. It also came with potatoes and rice. 

We wanted to get dessert but had no room. Since it was our first time here, the waiter surprised us with their house-made ice cream. We couldn't tell the flavor but it was very nice on the palate. Kind of buterscotchy. 

We definitely want to come back and try the lomo saltado.
author: Katie D.

description: Must get the half (not really half more like quarter) grilled Chicken. It was spiced and cooked perfectly with a little crispness.
author: Holla F.

description: Love this place. Staff is friendly,  and once your food is ordered  you dont have to wait long for your food to arrive. The food here is consistently tasty and packed full of flavor. Menu is reasonably priced. Great place to pop in and grab a great meal.
author: Jmarania M.

description:
I was up in the City and was craving for Latin American food so I decided to stop by here. I yelped for a good Peruvian food a few weeks before in the city and already wanted to give this place a try. The place is small, cozy, and friendly service. 

I came here for lunch so I ordered the Lomo Saltado lunch plate. It's Steak, french fries, plantain, grilled peppers and onions. It came out in about 5 minutes and it was a good portion. The sauce is amazing, and the part of the rice that was soaked in the sauce was so good. The beef was cooked perfectly. Love the grilled peppers,  onions and fries too.

I would definitely recommend going here if you want to try good Peruvian food. They have good price as well.
author: Thanh T.

description:
Garlic Central! No box of Altoids could erase the traces of garlic in your mouth, might not be best date night meal for most people, but for us we were all in! Recommended to us by my boyfriend's friend. We went there expecting traditional Peruvian food. And it's exactly what we got. Total fan of Saltado de Pollo, lean strips of seasoned chicken on top of a pile of french fries, loaded with garlic. All washed down with a pitcher of sangria, one of the best places to go when in the mission! 
Good service, clean spot. Got to go back for the Ceviche fosho!
author: Samira S.

description:
If Limon Rotisserie is modern, then Mi Lindo Peru is as traditional as it gets. Run by mom and pops. I was excited and we got the Chicharron De Calamares, Ceviche De Pescado, Empanadas, Chicharron Al Ajo, Lomo Saltado, Chupe De Camarones and Aji de Gallina. 

The Calamares was done right. The right amount of crispiness and not too overcooked. It was easy to eat and the sauce was a great compliment.

The Ceviche Pescado was overdone, perhaps it was let to sit in the marinade a bit too long as it was "overcooked" and it was a bit on the sour side.

The Empanadas were very large, but the flavor was lacking. It was a bit bland, but still good as the crust was light and flaky.

O Man Chicharron Al Ajo. My favorite appetizer of the night. The chicken was so tender and juicy. The chicken fried just right and the garlic, O the garlic....so delicious that after the chicken was done I was scooping it up to eat with the garnish on the sides.

The Chupe de camarones was  delicious. It's hard to describe it but here goes. It was thick but leaned on the watery side of thick, the flavor was somewhat familiar but could not put a finger on it and the soup, i believe the soup also had rice in it as well as small and big shrimps and bits of meat.

My another two of my favorites from the night was the Lomo Saltado and Aji de Gallina. The Lomo saltado had so much flavor, the sauce was so delicious and went well with the fries and rice. My only complaint was that the beef was a little tough but its lean steak so its understandable. Still loved it. 

The Aji de Gallina was very delicious as well and definitely reminded me of curry. But this was so much better than curry, the super hot sauce went so well with the yellow sauce.

And everything we had went well with their Chicha Morada, their Chicha Morada is as good as it gets, homemade, what else could you ask for? I would suggest taking out the ice as it dilutes it quite a bit.

If I did not have their empanadas and their ceviche not as overdone, it would have gotten 4.5 stars.
author: Reginald W.

description: Awesome food and great customer service. BUT this restaurant needs a very good cleaning, menus, walls, etc. Hard to eat when you see dirtiness all around you.
author: Noe D.

description:
Peruvian food is probably my favorite type there is. LOVE this place, their sangria is my favorite you definitely have to order at least one glass. I think what I like most about this place is their service though. I am a sucker for service, I've always worked in sales so I know what a different customer service makes.

When you walk in you're greeted, seated then offered bread. If it's your first time trying peruvian food I recommend trying the Lomo Saltado its  delicious with rice, steak, french fries, chopped tomatoes and onions.

Prices are good, I always have leftovers... this place is the best.
author: Aundria G.

description:
Delicious and authentic Peruvian cuisine that lacks the blandness that some of the overpriced Americanized/"fusion" restaurants have, but also takes a refreshing step up from the "hole in the wall" vibe that most authentic joints tend to have.

Small but cozy inside. Friendly service. And best of all, pollo saltado to die for.
author: John C.

description:
Go here!

This place is a gem. 

Their Lomo Saltado is amazing and so are the mussels with the salsa on top... oh and just the bread and salsa alone is delicious! 

I'm sure everything else is great too, but I haven't tried it all.
author: Marisa D.

description:
I ordered the Lomo Saltados. It was pretty good and juicy, but the fries tasted a bit too soggyish, not my style. 

My cousin ordered the fried fish, which was way too dry. It was kind of hard to eat =(

Friend ordered this chicken dish, which she thought it was good, but not as good as my dish. 

I came to this place hoping the food was different since I never had Peruvian food, but it didn't wow me, except the spicy salsa. 

Waitress was friendly.
author: Sandy T.

description:
After my first ever, albeit limited, foray into Peruvian food & drink, the girlfriend thought it would be a good time to expand this horizon some more. She proposed dinner at one of her favorite Peruvian (or any other cuisine, for that matter) places & exalted the flavors to be found there. Intrigued by the praises, I was game. So we were off & away from the tourist-y Piers to Bernal Heights . Mi Lindo Peru is itself as much a contrast to the loud, modern Peruvian bar we were just at as its neighborhood is to the Pier 1 1/2 location of that previous stop. Walking through the narrow door on the left of a bright, bold red-painted exterior, the inside, also painted red, offers a warm, homey feeling.
 
Arriving ahead of the dinner rush, we were seated immediately. Service was friendly & attentive. I began to survey the menu, but the girlfriend already had something specific in mind. She ordered & I awaited the food of her high acclaim. The wait was not long.
 
Out came appetizers of Gambos al Ajillo (shrimp in butter/garlic sauce) & Papa aia Huancaina (potato in a spicy cheese sauce) along with bread, butter & salsa. The shrimp was simply awesome. With the aid of some of the bread, the plate was completely cleaned of all traces of the butter/garlic sauce.

This was not the only time the bread would be drenched & slathered in awesomeness, however. The salsa was crazy delicious with distinct, unique flavors I had never tasted before. Spreading butter & then salsa on top of that onto bread might sound odd, but just do it - awesome, really.

The cold-pressed potato in cheese sauce appetizer was good too, though the sauce didn't have the delicacy or complexity of a similar sauce at our previous Peruvian eatery. The version at Mi Lindo Peru was more home-style.

To wash down our food, the girlfriend had a glass of sangria. I thought I'd give Peruvian beer a try so I had a Cristal. The beer wasn't anything special, but I tried the girlfriend's sangria & that was definitely the way to go.

Next came our entrees: Aji de Gallina (chicken in a creamy yellow sauce) & Lomo Saltado (beef strips on french fries). The beef strips & fries were good. In most other meals this dish would have been very well liked (& yeah, sure I still liked it enough), but this time it was completely overshadowed by the chicken in a yellow sauce of incredible flavors that I, yet again, had never tasted before. The sauce was reminiscent of a creamy Thai curry, but definitely with a Peruvian twist that was unlike anything I had ever tried before. Only a few bites were necessary to elevate this dish from unknown to one of my absolute favorites.

I love this dish so much that I already went back with the girlfriend a 2nd time shortly after this 1st visit for more. We, again, got the Gambos al Ajillo, tried the Causa de Pollo (mashed potato stuffed chicken salad) which was quite yummy & of course, got 2 orders of Aji de Gallina (1 to eat & 1 to take home). We also took home a cup of the salsa.

Mi Lindo Peru has quickly become one of my favorite places to eat. It is indeed a rarity that a single restaurant would introduce me to this many previously not experienced, exquisite & superlative flavors. The feel is warm & homey. Service is excellent. Mi Lindo Peru really is as good as it gets.
author: John M.

description: Don't  be fooled by the bad reviews .  U gotta come here and try it yourself.    Saltado de pollo , lomo saltado , mar y tierra , bistec a lo pobre and the salad is off da hook.  Sangria is good and service is good and fast.
author: Joe B.

description: Excellent service and food! Perfect for the nights when you have a craving but don't feel like going to one of the busier peruvian restaurants in the city.
author: Anastasia H.

description:
Mi Love-o

Sometimes I work at St. Lukes Hospital and I have taken collegues to this location twice.  Each time EVERY person in my party has been excited about their food.  Chicken and Rice are excellent!
author: Kevin H.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru isn't as lindo as I thought it would be. 

Our waiter was a nice guy and very on top of it, and the place was almost full. My biggest disappointment was the food. I've had gambas al ajo before in other restaurants, and ordered it. While my boyfriend got the ceviche. 

My gambas had some weird brown thing on it, I wasn't sure if it was garlic or something else, but it was just very nasty. And my boyfriend figured out the peruvian ceviche is kinda very different from the mexican one. There was no tostadas with his plate. It was very acidic fish and veggies. 

And on top of that, it was pretty expensive. Sorry, I won't be back.
author: Sophia G.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru has very reasonable prices and very good quality - better than expected. Very friendly service too. Put aside any hangups about modest surroundings.

Pro Move: Think twice before bringing a car unless you definitely need it. Parking in the Bank of America lot costs an annoying $12 flat fee, regardless of time, and street parking in the surrounding blocks isn't too tough to find.

Our purpose for the visit was the fried chicken (chicharron al ajo) which was on the greasy side but the fried garlic contributed to that.  It obviously wasn't fried in a southern US style to which my gf and I were accustomed, but the Peruvian style allows for a lot of fried garlic and heavy amount of lemon sauce, as desired. 

The cilantro rice with seafood was good but not great. The rice was cooked well but the seafood was not tender enough. However the arroz con pollo was quite tender and was our favorite dish.
author: Mike H.

description: I literally get so excited when I come here!!! Its ridiculous. I become a child and cannot contain myself. I love the ceviche, beef heart, but my most recent favorite dish is the fried red snapper!!! I would punch a baby just to look at this dish. It's amazing and really fresh. The staff here is always super happy and down to talk about any dish. Come here hungry and order more than you think you can eat, because you know, YOLO.
author: Eucalyptus J.

description: Some things were a hit (cassava) and some things were a miss (my steak was so blah). I think their seafood and fried rice dishes are pretty solid, but their prices (a little too high IMO) and some lackluster dishes make it hard to love this place. I did really enjoy the purple corn drink and would come back to enjoy it with some more fried cassava.
author: Kitty L.

description:
The food at Mi Lindo Peru is phenomenal and affordable. I ordered a chicken dish along with some fried plantains. The servings are huge, so I wasn't able to finish it all. The leftovers  served as a nice lunch for the following day (the flavor remained in tack). 

The food there taste so authentic and incredibly fresh. The restaurant is not pretentious, but rather provides a cozy, relaxed, homey atmosphere. 

While you're there, order a Pisco Sour -- by far the best I've had in SF.
author: Abena O.

description:
I went during lunch. The restaurant was pretty empty, I'm assuming they're better hours are for dinner. I ordered a salchipapas. And sadly disappointed. Presentation was lacking and flavor absent. The salchipapas that I know has sauce and doesn't taste like fried and hotdogs (which is what the dish is) it has its own flavor. Strike one. 
Next up was the tallarin Salgado con carne. Not bad. Different from what i remember. Good none the less. Well cooked steak and stir fried spaghetti. Will I return? Perhaps. Will it be my first Peruvian Restaurant choice? Not likely.
author: Christian C.

description:
Not accustomed to Peruvian Food, so my review may be skewed.
Went for Lunch on a weekday & enjoyed the experience tremendously from the simple yet warm family restaurant to the food itself. Had the Pescado Saltado & it was great. Tasted the marriage of soy sauce, tomatoes, veggies with the tender red snapper-- divine! Gracias :)
author: BeBe D.

description: We love coming here!  Have been to Mi Lindo many times.  Recently brought some friends to share in the experience.  We had the chicken wings, platanos and yucca for appetizers.  The chicken wings (chicharon style) are always great tasting with good texture in the coating.  The lemon flavored dipping sauce is fantastic as well.  The platanos are sweet and tasty, almost a dessert.  The yucca frita is good too, just enough salt for seasoning and the cheese dipping sauce tastes great with this.  The salsa for the bread is spicy but not too much and doesn't linger.  Most of us had the lomo saltado, the steak cooked perfectly, the fries just a bit of crunch.  You just can't go wrong with it.  Will explore the menu more next time but we continue to love this place!
author: Scott P.

description: I had the sopa ala criolla and the lomo saltado. I liked the lomo saltado, particularly the vegetables, spices and the sauce or broth. The meat was passable but not very inspiring. The soup was not very interesting. I forgot what my dinner companion ordered but she had been to Mi Lindo Peru before, ordered something she had before and said it was not as she expected. She was disappointed. I view restaurants with two prisms: Did I enjoy the experience I just had? The taste of the food and the other parts of the experience. And then also comparing it against other options, would I come back? On the first count, the food was okay but on the second measure, there are so many food options in SF, I probably wouldn't feel compelled to go back.
author: Gerard P.

description:
Having super picky eaters at home, and doing take out every friday "Mi Lindo Peru" didnt disappoint.  Placed my order, guy athe other end was super friendly. My food order for 5 ppl took 20 minutes.  I had the lomo saltado, gambas al ajo, the pollo saltado and shrimp . All the portions are enough for 2 people to share. the price was super affordable and the service was great, I was helped out to my car by a worker with my bags...
How is the food???  tasty!!
author: Claudia E.

description: Went here last night, , omg,, the BOMB!!!,, the best lomo saltaldo hands down, , and the best salsa for the bread when your seated!!!
author: Dennis B.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru?

I thought you knew! 

Went here recently for a UYE so here's my review. 

Great for groups of 30 + or a nice romantic dinner for two.

Met some cool folks Daniel L, Marti L, and even a Manabu. 

The memorable dish of the night from me to you 
is the garlic fried fish, it makes your breath eww!

The lomo saltado and ceviche are other dishes to look forward too.

Service was friendly, from my point of view.

Next time I want Peruvian, this will be my tried and true.

Just wished they played some more Blink 182.
author: Earl G.

description:
Oh, the places you'll go and the people you'll see...

Peter and I went to a UYE event at Mi Lindo Peru last night...it was, in a word,  SATISFYING. 

We met each other at the 24th Street BART station, walked the few blocks through the vibrant (and ever changing) MIssion District and arrived at one of the cutest, cleanest and most colorful places in the area. 

Which, was clearly the site of the aforementioned Yelp event. Three large tables of people sat cheek to jowl, chatting with each other, greeting new arrivals and generally Having A Good Time. 

I'm always astounded at how a small restaurant manages to pull off serving 35 (or so) hungry Yelpers without any major foul-ups. And Carlos and crew really *did* do this. The food just kept coming and coming...fish, rice, salsa...you name it, arrived fresh from the kitchen with nary a glitch. 

We passed the plates around family style, putting food at Daniel L's place as he was dancing about taking his role as host *quite* seriously. I mean, there was some concern that he would never get to taste the food that he had ordered. 

I would be happy to describe the nature and seasoning of each dish
but frankly, each serving was better than the next. I'll leave the actual food reviews to my fellow Yelpers who have a more discerning palate than my own. Absolutely everything was delicious...and Peter and I are sure to return to this wonderfully casual and festive place. Next time, we'll really read the menu. This time, we just dived headlong into the food. 

Thank you to Carlos for creating a setting where we were all comfortable...and for the formidable task of serving marvelous dishes to so many "critics" at the same time.

Thank you to Daniel and Marti for hosting the event. And for providing us with an amazing celebration of our Yelp friendships. 

And a shout-out to Ligaya for attending the event. I enjoyed chatting with her as we walked from MiLindoPeru to MItchell's Ice Cream around the corner.  

It was, all in all...a beautiful night, at a beautful restaurant. With truly beautiful people.

And did I mention the "bill," if you could call it that...

$12.00. 

The restaurant threw in three special dishes for free. 
I took BART on a senior pass. 
Daniel gave all members of the gathering gift cards to Mitchell's for ice cream. 
RInky and MIke gave us a lift back across the Bay. 

Positively outrageously 
Beautiful. 
Even my +1 thought so...and (you will remember from prior reviews) 
He loves being Mr. Frugal. 

Thank you all...
author: Dorothy C.

description:
Being able to dine at Mi Lindo Peru and being able to hang out with 30+ Yelpers for a UYE event at the same time deserves more than 5 stars.

Hosted by Marti L and Daniel L, this "little" UYE event was full of laughs and fun and of course delicious food.

So heres a quick rundown of what I tried last night...
- Bread n Salsa - Jason told me to try this, get some butter on it and then put some salsa. But he warned me the salsa would be spicy. I was like "PSSSHH I'm Taiwanese I love spicy!" And he was right, this does creep up on you..but its so good. You know how some spicy things can start to make you salivate ? Yea this salsa does that.

-Fried Fish w/ Garlic - this was very very good. I dont know how else to explain this dish, its fried fish with lots of garlic on top. And its just really good.

-Lomo Saltado - its like a mix of beef and french fries. I like this a lot too, seemed a bit funny but was quite tasty.

- Fried Chicken - I can't say I enjoyed this one too much, kind of dry. everything else around it was good..like the sauce. I'll give it a shot again next time.

-Saltado de Pollo - like the lomo but with chicken instead of beef. If I had to pick between the two, I'd stick with the beef but this is quite good for all those non beef eaters out there.

- Potato sandwich thing - This thing was quite tasty. Not sure what it was called but Jason ordered it. Its a pretty small dish but its quite heavy so you wouldnt want to eat alot of it. What looks like bread slices is actually like flattened out mashed potato and between it was like chicken I believe..argh i dont remember but im going back to try that too.

- Paella - very nicely done, the last time I had a good paella was at my friends place. But I'm sure paella is a piece of cake for Mi Lindo.

There were some dishes that I didnt get around to. But the way I see it, this event was kind of like a tasting and a way to get everyone together and have a good time. 

Thanks again to Marti L. and Daniel L. for organizing this event. It was just a great night. Oh and to top it off they passed out Mitchell's Gift cards..and that is where we headed to after.

Wowzers a great meal and then some great dessert all with great company~! What more could you really ask for?

photos from the event are up.... http://www.flickr.com/photos/37618491@N03/sets/72157623561857329/
author: phillip w.

description:
Coming from a long long line of pet guinea pig fanatics, I was a little bit nervous trying Peruvian food for the first time.  All I knew was that in Peru they eat guinea pigs; which is pretty much like eating human children in my family.  Eat all the rabbits, squirrels, whatever you want, but guinea pigs?!  Anyway I digress...

There were no guinea pigs in all of the culinary creations served at our giant, U shaped, table maze of awesome Yelpers.

The service was top notch! They kept track of individual drink orders, water, checking in, quantity of food ordered, and big smiles!  

Food seemed to just keep coming! Tasty bite after tasty bite.  I tried very hard to try everything so lets see how  I do:

Ceviche- Possibly my favorite ceviche I've ever had.  They fish was thick but not too thick, there were calamari rings and tiny shrimp in it too. The lime was prevalent but not over powering.

Fried Plantains with Sour Cream-I've never had this be bad in my life.  This continues that trend.

Corn Rice with a stir fry of chicken and french fries, another had beef and french fries- Sound weird?  I though so too.  But much to my pleasant surprise, it was quite enjoyable.

Fried Fish with Garlic on Top- By far my FAVORITE dish and very popular.  And for good reason. Perfect frying is an art.  Mi Lindo Peru has that down.  With perfectly fried minced garlic topping, 4 or 5 orders disappeared in a flash.

Fried Chicken Wings-Not your typically over breaded fried chicken wings.  Much more like the fried chicken I have had a Indian restaurants in Malaysia, these were piping hot and TASTY!  Some sort of tart dressing made them that much better.

Paella-I don't know what Peruvian Paella is supposed to be like, but this was delicious!

Cilantro Fried Rice-Ok, I'm sure that's not what it is called but it's what it was.  A+

Overall this was an amazing gathering. Huge props to Daniel L and Marti L. for organizing this very affordable, delicious, and amazing event (thanks for my scoop of ice cream too!  You guys are super sweet).  As usual, I'm always excited to see all my wonderful yelp friends and I have to say thanks to Mr. Darryl P. for giving me a ride so I didn't have to walk a million blocks through the ghetto-parking was quite easy.

Save The Guinea Pigs, Eat A Rabbit!
author: Susan C.

description:
Hubby and I had the great pleasure to join 28 or so fellow Yelpers in a fun-filled evening with delicious food at Mi Lindo Peru.  Hosted by lovely Marti and the gracious Daniel L--it was a super success!

I'm sorry I didn't get to meet everyone but the warmth and friendliness abounded!  I did get to meet Ligaya, Yelp royalty--she is just one of the "funnest" people on Earth! She is also able to talk about any food or any subject!  I think we teased Earl's wife, Joyce, a little too much.  She mentioned that she was expecting in a couple of months and loved eating so we kept shoving plates in her direction.  She took it all in stride with such great humor, as if we were life long friends!  Also got to meet super Yelper Hen and several other Yelpers----what a treat to meet new folks!

And great as always to see my buds, Tom R, Manabu, Dorothy and Peter!

Before I get to the food I have to mention that the service was perfect!
Carlos and his staff were friendly and attentive.  As soon as emptied our many carafes of water they were refilled.  The plates of food came in a steady stream but not so fast that we felt rushed.  This is really a mark of a well run and organized restaurant.

Hubby and I shared a salad and two vegan dishes:

Paella de Verduras (Saffron-flavored Spanish rice with vegetables)

Saltado de vegetables (Sauteed onions. celery, carrots, mushrooms, tomatoes, french fries with seasoned rice.

Both are dishes were satisfying and huge!  I think we must have gotten a double order.  

We got a separate check which is yet another reason to love this place.

A perfect UYE!
author: Rinky N.

description:
3.5 great service
Went here for lunch with co-workers.  
Chicken ajo good  but needed salt
Arroz con pollo was good but it lacked something, I don't know what.  
Chicha morada, yumm.
author: Claire J.

description: French fries , rice and cheap meat for $17. How is this Peruvian food . Service was okay
author: ferhat n.

description: Great food just fell short of my local so cal favorite pollo inka but definitely worth the trip
author: Jose M.

description:
Lomo saltado. So. Good.

The staff is incredibly friendly and the food is tasty. It is very cozy, and pretty authentic. This is what I crave when I'm away in Chicago. The portions are huge and the prices are unbeatable.

If you're looking for great Peruvian food in the city, I highly recommend this place.
author: Bernadette R.

description: Love, love, love their food.  Always great service and hot, fresh food.  I look forward to going here at least once while in San Francisco.  Parking sucks but that's about the only downside.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
I was hoping that this place would be really good after seeing the reviews on yelp and the high rating.
unfortunately it was a little disappointing. The ceviche was actually very sour. I think it was over-limed. the lomo saltado with fried egg and plaintain was good and tasty but i think it was a little on the salty side. 
similarly, the Aguadito De Mariscos (seafood cilantro soup) was also a little too salty and didnt have too much cilantro taste. 
The prices arent actually that cheap compared to the other Peruvian restaurants in the bay area. It is definitely not the best Peruvian restaurant in the bay area but its also not the worst.
author: Alex H.

description:
food is really good here, will definitely come back! wish they would have brought out the entrees a bit later because we were still working on our appetizers.

my boyfriend liked his lamb and i loved my salad. the mac n cheese is pretty good, but once you eat the top layer, there's nothing special about it.

not a good place for large parties. and you will be sitting very close to your neighbors.
author: Sofia M.

description: Yummy!!! Food was amazing and the service was great! Big portions and the sangria was great!! would def. come here again!
author: Cynthia N.

description: Great service and good food.  Not a fan of eating rice AND potatoes so I always ask for salad instead of potatoes.  Staff is so accommodating.  The salad is always fresh, as is the bread.  One of my favorite lunch spots!
author: sumaya g.

description:
After a tiring morning of "Feedin the needy" as Nancy R. put it, we carpooled on over, parked in the Burger King parking lot and walked up the block to Mi Lindo Peru. It was raining dogs, frogs and polliwogs but we got inside and warmed right up. The waiter even mopped up our umbrellas and the floor with a towel. How sweet. and then.. the sun came out... lol

Cassava  fries = ok
loma? = really good
gaspar al ajo? (i cant remember but it was shrimp in garlic and wine for $16) = awesome
crab dip w/ crackers = yummy

the entree's came with rice and everything was FRESH and HOT!! I loved it and i'll probably come back with my mother... even though it's a bit pricey.

Oh, and they can only split the bill two ways...
author: Brianna S.

description: Not very authentic. Peruvian food is very flavorful and this wasn't at all. The service was good but a waiter was in a bad mood... We order the jalea but the salsa was lacking as well as the sauce for the yuca... I'm from Perú; born and raised there... Not recommended...
author: Rosario B.

description:
3 stars, why you say??

I dont know if it was cuz i took the food to go and didnt appreciate the ambiance inside of the restaurant while eating there but the food to me was just ok, the pescado al ajo(fried red snapper w/butter sauce and touch of white wine) was excellent i give them that, but everything else we ordered was just ok.

here is the breakdown of what we got : 
Anticuhos - beef heart grilled shish kebab style
Arrozcon Pollo - chicken rice peas, sauteed w/ cilantro sauces
Milaneaa De Pollo - basically chicken fried steak with white rice and corn
Paella Marinera - saffron flavored spanish rice w/ seafood
Pescado al Ajo - fried red snapper w/ butter garlic sauce & touch of white wine

the heart was super gamey, lil to gamey for me and that sez alot cuz i like to eat goat, lamb, antellope hahha u get it. There version of chicken fried steak i was excited for until I took th first few bites and realized it needed a sauce of some sort to help it down, I guess I just was not use to chicken fried steak not coming with a type of gravy. Their paella for me was a miss had a strong smell but average taste kinda lacked something, you know that feeling you get when you bite into something and hope every never ending in your mouth should get hit, sadly their paella did not do the job. The Pescado Al Ajo to me was the best thing on there menu by far bumped up the stars on my review fried red snapper with butter garlic sauce

Fish alone is not one of my favorite dishes but if it is made right I would go back again just for that dish, here fish was fried tender and flaky on the inside and on the out crisp to the crunch the sauce of course also helped, butter garlic you can taste on every bite meshed well with the white rice not so much the arroz con pollo or the paella. Yum definitely would head back just for there fish everything else don't think I would order again, I also tried to get their version of lamb shanks (Seco De Cordero) but they did not have any = (

food *** not super good just ok
Pescado Al Ajo ***** dam I can't say enough bout that red snapper
price $$
ambiance *** all red inside with decoration on the wall lil dark even during the day
customer service **** they are very helpful and informative
author: Clarence A.

description:
We tried this place for lunch. We ordered: 

Sangria
Anticuhos - beef kabobs appetizer
Yucca Frita - yucca fries appetizer
Arrozcon Pollo - Chicken entree
Pescado Saltado - Fish entree
We also requested our server to give us some extra peruvian chutneys - red, yellow and green ones. They are amazing and must haves!

We loved everything that we ordered. The chicken dish was very different and very tasty! The Sangria was also good.

Would love to come back to this place!
author: Parminder Nayyar C.

description:
The pops was not happy when we told him that we were going to have chicken nuggets for dinner.

"You want fries with that?"

We were one order short of McDonalds. The pops was pist. He had made reservations at Limon and we stood Limon up in favor of adding another kiddie to the dinner table.

Mi Lindo Peru turned out to be an even better choice than Limon. Mi Lindo Peru combines Peruvian and Spanish cuisine. Brother and I wanted Peruvian and the pops and I have a slight obsession with Spanish food. What can I say? We love our tapas, meat and potatoes.

Dinner consisted of Chicharron Al Ajo, Yucca Frita, Platano Frito, and two orders of Lomo Saltado. Empanadas were no longer available so we gnawed on the complimentary bread. Yes we got butter but we also got spicy salsa. Salsa on bread? HELL YEA! 

The Chicharron Al Ajo came out shortly. They were the chicken nuggets Brother was bragging about. Small pieces of fried chicken with the crispiest skin you could ever imagine. They were covered (covered was an understatement) in minced garlic and when you dipped the chicken in the lemon sauce oh my god. Barbecue sauce and honey mustard have nothing on it. And if you love garlic, chicharron, and anything fried, this was IT. The yucca fries were denser than potatoes and very filling. The fried plantains balanced out the salt on the table. They were so sweet I could eat them for dessert. Plantains are always mandatory.

The Lomo Saltado plate was huge. I wondered why we ordered two and Brother explained the pops said he wanted his own. We all shared anyway and we were able to pack away all those lean and tender strips of beef. The slivers of lightly cooked onions and tomatoes were like fresh salsa for the dish. The beef also came with a pile of papas fritas and tasty white rice. It had everything from A-Z.

Mi Lindo Peru is not trendy nor packed. It's at the top of Mission far enough that there was plenty of parking available. Mi Lindo Peru is like eating at home. It's comfort food in epic proportions. And you can kick back and relax. 

The pops was even ready to say, "Oh sh*t son, this was hella good!" Because it was.   

The pops left happy and even let the kiddies go to Mitchell's for dessert afterwards. 

The end.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Good food. Good service. Great selection.

I enjoyed my self.

A nice family place.
author: Pisco S.

description: One of my & my family's favorite restaurants! Food is bombdiggity! Love everything on the menu!
author: Jae C.

description:
The ceviche was great.  We also got the fried seafood platter (without realizing it was all deep-fried), which was good if you like fried food, but it was too much for us.  
The passion fruit cocktail was really sweet, which I guess I should have suspected.  The place is very well lit, and tables don't have table covers or anything, so it's not a great date place, but good for small groups.  We went at 8pm on a Saturday, and it was surprisingly half empty, which played to our favor - we finished eating & were out by around 8:50.
Our experience was probably 3-stars, but I'd attribute most of that to our ordering choices.  Next time, I'll make sure to get the rice & order sangria instead (which is evidently their specialty).
author: bret s.

description:
Great restaurant.

My family goes here every couple of months because we know the manager, who's a real great guy. He always treats us well and makes sure we're comfortable.

The food is delicious, very prompt and decent portions. You can't go wrong. I've only gone to this Mi Lindo Peru (I know there was a couple out there, don't know if they've sinced closed down)

But yea, I would come in the early afternoon, I don't know how busy it gets at night.
author: Tatiana M.

description: We had a huge party (17 people), and we ordered a bunch of food. The service was really good and attentive. The food was good too. Like your typical Peruvian food, lots of good fried food. And they have this special fruit drink that was super sweet, but pretty good.
author: Arnold W.

description: LOMO SALTADO. what else? Good food for a good price. Been here a couple times already and I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Cecilia B.

description: Great Peruvian food. Nice family restaurant. I've tried  almost everything on the menu. It never disappoints.
author: Lisa R.

description:
i've been here three times, and every time my experience just gets better and better.  

every time i've been here, it was a little after 2pm and they close at 230 so it was pretty empty.  

they provide complimentary bread, butter, and a spicy salsa to dip the bread in.  as spicy as it was, i found myself continuously dipping my bread in it.  the flavors were amazing.

my dad ordered Jalea as an appetizer but is found on the seafood portion of the menu.  it consisted of deep fried fish strips, fried yucca topped with fried calamari and shrimp served with a aioli type dipping sauce.  it was all cooked perfectly. light golden brown with a good crunch to it.  

i ordered lomo saltado which was lean strips of beef sauteed with onions, tomatoes, and french fries served with rice or salad.  i had it with rice.  This was a light dish.  it wasn't greasy at all.  i couldve lived without the french fries but it seemed like lots of their dishes had it in them.  overall, this dish was DELICIOUS.

friendly staff, fast, and fresh!
author: M B.

description:
Ah the secret's out! 

Its been awhile since I've been back to Mi Lindo and man does it sure look like the cat's outta the bag. Stopped in yesterday for a couple orders of their Lomo Saltado for takeout and Mi Lindo was packed to the gills (and it was ~9pm!). Glad to see that they're doing well.

The Lomo Saltado was just as good as I remember. Kudos to Mi Lindo for including their spicy salsa-like side and even a portion of their bread!

This place is still holdin' down my #1 spot for killer peruvian food in SF.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
ok... so, yes.. I might be tipsy.. and maybe tomorrow I will be sorry... but somehow I don't think so... I give Mi Lindo Peru 5 stars while I am tipsy after having two of their Pisco Sours..  what else can I tell you? Those cocktails are delicious.. and strong! Their ceviche is abundant and fresh.... their yucca is to die for... their seafood dishes are unforgettable.... and the mango mousse that I finished a mere 30 min ago was para chuparse los dedos!!!  
   The service is friendly, efficient and unpretentious... you hardly ever have to wait for a table... and the prices are really reasonable... 
If you want to break your bank at el Limon, or dine with a hipper crowd at el Destino, help yourself! I will gladly take your table at Mi Lindo Peru...   :)
author: ania w.

description: Great place. Good food. Great portions. The plates do have a lot going on though. The dish I ordered was bistek grilled with onions and plantains. The order just had a lot of flavors and the plantains were sweet. Which may not be for everyone.  Overall good experience. And don't forget to grab an Inca cola
author: Nikole D.

description: This place is the best! I love their Lomo Saltado. It has lots of flavor and never disappoints. Whenever I'm in the mood for Peruvian food, this is the place to go!
author: Mariella A.

description: We ordered the Ceviche de Mariscos, Saltado de Pollo and the Pescado al Ajo and each dish was delicious and so flavorful!!!  I came here once before, about 7yrs ago and haven't been back since until just recently and I was happy that it was still as good as I had remembered.  The servers were pleasant during our time there and the portions for all of the dishes that we had ordered were more than sufficient to share between the three of us.
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
I'd never had Peruvian food before...but it's delicious!  It's interesting how french fries are mixed in with a lot of their dishes.  Jill K. tells me Peru has like the largest variety of potatoes or something...who knew?

Their lomas saltado was so good I inhaled the whole plate.  And their sangria was a great compliment to the meal.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
The Ceviche Mariscos was good and fresh, but I found it too expensive for the portion size. Arroz con Pollo was huge. Tons of rice, with peas and corn, but I only  found 3 pieces of chicken and I felt that the dish was overpowered by the taste of cumin. The empanada was ok. the meat mixture was much more sweet than I would have thought.

Service was great! Our waiter and server, kept our water glasses filled and our needs taken care of.

I was expecting more from Mi Lindo Peru, because of all the wonderful reviews, but I will probably be coming back to try the other items on the menu.
author: Robin K.

description: I absolutely love this place. I've been coming here for years and it's still one of my favorite restaurants. I used to get the picante de mariscos a lot when I was younger but now I get the lomo saltado, they're both amazing. The service is great and  it has a delightful ambiance to it. 5 stars!
author: Jill P.

description: We have been driving from Oakland for years for the fish at this place.  We get the fried snapper with the onion topping they put on the steak.  We also get the salad with potatoes and the noodles and vegetables.  We are stuck on this combination because it is so good.  Everything is fresh and cooked to perfection.  The food preparation is very consistent.  The service is great and the prices are very reasonable for the amount of food.  The ambiance is basic which suits us fine because we just care about the food.  One of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco!
author: Larry R.

description:
They have paella! Maybe i don't need to be impressed by that but i really don't find that many places that make it so it's sort of a no brainer for me. I've only ever had paella in Spain so i guess it can't quite compare but i figure for stateside paella i'm pretty happy with it.

and i rarely talk about service but it's really excellent here, not gonna lie they take care of you quickly and efficiently.

parking is really tough tho...
author: Misha T.

description: Had wanted to eat Peruvian food for a while, had spoken with a friend about going for a while and today we made time to go and have Peruvian food. I had the Arroz con Pollo. Huge serving of delicious arroz, veggies with huge pieces of chicken.  Yum! I was only able to eat 1/3.  Waitress was very nice and boxed my leftovers. To drink I had a glass of their house Sangria, small but tasty. Total bill for 3 persons; a dish & a drink came to about $55
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I had been wanting to eat Peruvian food for a while especially since I made a new friend whose from Peru. With my luck, Kahanalei M'. wanted to come here to celebrate her birthday. We ended up ordering three dishes: Ceviche de Mariscos, Saltado de Pollo, and the Pescado al Ajo.

Ceviche de Mariscos: Cold Snapper fish with prawns, calamari, and onion in a lime sauce.

Saltado de Pollo: Stir-fry chicken with vegetables and rice.

Pescado al Ajo: Steamed or fried snapper fish with garlic, butter, and white wine sauce with rice. 

I'm glad I tried all three dishes but my ultimate favorite was the pescado al ajo because it was extremely flavorful and garlicky, which I love. I also liked the saltado de pollo because it reminded me of a dish my grandma would've made. It had that very hearty homemade taste, but what do I know? 

The waiters were very attentive when it came to refilling our water glasses - my glass never went dry. They were also very pleasant and didn't mind our extended stay. 

I will definitely come back for the pescado al ajo!
author: K. E.

description:
I've never really known Peruvian food (but Ceviche and I get along just fine) until Mi Lindo Peru. B suggested this venue for a goodbye dinner for the wonderful food, and what a great choice! 

First order of business, order a pitcher or two of Sangria. Ceviche is always good to start off with, so please do. Then, order the seafood soup (SO much seafood) and the whole fish deep fried with garlic and you can tell your taste buds to thank you immediately. I was skeptical whilst B was raving about the garlic fish, but he was not wrong (he very seldom is, when it comes to food). Even after everyone at our table was full (portions are huuuge), they still could not resist picking at B's plate of garlic fish. 

I'm definitely coming here again, especially since prices are reasonable for the amount and quality of food you get.
author: Julia C.

description:
A member of our group was reading the NY Times Travel section and it was discussing Peruvian food in SF. Of the restaurants mentioned, Mi Lindo was among the most "unpretentious" and so we decided to give it a shot. The other restaurants featured in the article appeared upscale, intimidating, and expensive; not Mi Lindo!

I'll just go ahead and begin by revealing the primary driver of my 3 star rating. The waiter kindly brought water to our table, a standard restaurant courtesy. All was well.  A few minutes later, I notice my water glass has lipstick marks; I'm FREAKED OUT! It was pink. NOBODY in our party was wearing lipstick. I know I didn't mix glasses with the guy across from me! THIS IS DISGUSTING!!!

I remained cool as I quietly placed the glass on the adjacent table and proceeded to mentally begin planning my Yelp review! I hope this was an isolated and accidental incident. But in my mind, I was targeted! 

Aside from the above noted MAJOR problem, the food good. When the waiter brought out the dishes, the smell was amazing. Taste was great as well. We ordered drinks: Sangria. It was my first Sangria, so I can't compare, but I hope it was a clean glass.

Dessert was good as well: Chocolate Cake and Fried Banana With A Peruvian Ice Cream. The chocolate cake clearly wasn't a Peruvian dish and now that I think of it, why did I order chocolate cake? But the Fried Banana w/ Ice Cream was tasty and full of goodness. Plus, unlike the chocolate cake, it actually tasted like the dish was prepared on-site in there own kitchen.

The atmosphere is very casual and simple. No need to impress anybody here! I would go back if not for the water incident.
author: Nathan E.

description: Food was fantastic, portions large, service attentive. Plantains particularly good, as were the fish with garlic, and the fried chicken appetizer. I would definitely return
author: Kris F.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Francisco.....

I've been here numerous times.  I always order the same thing.  Gambas Al Ajillo (prawns sauteed in a garlic sauce) AND Saltado De Pollo (chicken sauteed w / onions, tomatoes & french fries) or Pescado Saltado(red snapper sauteed w/ onions, tomatoes,french fries).

AND the sangria is sooooo Good. Two glasses & I'm feeling great :)

The service is superb.  Carlos is super duper extra cute & very pleasant and polite.  He always greets me when i come in & always sits me at my favorite table.

If you've never been here, what are you waiting on??.. GO!!!
author: nicole b.

description: This is one Peruvian restaurant that has healthy portions and has a home style taste. No complaints from me about this place.
author: Billy C.

description:
My first introduction to Peruvian food was in So Cal. w/ Don Felix and El Pollo Inka. DAMNNNNNN GOOOD LOMO SALTADO. (if you're ever in so cal def check those places out)

As for Peruvian food in the bay, I first tried out Fresca on Fillmore. To be honest...ehhhh, a little over priced, portion size wasn't all that great, wasn't as tasty as I experienced back home in So Cal.

But then comes MI LINDO PERU. DAMNNNNNN their lomo saltado is FRICKIN AMAZING. Juicy  flavorful steak and nice thick crisp french fries. and the rice has flavor too! It's not just filler. the entire dish is amazing. as for portion size? You definitely get a nice FAT plate of good food. 

I didn't want to write a review until I tried some other dishes. Cuz let's face it, the default dish at a peruvian restaurant is the Lomo Saltado.

Appetizers: Seafood Ceviche is a MUST! Slice of Sweet Yam, Potato, Onions, Succulent fish, and calamari, sprinkled w/ corn nuts and onions,  all on a bed of lettuce drizzled with a great lime sauce. If you're a fan of seafood and things citrus, you'll also be a fan of their ceviche.

I'm also a big fan of curry and things spicy. So I checked out the Aji De Gallina. Steamed potatoes, shredded chicken, and a spicy yellow chili sauce served on a bed of rice. This is pretty damn good too and the amount of spice is just right. Just enough to heat up your tongue but not enough to make you sweat and grab a napkin to wipe that dripping snot off your nose.  

As for desserts. I can't say much, since Mitchell's ice cream is just a block away. My go to place for dessert. So if I ever have a craving for Mitchell's, i'll try my best to stop by this joint. Or if i'm craving Peruvian food, off to Mitchell's!

4 stars for Great food, portions, and service.
author: Micael H.

description: The beef hearts are good!! Their food is very traditional with tones of flavor!!! I love the green sauce. It's extremely spicy so if you do not have a tolerance for hot food I suggest do not try it.
author: Ciara R.

description:
A great evening and a fantastic dining experience.  Mi Lindo definitely lived up the the reviews I read here before venturing out to try it.

Incidentally, I will actually be in Peru in exactly two weeks after eating here so this might be an awesome rehearsal for what's in store there :D

[soapbox] OK... so it's in the Mission, ON Mission.  So be prepared for parking woes (we lucked out with two incredible spots) - and PLEASE, don't ding the restaurant because you couldn't find parking.  I hate when people do this - how is this even remotely in the restaurant's control??? [/soapbox]

Charming little restaurant, full of food smells - so awesome and welcoming!  I think this place can accommodate about 40 people tops but it's still very spacious and you get a lot of privacy even with all the coziness.  I never felt encroached upon by fellow diners.

Nice ambiance and decor (check out the light fixtures that look like seashells).  And the most amazing staff - so friendly, patient and ever so attentive to detail...  I had mentioned earlier on that I was allergic to shellfish and the waiter (I think he was also the owner perhaps) remembered (more later)

We ordered a small carafe of the sangria which was really good and sweet, with apples primarily.  It's nothing to write home about but it was a good smooth drink to accompany the meal.  They also brought out some fresh bread with butter and some hot salsa which was really tasty.

We started off with the Champinones Al Ajillo (mushrooms sauteed in a garlic sauce) and the Ceviche (red snapper  marinated in fresh lime juice).
