Both were pretty substantial and both were delicious.  I loved the mushrooms - the garlic sauce was authoritative without being overwhelming.  The ceviche was just fantastic - so tangy and fresh... the fried corn was a great touch and added some awesome crunch to the raw fresh fish.  Very well executed dish!  A definite repeat.

For the main course, we just ordered one thing - the highly recommended Pescado Al Ajo - we got it steamed - red snapper topped with butter garlic sauce & a touch of white wine.  A pretty substantial portion, easily enough for two, comes with rice, potatoes and a small piece of lettuce and some tomatoes.  It was also delicious, the fish flaking easily and chock full of flavor.  Large pods of garlic complemented the flavor of the garlic butter sauce - again, a dish I'd readily repeat.

Never felt rushed during the almost two hours we were there.  Again, extremely helpful and friendly staff - such a delightful little place - I love places like these that seem "family-run" and that take such pride in their food and their service.  End result was a most enjoyable evening and a guaranteed repeat customer.

~ 5 stars overall - now, I have to compare this with real Peruvian food - look for a possible review update if one is called for :)

# 232
author: Badri N.

description:
This place has the all the potential to become a restaurant representing the best of peru. The menu is authentic and represents classic Peruvian flavors, ingredients, and cooking methodology.  However, mediocre service combined with unprofessional cooking makes me never want to come back.

All these 4- and 5-star reviewers clearly have little idea what great Peruvian food can be. There's at least 4 other Peruvian restaurants in the city that will blow your mind if you think this place is great.

It seemed like Lomo Saltado here is the most popular thing, and also the easiest dish to cook in Peruvian cuisine (you can do it a home, people, its just a slow stir fry of onions, tomatoes and seasoned beef). so for my first meal there, I wanted to try something that would really test the quality of the cooking.

Aji de gallina ($15) is a Peruvian classic dishes that, due to it's complexity, reveals both quality of ingredients and the chef's understanding of both stewing and sautéing. The recipe calls for chicken, cheese, onion, cumin, garlic, and aji peppers -- all together incredibly difficult to balance, and clearly revealed a junior cook using mediocre ingredients. The milk and the cheese felt curdled and tart, instead of creamy and soft. The chicken was dry instead of tender. And the aji, didn't feel any of the signature pepper at all. Clearly, I was very disappointed.

As for the rest of my meal, nothing impressed me enough to come back for a second try.  Avoid the yucca huancaina ($6). The sauce is runny, lacking bite, the yucca under cooked. The flan ($6) was overly thick, and the caramel sauce lacked density.

Skip the free bread. It resembles the large french loafs from the nearby Safeway. If you must have the bread, remove the innards, or risk pre-meal fullness.

I don't usually care for presentation, but decor is uncoordinated. Photos, painting, and metal work evoking Old world heritage clashes with the acoustic tile ceiling, mirrors on columns, and plump kitty ceramic figures on a shelf near the register.
author: Jack Ian L.

description: What this place should really be called is Mi Lindo China. Seriously, yelpers, 4 stars?? Have you all NEVER had chinese food before? It tastes EXACTLY the same as the food at this place. In fact, I propose that they change the name of the lomo saltado to beef lo mein, or beef with vegetables. One yelper mentioned "Flavor Heaven".. yes, that's from the MSG, also another chinese staple. They even have 2 of those chinese ceramic cats (you know, the kind doing the fist pump).  I had the ahi de gaillna and it resembled bad indian food. I am so blown away by the high rating since this is the WORST "peruvian" food I've ever had. To call it peruvian is an insult to places like Fresca which actually make great food. I am so disappointed. If you know what good peruvian tastes like skip this place.
author: Layla L.

description:
This place is freakin good.  

Must haves:
**Mussels- covered in cilantro, lime, and garlic. Drool....
**Shrimp chowder- large prawns and tiny shrimp, creamy and so good!
**Lomo Saltado!!!! LOVE LOVE LOVE! 

I love the unlimited bread and salsa they give you upon arrival! The servers are so friendly and helpful!
author: Melissa C.

description:
Been my "I wanna some Peruvian but not rob my wallet place".

Good food, fast service, casual but friendly.

Taste authentic, and always hit the spot, yeah, the Sangria is pretty damn good here.
author: Alice C.

description:
We came on a Friday night and was seated right away even though there were 5 of us. The ceviche was really good and they had big portions. We also ordered steak but it was overcooked even though we asked for medium rare. All of us ordered a plate and most of us only finished half of the plate. 

Service was alright but the ambiance was nice, it's a small restaurant and everyone was pleasant. 

If Limon is overbooked or you don't want to wait for Limon, go to Mi Lindo Peru for ceviche. 

Parking sucks to find! It's SF what else do you expect?!
author: Anette N.

description: Poor service. We waited 15 minutes and no one said anything to us. Then someone just walked in and they seated him in front of us...  We left.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
I am finally writing about my favorite restaurant, Mi Lindo Peru. I have been coming here for many years now with family and friends...and never been disappointed! Carlos, his sister, and the rest of the crew do a fantastic job of making everyone feel welcomed and satisfied.

Here are my recommendations:

Appetizers:
Causa de camarones- mashed potato with shrimp and mayo: creamy and tasty
Papa a la Huancaina- potato (sliced) with a cheesy sauce: just the right amount of kick in the sauce
Entrees:
Bistec a lo Pobre- steak sauteed with onions/tomatoes and served with a fried plantain & egg: nice and juicy with sauce that enhances the already tasty rice
Lomo Saltado- beef strips with french fries: who can resist that combo?

Wash the meal down with a nice Inca Cola (golden version of Coke), a refreshing Chicha Morada (juice from purple corn), or a cool Sangria...AWESOME!
author: Rod L.

description:
Not that they need another review, but their food made me so happy, I have to rave a little.  Garlic galore! Garlic chicken, garlic shrimp, garlic dip for my delish garlic bread.  Maybe you won't be kissing anyone after eating here, but it won't matter- its just that good.

Double bonus: Their home made sangria...heaven!
author: Jax S.

description:
FLAVOR HEAVEN!!!

I've been here a handful of times, but I can't order any other entree.  Lomo Saltado rocks!  Not a fan of the fried banana, but every other appetizer I've tried has been the bomb!  You must have the empanada...

I love spicy food.  The salsa is PERFECT - right on the border between shiny forehead and fanning myself.  I have to take a few seconds break between bites.

I haven't had a dessert yet.  I never leave enough room.
author: Hester B.

description: Maybe we were there on a bad day, no excuse though good restaurants shouldn't have  bad days. My Jalea the mariscos was huge and it tasted ok except for the onions they were clearly old they tasted horrible and the texture was bad and the waiter did not care or apologized when I let him know.  The aji the gallina was watery and tasted off maybe it was old too. My boyfriend couldn't even eat it and he is Peruvian so he knows what it should look and taste like. Gross.
author: Linda Q.

description: Delicious food. I have never had Peruvian style food. Very different seasonings, some dishes served over french fries or with some type of potatoes. The green salad was even good with avocado, cucumber, potato, tomatoes and an oil & vinegar dressing.  What a wonderful experience!
author: Trish M.

description:
Bread. It was alright, but definitely not the best bread I've ever had. I thought it was too soft and moist.

Salsa. Came with the bread. Definitely spicy even for a spice-head like me. 

Inca Kola. My friend got it but I had a sip and it's pretty much just cream soda. 

Picante De Mariscos. Mussels, Calamari, and Shrimp with Spicy Andian Yellow Chile stewed with a touch of Milk served with Seasoned Rice. I ordered it medium since I saw how spicy the bread salsa was but I figure I could have probably ordered it spicy because it had zero kick to it whatsoever. It was really yummy though! The seafood was really delicious, though I'm pretty sure it were frozen and not fresh. It just didn't have the fresh taste to it, but at these prices I'm not complaining. The sauce was delicious but definitely needed the spiciness.

Seasoned Rice. With Corn. Came with the Seafood. It was alright, but seeing as I'm not a fan of rice, I'm probably not the best person to ask. I figured I should get rice because I hadn't eaten rice as carbs in awhile and I figured my body needed it. Heh.

Fried Plantain. With a side of Cream Cheese (I think.. that's what it tasted like). The plantains were pretty good and I'm so glad they weren't overly burnt. The cream cheese was a bit strange for me though maybe because I'm not used to it but I thought it was a bit weird. 

Lucuma Ice Cream. My friend mentioned that we wanted to try the lucuma at Mitchell's and our server ended up giving this to us on the house to try so we could see if theirs was better or Mitchell's. It was very nice of him and the ice cream was really yummy just like he promised, but we didn't get a chance to try Mitchell's that day so our comparison shall have to wait until the next time. The ice cream was good though, creamy, smooth goodness! 

Their food was pretty good, so I'd be down to come back and try different stuff next time. I really wanted to get ceviche but it was cold and rainy when I went so I will definitely give that a try next time!
author: Constance C.

description: Yum. I had the grilled chicken and my friend had that spaghetti with beef - forgive me for not knowing the names of the dishes. Everything was cooked well and evenly spiced. We also had the calamari which was cooked to perfection. I can't wait to come here again and try more dishes!!
author: Elaine C.

description: I know I should say something else but I can't say enough about the mussels and the aji de gallina. That is all.
author: Edi B.

description:
I went with my family (all Peruvians) and my boyfriend who had never eaten Peruvian before.  We were all pleasantly surprised as we've eaten at almost every other Peruvian restaurant out there.  My aunt had the lomo saltado, which was very tasty.  My mom definitely picked the winner with her Aguadito de Mariscos.  The boyfriend just got the steak which was blah, like any regular flank steak with fries.  I just picked at everyone's plates as the portions are huge and you definitely do not need a plate per person!  

I personally came for the ice cream as I am a complete sucker for Lúcuma ice cream whenever I have the chance!

It was nothing fancy but the restaurant was packed and the staff was hospitable.  Prices were great for the quality and portion size!
author: Juliet K.

description: First time going to this restaurant and I must say I was full and completely satisfied with our dishes. I ordered the saltado de camarones and not only is was it delicious but also a big plate. Everything tastes good and loved the complimentary bread and somewhat spicy salsa.
author: Christian L.

description: I love this restaurant! I've been there several times now, and the service and food are great. I love the bread & butter, the lomo saltado, galea and the chicha. You get a lot of food for your money as well!
author: Assia H.

description:
This place offers decent Peruvian food. Ive had better but it does satisfy the craving for it! I had the saltado de gambas and the ceviches de pescado. the ceviche was amazing, the saltado was a little bland. I definitely needed a little bit more of a kick. you also gotta try their traditional drink called "chicha morrada". it tasted like like hibiscus tea mixed w cinnamon. pretty good.

prices are good (15 for my saltado) and portions are big. come here with a big appetite!
author: Susana M.

description:
Made a special trip to the Mission on a Sunday night to try this place out.
I am a huge fan of Peruvian food, and I'm on a personal mission to try all Peruvian restaurants in the San Francisco area.
I was very pleased with the service @ Mi Lindo Peru. Our waiter had big smile on her face and was very attentive to our needs.  We all had a glass of Sangria, which I must say was very good.  We kept it light this evening, so I didn't get a chance to try as much as I would have liked to.  I definitely plan on returning though, and will keep this post updated.
We had the Ceviche de Mariscos- which was excellent and also had the Camarrone Causa which was also very good. 
I will be a repeat customer!  :)
author: Stacy C.

description: Went to dinner with my parents here. Ordered the arroz con pollo. Spent the next day throwing up.
author: Cynsf Z.

description:
Reasons why we may have scored a complimentary plate of halibut ceviche from the host/waiter at Mi Lindo Peru:

A. My SO is cheap (this leads to B...)

As the SO was about to jump on the phone before I ordered our food, he told me that if the ceviche special of the day was less than $10, we should order it.  Yeeaaah...ceviche for $10?  My SO is not only cheap, he's also naive.

B.  The look of disappointment on my face when I found out the ceviche was $18

When the waiter told me the ceviche special was $18, and knowing what the SO had told me earlier, I dropped my head in disappointment and sadly told the waiter we would order the significantly cheaper potato appetizer.

C.  I busted out the camera

I kept snapping away at each and every dish on our table, so maybe the waiter thought we were food critics?  Ha!  Yeah right, he probably knew I was a Yelper and wanted to score some brownie points in my review.  Well, he sure did!

D.  My dashing good looks (no explanation needed, ha!)

E.  All of the above

Regardless of what the real reason was for us to receive free ceviche when nobody else did, I love Mi Lindo Peru.  This is my go-to spot in the city for Peruvian food.  I've always had great food here.  I'm a fan of their mushroom tapas, their tasty Lomo Saltado dish, their juicy and tender Bistec a lo Pobre, and their generous Arroz con Mariscos plate.  Their portions are huge, which makes this restaurant a bargain bite. Their dishes are meant to be shared, but I've witnessed a guy finish an entire Arroz con Pollo plate.  It's advisable to come in the early evening to avoid the long waits and the big crowds.
author: Diane L.

description:
I have three words to update my last review: Aguadito de Mariscos.

If you like cilantro, and even if you don't - this is a must order soup.

I don't even like soup. But when it's cold outside, nothing else will do. 

Go now. Go often.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
This was a pretty good spot for peruvian food. I came by because a group of friends told me to meet them up here for dinner and it was good. The only bad thing about the place was the sangria was pricy, $20 a tall jug. I ordered a seafood dish with red snapper which was pretty good. 

This place is worth a try!
author: Elliot T.

description: Amazing flavorful Peruvian food! Served in giant portions! My husband and I usually have to split an order. Start with their calamari & order the lomo saltado. Every visit there is great!
author: Sharon N.

description:
came here during lunch with another student 

we ordered our food on the phone ahead of time and it was prepared for us before we got there! usually restaurants don't do this.  

Bread and Butter and Salsa for appetizers - a little cold and not really fresh tasting, but hey, its free

Lomo Saltado - fries and beef - could have given been a more saucy beef, the flavor overall came off as a little plain, but the salsa from the bread really helped.

Fried Chicken Wings - teeny tiny and dry, but crispy...

Overall it was an OK meal, great salsa however
author: Tina A.

description:
I ate the red snapper with garlic butter on Saturday.

I am STILL BURPING UP GARLIC! 

What I'm trying to say is, the food here really stays with you, and I guess with the usual gut rot you get from eating fast food at a pace as feverish as most people these days, it's a welcome change. The food here is plentiful and comes out quickly. The atmosphere is "boisterous night with the in-laws." All the lights came down when it was time to sing Happy Birthday to a complete stranger, and everyone but me chimed in.**

A complimentary jug of sangria was promptly offered up after our long Saturday night wait. Food came out so fast my head was spinning. I was drunk, stuffed 'n' chuffed before I knew it and had to be wheeled out on a gurney. Can't wait to go back.

**I refuse to sing Happy Birthday to anyone.
author: Kat F.

description:
I'm eating the primal blueprint way (variation on the paleo diet - no grains, no sugar, no legumes), so going to South American eataries can be tricky.

However, Mi Lindo Peru is more than happy to swap out rice and bean options for salads, so ordering here was a lot easier! The service was friendly and helpful with suggesting beers and meals for my friends, too.

I got the Pescado Sudado steamed snapper fillet topped w/ onions, tomatoes and potatoes. It wasn't incredible, but it was tasty and HUGE.

My dinner companions ate the Saltado De Pollo, Lomo Saltado, and the Saltado De Vegetables. All of them were happy with their meals (and very full by the end).
author: Mia J.

description: Came here for the first time a few weeks ago and we enjoyed the food.  The waiters were all very nice too.  I had a seafood dish (forgot the name) and my husband had the Lomo Salteado and both were very good.  I will be coming back for more.
author: Mirna V.

description: I had the pleasure of living in Peru for two years. Lima always has a special place in y heart. I was the guest of a dear Peruvian friend today at this restaurant. It is humble and small. The service is incredible and the food is authentic Peruvian served in copious quantities. It is the real thing and wonderful. The staff is friendly.
author: Jack W.

description:
Everyone we've taken to this place has LOVED it.

Thanks for Florio for taking us here and getting us hooked.

The salsa/tomato hot sauce spread thing is delish.  So is the Chicharron Chicken, Lomo Saltado, and Garlic Prawns.  YUM.
author: Miss Bonnie B.

description:
It's a nice, local Peruvian joint. The service was good, food not-bad, ambiance traditional. But the food didn't cut it for me. The food was relatively "ok" compared to the other Peruvian BBQ joints that I've been to. I ordered the Lomo Saltado which was tasty, but lacked the flavor I was looking for. The rice and meat felt a little dry. The potatoes were overcooked in my opinion.

The food is also relatively expensive for what it is... Service was good, which is the only thing that really stood out for me. The server and waiter were both friendly and didn't give us "the look" when the restaurant was getting busy, and we'd been sitting at our table for 2 hours!

The workers were really nice, but the food was not up to par. I'd say it is an even 3.5, and though I wish I could give it 4 stars, the lomo saltado just didn't cut it for me. It may have been a bad experience, but unfortunately I won't be back for a second tasting.
author: Elly C.

description:
Craving tapas and after a not so stella experience at Alegria, I was determined to find the right place.  Almost didn't make it thinking we will never find a parking space or be able to squeeze in on a Friday BUT we were lucky on all fronts!  Got there around 6ish and there was a space almost right outside, we had our pick of the table and the time and attention of our waiter.  

We picked the corner booth near the window.  Everything on the menu was tempting so we had to seek some recommendations.  The dinner traffic picked up right before 7pm and the place was packed when we left. 

The bread was ok but the salsa was DELICIOUS!  I tried to eat it with everything and finally had a few spoonful by itself.  The pieces of jalapeno pepper added a nice kick to it.

What we had:

half liter of sangria - $12 - it was pretty good, a bit on the sweet side so the ice helped.  i actually liked the diced apple.

Anticuchos - beef heart - $8.95 - you get two skewer of 3-4 pieces per skewer and two thick slices of grilled potato.  there was this yellow spicy sauce served on a piece of leave.  the beef heart was very flavorful and tender.

chicharron al ajo/del pollo - $10.95/$9.95 - fried chicken topped with chopped garlic with a side of fresh lemon juice w/ spices.   we were able to almost customize this - with bone in dark meat.  tasty.

ceviche mixto - $15.95 - fish, calamari, mussel, shrimp served with potato, yam and fried corn.  It's a bit tart. The fried corn was fresh and still hot - yummy.  

arroz con mariscos - $15.95 - rice simmered in cilantro sauce mixed with clams, squid, mussels and prawns.  this was delicious!  full of flavor, again hubby enjoyed it even though he's not a fan of cilantro.  it has the nice hint of fragrance but not overpowering on your taste bud.  generous portion.

look forward to returning and trying other items.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This place is good; came here with a friend and we started off with a half liter of sangrias. 

For food, we tried the ceviche de mariscos and the garlic fried fish with fries! They served complimentary french bread with whipped butter and spicy salsa! I'm definitely coming back here again and try something different!
author: Mika D.

description:
I went here with my peruvian husband and my family because we wanted to introduce a family friend to peruvian food.  We had heard a lot of good things about this restaurant from word of mouth from an article in which is it mentioned, and maybe our expectations were a little high, but I could have made better peruvian food than what came out of that kitchen.  

Both my husband and I are really sad that people think this is what real peruvian food tastes like.  I'm not sure we would even qualify it as good food.  The food was too salty, had too much MSG, lacked flavor, the rice was stuck together and overcooked, the lomo was chewy, the anticuchos were chewy, the jalea over fried, the causa gummy, the french fries for the lomo were overcooked and dry. The fish ceviche was good, but was so over priced I would have thought we were eating at La Mar.  The oregano chicken was also good, but the rice with it was all stuck together, and calling it a half a grilled chicken leads you to believe something else is coming out on the plate.

The service was good, very attentive, too bad the food wasn't up to par.

We were greatly deceived by this restaurant and we will not be returning.  If you want to get real peruvian food, there are many better places to go in SF and East Bay.  Sorry, Mi lindo peru, our experience with the food was not very lindo.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: beware of pricing scam! yelp prices are not the same and the business does not want to change prices to what they charge in store. i ordered what should have been a $45 and when my wife went to pick it up in the store they charged her $60. i called them once she got home and they said they added $5 to each plate in restaurant and will not price match yelp pricing. what used to be a decent place to eat is now ridiculously overpriced. you can get better food at limon, and way better customer service. go to limon! i'm calling 7 on your side#
author: Rosa P.

description:
Mmmm, papa/yuca a la huancaina, shrimp stuffed avocado, arroz con pollo, lomo saltado....oh the list could go on.  I recently had the vegetales saltados, if veggies could be that tasty and filling EVERY time, I just might become a vegetarian.  Might. 

Everything is so savory and so flavorful.  The portions are huge and filling.  Mi Lindo Pero is a place that is consistently good.  The Peruvian beers are great too, there's the Cuzqueña and Cristal.     

I love the decor.  Some of the mounted items on the wall are just so lovely.  If it could fit in my purse, i might try to sneak it out.  No dice, they are huge gold plated inka-style decorations.  Maybe they'll sell them?

Service is great and friendly, and food is served promptly.  But beware while during the week a 7pm dinner has no wait, this is not so thurs-sunday.  Be prepared to wait during peak dining hours.  But please do wait, you'll love it!
author: Lesliegh H.

description:
Never a miss!

I've been going here for quite some time and it's really good food.  The portions are large, prices reasonable and the service is always friendly!  My favorite is the lomo saltado. Oh yeahhhh

It can be tough to find a parking spot but I've never missed yet.
author: John D.

description: Not great. Honestly, dont waste your time. There are too many great reataurants in this neighborhood to waste time at this place
author: Daniel Z.

description:
My coworker suggested this place a long time ago. So being the food junkie that I am, well I suggested this spot for a date night with my fiancee. Its a small hole in the wall, we probably drove a couple times because it wasn't too visible. EVERYONE was SO friendly (gotta love that), it was over all good experience from the beginning to end. The lomo saltado was fantastic and the spicy aiole sauce was perfecto! Try the sangria is pretty good too! 

Ive been bugging my fiancee to take me back so hopefully I will return soon!
author: Daisy R.

description:
It had been awhile since I had eaten at Mi Lindo Peru, so I suggested it to my boyfriend, and we had an amazing dinner. It really reminded me of why I missed eating here so much!

I normally just order a main dish from here, but tonight we decided to get some appetizers. We ordered the ceviche de pescado (red snapper with lime juice) and the cangrejo con alcachofas (baked artichoke hearts, crab, and cheese served with crackers). Both were amazing, but the ceviche definitely stood out for us. 

For main dishes I ordered the lomo saltado, which was as amazing and delicious as I remembered it, and my boyfriend ordered the arroz con pollo, which he loved and COMPLETELY devoured. I, of course, had to take home the leftovers ;) lomo is so good the next day!

There was just enough room for dessert, so we had the platanos fritos con helado (fried plantain with ice cream). SO yummy and just a perfect end to an amazingly delicious meal.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
honestly, i came here a while back like... close to a year ago, and completely forgot what i even ordered. but i remember it was freaking delicious. pretty sure it was a chicken dish that came with some aji sauces. also thinking we probably got some sangria for no other reason than I am the sangria queen. 

but the best part about this place was the service. i went with three others, and we stayed a while probably close to two hours. we were just having a good time laughing and drinking that we didn't realize it was already almost time for the restaurant to close! the owner/manager? saw we were enjoying ourselves and instead of shoo-ing us out, made us feel even more at home and even joined in on the party. he gave us another pitcher of sangria on the house (we got tipsy lol) and volunteered to take some pics of us (I remember, it was a friends going away dinner). i just thought his spirit was awesome. 

so recap. good food. good vibes. good sangria. good times indeed. 

i love me my peruvian food, so will be back!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
What's not to love about this place?  From the mis-matched garage sale furniture, to the unpretentious Outer- (Mid-?) Mission clientele, to the delicious $9-14 entrees which comfortably feed two regular appetites, to the menu that has more seafood dishes than all others combined, Mi Lindo does Peru proud.

One caveat (mentioned elsewhere here, but unheeded by me on my first visit): if you're planning on walking up the street to Roccapulco to do a little dancing after dinner, you may want to stay clear of the otherwise wonderful Sudado de Mariscos (seafood soup); the smell and taste of this one stay with you for awhile...
author: Zain K.

description: Damn. I effing love this place. My mouth is literally watering as I write this review. Food is excellent and service is good too.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Everything was delicious!  I love sharing family style with good friends.  Since we were celebrating a special get together, we brought a nice bottle of wine, surprisingly only $10 corkage fee.  I really love the quaint decor and friendly, attractive service.  I don't know if they are siblings, but they all have a unique international flavor.  If the mission street parking overwhelms you, you can pay $12 to park in the BOA lot, which is literally next door.   

Must try:

Chicharron de pollo - fried chicken wings
Ceviche Mariscos (Mixte)
Ayacucho - beef skewer
Arroz con Pollo - chicken paella
Lomo Saltado - saute beef w fries
Plantains with ice cream

One of my current crushes, and will definitely be back every chance I get.
author: HY L.

description: Tough call...  The only thing that might knock this down to a 4-star rating is the interior decor.  It's a little cheap looking.  But then again, the food is very reasonably priced as well.  And it's REALLY GOOD!  Service is very good, reasonably fast and helpful.
author: R G.

description:
I haven't been here in ages. Carlos, the owner, is a friend of mine as well, so I would like to disclose that tidbit before I write this review.

I came here tonight for Daniel L and Marti L's UYE party. Catering to roughly 30 ppl is not an easy task for both the host/hostess and the restaurant but the event went smoothly, the company was great, met a lot of people, and the food was fantastic. 

Usually when you get a bunch of people and order family style, you really can't get the essence of the food. The food is a lot better when the party is more intimate. You can then really appreciate the intense ingredients that is used in their dishes.

Notable items:

Believe it or not, the bread and salsa is one of their highlights. 

On weekdays they use this regular bread but on weekends they have this fresh baguette that is awesome with butter and their fresh home made salsa. The salsa is a creeper. It doesn't taste spicy in the beginning but once you get onto your third and fourth bites, it will hit you. I usually pass on bread because it is a filler, but I just can resist it here.

Arroz con pollo..............my favorite.  It looks and taste like a paella with chicken and pesto sauce.  Very fresh, vibrant and a rather light taste to a very heavy dish.

Fried fish with garlic........not on the menu but Carlos will hook it up.  Best descirbed by susan and philip........everything taste good when it is fried.  This dish however is very intensely infused with fried garlic.  The garlic is very strong and you will be smelling for a while.

Lomo saltado...........beef strips with french fries and rice. I know......sounds a little weird but it was great 

Fried Chicken......love the fresh lime juice and pepper that it comes with 

Paella...............Awesome 

You really can't go wrong with any of the dishes here. 

Again. Great job Marti and Daniel for setting this up and thank you again for the dessert.  That was a great touch at the end of the night to give us gift cards to Mitchell's.  Mitchell's the ice cream parlor and not Mitchell's the one on Polk and O'farrell.  Although that would have been a better way to end the night.
author: jason g.

description:
UYE at Mi Lindo Peru last night! Fabulous event hosted by Daniel L and Marti L (Thank you guys!). 

I hadn't ventured on Peruvian cuisine before, to many of my friends' surprise. Maybe we Brazilians look at our neighbors fare with snotty eyes. Or maybe there are so many similarities  between us that I never felt a need to eat exclusive Peruvian food. But last night I had a great opportunity to fall in love with it!

Although the place was relatively small, the 30+ party was comfortably accommodated. The service was very friendly, attentive and fast. Now to the food: the arroz con pollo was great, with rich cilantro flavor. Amazing fried snapper covered with fried minced garlic. Lomo saltado: beef strips with French fries, rice and a lot of onions. Fried chicken with lemon flavor. A very rich paella. And, of course, delish  fried plantains for the final kick! For such an affordable price, it was definitely a great treat!

I got  a great introduction to Peruvian cuisine, met some of my already Yelp friends, made more friends and had a fabulous time! Fabulous way to kick off the Spring! :-)
author: Simone W.

description:
I don't give out 5 stars very often.  In fact it's pretty rare but this place was definitely deserving of praise and affection.  

Marti L and Daniel L - Awesome job hosting a successful UYE!  
**Golf clap**

Cool peeps, great food, and a gift card at Mitchell's?!  WOW!  All for under $13?!  Amazing!!!

The food was VERY VERY good.  Not sure what was ordered exactly but I definitely enjoyed all the interesting dishes being passed around.  And the service.....  They were super friendly and very accomodating.  We obviously took over the restaurant with our large party but the service was still intimate and top notch.  Kudos!
author: Danny L.

description:
Hi there! My name is Dug! My master made this collar, so that I may talk! Squirrel!!! That was my first impression of Peruvian food. Squirrels and guinea pigs. LOL! 

All that we had was just chicken and some seafood. I think at least? My first experience with Peruvian food was awesome! I guess that you can say that I popped my Peruvian food cherry last night. We had some ceviche which I had a small bite of was pretty good! Fried plantains. Need I say more? I guess I will! Chicken with potatos and corn rice, beef made the same way, fried chicken, cilantro rice, paella and fried snapper with garlic which were all delish!

I have to commend the service of one gentleman serving the massive group of 30 people organized by the lovely Marti L and awesome Daniel L! It was preobably some of the best service that I have ever experienced considering the task that he had. Great meeting new Yelp folks as well as the familiar faces! You are one crazy and fun group of people!

I will definitely have to come back for my squirrel... Um I mean Peruvian fix!
author: Darryl P.

description:
30 awesome Yelpers + really good Peruvian food = good food with good company!!! 

This was my second time experiencing Peruvian food and it won't be my last! The food was simply amazing: The two things that stood out for me was the Fried Garlic fish which was delicious and the Paella which was amazing.  This place is limited in space and last nite is was even more limited since 30 Yelpers took over this place! Carlos ,the owner, was awesome, he kept the food coming and made sure we were well taken care of. I was so anxious and excited to meet Yelp friends i talk to on a regular basis as well as all the new Yelp friends i made last nite. This was my first UYE and its thanks to Marti for inviting me!! ^^ 

I will definitively be back to check out more of the dishes

Thanks for putting together an awesome UYE Marti L and Daniel L.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Vegetarian dish was mediocre -- very oily, no protein to speak of. Friend's dishes with the squid looked quite good, but I wasn't in the mood for meat. 

Sure, maybe having a vegetarian dish that was a bit more "well rounded" (e.g., including egg or tofu) would not be very Peruvian, but it certainly would not hurt to have a better veg. option, for a restaurant in SF.

Also, service was definitely on the slow side, even though restaurant was 2/3 full.
author: sean m.

description:
Adorable restaurant with great attentive service. It's on the small side, so be sure to make reservations. For some reason it was so HOT inside! I guess they have little or no ventilation...so dress accordingly. 

Sangria was not bad if you do not enjoy the taste of alcohol. Most of us ordered what they're well known for: french fries with either beef or chicken. I opted for the chicken...which turned out to be a bit dry to my disappointment. However, the french fries and sauce were amazing! Portions are pretty big, so even though I picked over most of the chicken I still ended up stuffed to the brim. My friends ordered their fried rice with chicken, which turned out to be amazing! So simple but so delicious! 

Prices are extremely reasonable for the portion sizes. I will definitely return to try some of their appetizers and other entrees!
author: Vivian D.

description:
I've never had fries with rice before. This place is great. The entrees are huge! I don't know how them three White folks who sat behind me were able to finish their entrees so fast. I had to share an entree with my mom and we struggled whereas they completely wiped out their plates. Wait, I'm reviewing the restaurant, not White folks. J/k! The staff (just one waiter) was friendly and the prices are fairly cheap considering the portions. The ayacucho (kabob) was good, but I prefer the Thai kind.

I had the saltado de pollo (as suggested by other Yelpers and the SFBG review) - This won't disappoint. JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: It must be said that the service was great here.  However, the food was less than memorable.  We brought the parents here when they mentioned they wanted Peruvian food somewhere close to our place in Glen Park.  After a quick Yelp search, we found that this place fit the bill. Unfortunately, none of us were raving about our dishes.  Next time, I'll stick with what I like, which is Limon in the Mission.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Peruvian or not, the food here tastes like it came right out of your own kitchen. It's comforting and its something I like going back to every now and then. And the dish that you should come for is the Lomo Saltado. And if you like the spicy kick in the butt, ask for their spicy Aji sauce.
author: Vien T.

description:
I haven't reviewed this yet? Weird. I've spent a birthday here, many dinners over the years, the food is excellent and reasonable. I also love chicha morada and the family running it is lovely.

They lost a star because after so many visits, I had to walk out last week because we were seated, then told to move to another table because someone mistakenly sat us at table for four - and then said it was a reserved table. Which wouldn't be so bad but we waited for 45 minutes for a table when we were told it'd be 15. 

But I'll be back. If they aren't too crowded and I can sit pretty quickly. I guess its now so popular you have to make reservations.
author: Cheryl D.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru always has good food and friendly service at a reasonable price. MLP is one of three Peruvian restaurants in Bernal Heights and all are worth trying and all a little different. In my opinion MLP is the most traditional Peruvian restaurant of the 3. 

I have had many items on the menu and everything has been very good. I usually order some type of Saltado. How can you go wrong with both rice and fries with your meal? I always order the chicha morada, a sweet drink made from Peruvian blue corn - very good and also traditional. 

Bernal Heights has so many very good inexpensive places to eat, I'm a lucky girl.
author: Yvette K.

description: Surprisingly, I did like it... Went for another popular Peruvian  restaurant but they weren't opened... Glad I found this little place, a lil hole in the wall with good food. Eat arroz con mariscos and arroz con pollo both delish. The Ceviche's fish was super fresh but they could improve the recipe...  Good sauces and good Chicha Morada.
author: Cathy N.

description:
Wow, their lomo saltado, sangria and service here are amazing!!! 

One bite and i'm a huge fan!!! The sangria is also really yummy! 
Service here is also great.  The waiter was attentive and made sure we were enjoying ourselves. Overall, had a great time here. can't wait to come back!
author: AhLin C.

description:
Finally made it to Mi Lindo Peru after wanting to try it foreva-eva.

We had no idea what to get so we asked the waitress for suggestions and ended up with:

-shrimp with garlic sauce for an appetizer which was SO DAMN GOOD I wanted to lick the plate clean and pour garlic down my throat. Needless to say I kept it classy and just mopped up the garlic sauce with bread and mixed it with the entrees. I could've ordered 2, 3, or 4 plates for myself. Each order came with 6 pcs. The complimentary bread came with butta and a deliciously spicy salsa. It wasn't served warm but was soft and dense.

-chicken in green chile sauce with boiled potato and hard boiled egg with rice which was supposed to be spicy but not in the least.

-paella with calamari, shrimp, mussels, and clams.

Portions were huge!! One entree is big enough to share between two ppl. I feel like I stuffed my face and we still had leftovers. This was definite comfort food and although the entrees seemed a little pricey, they made up with it in portion and soul-satisfying-stick-to-your-ribs goodness. I would still put this on my list of CHEAP EATS. Everything seems authentic and service was warm and welcoming, attentive but not intrusive. 

I wanna go back to try the lomo saltado and arroz con pollo as we were eye-fcking other tables and their dishes.
author: Angela W.

description: OH MY GOODNESS! I have NEVER had such wonderfully flavorful lomo saltado! I also had a seafood soup, but the lomo definitely was the best. I like the size of this place as well, not too big but not too small. And the waitresses are really friendly. Glad my boyfriend and I stopped here on the random.
author: Renay D.

description: Excellent food, reasonable prices, great service! This place is a gem- we'll definitely be coming back.
author: Jim P.

description:
Bomb.  Seriously Bomb.  I feel like I could order anything and its gonna be good. 

Chicken Chicharons - shit i dont know how to spell it, but its bomb.
Lomo Saltado - Bomb baby bomb baby
Pollo con arroz - very good
Seafood Paella - yes please ok more please
author: Sage S.

description:
I wish I weren't as drunk as I was when I came here for dinner.  I also wish I didn't eat as much as I did because by 10:30 when the rest of hip SF was starting their nightlife, I was ready to Al Bundy it (hand into waistline and pass out on the couch).  I recalled that for part of the night during dinner, I kept thinking to myself - I definitely want to write a Yelp review about this, but I can't remember anything ... hmmm, more meat ... hmmm more ceviche.  I went with a Peruvian that I trusted to order all the food.  

I really enjoyed the ceviche (she claims that she asked the kitchen to do half shellfish ceviche and half fish ceviche - it was really delicious!)  The calamari was also great, but the dipping sauce seemed a bit mild or watered down.  That's about all I can remember.
author: Kathleen W.

description: Arrived near closing time, but they took us in anyway. The food was above average and the portions were filling.
author: marco t.

description:
My first taste of Peruvian Food was at this wonderful restaurant and now I find myself craving the Lomo Saltado everyday. Could it be Love at first taste, could I be obsessed, hmmm. I think it is just the wonderful flavors that just mesh well together that have my taste buds going crazy for more. 

A friend of mine who is from Peru, wanted to try food from his country and since I am always up for something new, how could I say no to that. :) I was very impressed with the appearance of this place. Its like you step into a whole other world, Mission is a little ghetto and this place is far from it! The inside is very updated and the service is great! My friend suggested I try the Lomo Saltado since it is a very common dish. It is thinly sliced steak sauteed with onions, tomatoes, and french fries. Yup, French Fries who ever though of that was a genius! It also came with a side of rice which looked like plain white but actually had a delicious flavor to it. 

I am actually making plans to head over there soon, I can't wait. :)
author: Norma Denisse S.

description: Love this place! Been coming here for years and I don't even live in SF.  The staff is very friendly and has great customer service.  The Chicharron de pollo is always cooked perfectly and the sauce it comes with is sooo yummy.  Other dishes you can't go wrong with are the Lomo Saltado, Papa a la Huancaina, and Ceviche de Mariscos.  Their bread is good too.  The restaurant itself isn't huge and it's popular so you may need to wait.  It's a nice place to have a casual gathering with a small group of friends.  I've been here also for a family celebration with kids and even though we were a larger group, the staff was just as nice.  Sometimes parking can be a challenge so be prepared to walk a few blocks.
author: MARJORIE S.

description:
Delicious! 
Started off with the Sangria - very good and had me a happy camper after only one glass...and I am not a lightweight. Only wish they sliced the apples a little bigger and if they added different fruits it would be a plus. 
We ordered everything to share and our 3 dishes were more than enough to feed the two of us: *Fried casava sticks with the cheese sauce. They were light and crispy. The cheese sauce had a great taste to it, not overpowering cheesy-like. 
*Ceviche de marsicos. YAY! It was so delicious! Everything tasted so fresh: red snapper, shrimp, prawns, mussels, red onions...all served with yams and yucca and the citrus sauce to die for. Very tangy, but I love that. I was putting that sauce on top of everything, it was so good.
*Lomo Saltado - Oh my lord. The marinated meat/steak was so flavorful. The combo papas fritas and rice can't be beat. We were too full to have dessert. 

Having visited Peru, I thought the food here was very comparable to what I ate in the country. Only thing missing was the high altitude tea :) 

All in all, wonderful. I had no issues with parking. The place was small and full, but by no means crowded and we did not have to wait at 7pm on a Thursday. Our bill came out to $52 (before tip) and that was including the Sangria. Not bad...and we even had leftover Saltado for next day's lunch. I will be back!
author: Karen B.

description:
I was a little hesitant at first.  

This block of Mission has quite a few restaurants and almost anything sounded better than Peruvian food.  What is Peruvian food?  I had no idea....

But i am glad my wife talked me into it!  We ordered quite a few dishes...too many to list but they were all great.  The salsa was the stand out of the night.  Amazing spice but so flavorful and fresh.  We ate every scrap of food but i couldn't let it end.  I asked for a cup of salsa to take home!  It's that good!
author: Reggie A.

description:
THe hubby had to work on Satuday from 8am-5pm, so when he got home, I fixed him a small dish of avocado and fresh chips. My baby was so tired. I wanted to give him a special dinner. So we sat in our home in san jose where I rubbed his feet and gave him a fresh iced tea. 

Then I thought of a great plan. I told the hubby to get in my car, and I made the 1 hour trek to San Francisco to the unknown.

As we arrived, I thought of my husband love for latin and spanish cuisine, and naturally i thought of Mi Lindo Peru.

My hubby has parking karma so I parked very carefully in a spot in front of a cafe in Bernal Heights and we made our way to Mi Lindo.

There was alot of people there, but we found a spot by the door. My hubby wanted me to order, so we both started off with the Inka Kola - Closely resembling a bottled strawberry soda. And he had the iced tea.

Fresh bread, their fabulous chunky red salsa and butter were served upon seating. 

I knew my hubby was famished since I fixed him a light lunch when he came home for lunch.

So I ordered 
1)  fried chicken appetizer with lemon juice
2) Gambas al ajillo - Garlic butter grilled shrimp
3) Sopa Criolla - Creamy beef and light tomatoey soup
4) Arroz Con pollo for me
5) Zarzuela - Seafood stew for him with rice

The fried chicken is lightly dusted with bread crumbs and lightly fried. The chicken was on the bone but was tender and delicious.

The Shrimp was for my husband and was fabulous. He inhaled the small dish provided it was soo good.

The soup has a wonderful creamy flavor with subtle spanish flavors and tid bits of beef floating in the soup. 

The Zarzuela stew contained shrimp, mussels, calamir, clams, minced onions in a lovely saffron flavored and scented red broth. The flavors were mellow and well blended. It was served with white rice and corn.

The piece de resistance was my arroz on pollo. There were huge chunks of boneless dark and white meat chicken in a cilantro flavored rice frenzy with peas. It was well seasoned and so delicious. Slivers of red tender bell peppers melded deliciously with the rice. They gave such a huge portion that I had leftovers. 

The service was very attentive. My hubby's iced tea and our waters were constantly refilled. The service was efficient, friendly and the food was magnificent. We will be back. Trust me.
author: Charlene C.

description:
Tallarin Saltado de Carne and Lomo Saltado are my favs.  I prefer the Tallarin because I believe the lomo saltado at other peruvian spots are a tad bit tastier.  

I love that this restaurant embodies everything of a family owned, mom and pop shop.  I feel like I have my own Peruvian Auntie cooking me dinner every time I come here =).  

If you're looking for an ambiance that is more high end, I would suggest going to other Peruvian restaurants like La Mar or Limon.  However, if that just isn't your scene Mi Lindo will be perfect for a low key night on the town.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Char C. B.

description: My husband had been hankering for Peruvian food so we made the trek to Mi Lindo Peru. The parking was difficult to find on a busy weekend. The wait staff were extraordinary and they kept coming to check on me and the kids(had the baby twins and my daughter) when my husband was parking. The food itself was ok- we've had better. The paella was dry but it had a generous helping of seafood and there was a lot for one person. There was an appetizer that was good for my daughter since it had hotdogs and fries and she also enjoyed the fried plaintain . The restroom was clean but did not have a diaper-changing station. Ambience was good but  the tables were arranged a bit tight. Very friendly atmosphere.
author: Melanie G.

description:
I've been hearing alot about this place from my friends but for whatever reason, it wasn't on my radar. I finally got to eat there Tuesday night after work. Melanie decided to take me since the line outside So was a bit ridiculous. (We will go back there though.)
So as we approach Mi LIndo we hear quite a bit of a ruckus. Melanie tells me that there must be a party because it's usually a nice quiet spot to enjoy some good Peruvian grub. Lo and behold, there was a gathering of Yelp friends. it didn't really bother me because it added to the festiveness of the evening. 

Since I've never had Peruvian food before, Melanie recommended the "saltados", which are basically rice plates with your choice of either beef, chicken, seafood, or vegetables. I opted for a chicken saltado while Melanie had a vegetable one. I found it interesting that both Peruvian and Brazilian rice plates come with french fried potatoes along with your rice. We also had fried yucca as an appetizer which came with a deliciously creamy dipping sauce. Once again, deep fried yucca is served at Brazilian joints but instead they're called mandioca (which is portuguese, I assume, for yucca).

I was very satisfied with my meal. Unfortunately, we didn't have anymore room for dessert which Melanie said was very gooooooood. It's all good because it's all the more reason to come back.
author: Ivan F.

description:
Our friends took us there, I was still on recovery from a cold, I was thrilled they had so many different kinds of seafood which exactly I wanted. I ordered seafood soup with cilantro sauce, it was so good. There have numbers of different kinds of soup as well. Their food is more simple than Fresca or Limon, lots of individual items.
4 of us ordered different items, each has different flavor and they were all good. I would go back there and try number of different things.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Damn good after you had a few drinks at the Knockout. I have been to Peru and can definitely say that the food tasted "authentic" - except for the lack of Aji de Gallina (sp?) on the menu.  What's up with that?

You don't go there for the decor - it is clean, but trendy it is not.  The empanada is great - really flaky and moist crust and yummy beef inside.  We also ordered a side of plantanos which was good - but not as good as my mommy makes (sigh - can a west indian girl get some good plantains, already?!?).

I had the Lomo Saltado which was excellent and much better ( and cheaper) than those at Limon and Fresca.  Tasted my friend's arroz con pollo and it was a bit bland.  

Portions are huge so expect to take home a doggie bag.
author: Kamael S.

description:
My first time in this restaurant was not a good experience ( four years ago), but I tried to give them another chance and went back on August of this year and...
Lomo saltado : Just okay. 
Huancaína sauce : Terrible! I thought their main ingredient was juts water, no flavor at all, and fried yucas undercooked. 
Chicha morada drink : No flavor, no crispy apples on the top, nothing.
There are many other restaurants that have decent peruvian food.  I am peruvian and I feel bad that people can think the kind of food they sell in this restaurant is "peruvian food".
author: Nadia J.

description:
Went here recently and loved it.  The atmosphere is pretty simple and casual, but the food was great.  At 7pm on a Saturday night it wasn't so busy, but started to get busier an hour or so later...still not so busy that it's hard to get a table.

My friend and I started off with the Cassava (yuca) fries, which were so good that I wish the serving was a bit bigger.  For my entree, I had the Lomo a lo Pobre, which was a very generous serving of strips of steak, french fries, rice, and a fried plantain on top.  It was like main course and dessert all in one.  Lovely.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Finally made it out here after Diane P. and Jason G's glowing reviews.  Wondering how authentic the food would be compared to my trip to Peru.

Here to say it's quite yummy.  Lomo saltado, calamari, and empanada were very good.  Fried banana was OMG.  Paella was a bit bland, but I've only been to one place in SF that does it well.  Service was excellent and prices are pretty reasonable; no where near what we paid in Lima, but decent relative to Bay Area restos.  

Worth a try if you're craving Peruvian food in a casual and laid back atmosphere.
author: Jennifer H.

description: LOMO SALTADO with egg and the plantain.....friggin delicious!! free bread is a huuuge plus in my book. the only place i'll go to for peruvian
author: Alvin P.

description:
I'd been hearing about Peruvian cebiche in SF, but apparently this isn't the place. Yes, they have cebiche, and it's nearly acceptable, but no where near the quality, flavors, subtlety of a place like Segundo Muelle (Miraflores).  Rather, it was overly lemoned, overly onioned, overly priced. Maybe I should have sprung for the upscale and pricey La Mar Cebicheria Peruana?

As for Lomo Saltado, I never really care for it anyway--it always tastes flambéed (not in a good way. Burnt. Like tasting the fuel and not food). I succumbed to other reviewers and ordered it, but it wasn't so special. 

On the plus side, the people were nice and the chicha morada was a bit watered down (but in a good way!)
author: Rick S.

description:
Very authentic, and palatable Peruvian food. Okay service. 

The decor of this place was very nice, but the layout of the restaurant left us feeling a bit cramped. As for the food, divine. I had the classic 'Arroz Con Pollo' while others of us had more unique dishes. The reviews were unanimous, 'great authentic Peruvian food'. Red onions galore, amazingly seasoned rice and moist, delicious meats. 

As for the service, sub par. Surprisingly, from a restaurant with a family owned, authentic feel, our waiter was less than genial. The restaurant is lucky the food superseded his service. Solid Peruvian grub.
author: Jordan W.

description:
i love Peruvian food :) 
mi lindo Peru is so yummy !!
i knock one star off for parking, its pay parking everywhere you go in SF.
this peruvian restaurant is better than the one is san jose, 
the bread & salsa is so so good ! to start with spicy 
i got camarones lomo saltado & my boyfriend got the carne one. 
it was delicious ! it was good portions, didnt finish mine, inca cola :) 
i got 2 alfajores to go, 
service was great
bathroom clean. when i go back to SF, this is the place to eat hands down !
author: R F.

description: Very solid spot.  A nice change of pace on this end of Mission.  Personally didn't love the "french fries mixed into the food" thing, but probably just because I haven't had it before.  Attentive, fast service, really clean, comfortable space, would definitely return.
author: Todd G.

description: We went there with a group and tried a bit of everything. The food is good although not as much as to want to go again. Maybe is not my type of food. Service is good and the place is nice.
author: Beatriz L.

description:
I miss living in the city soo much and this restaurant is one of the reasons why :(

My fav is the Saltado De Pollo. I crave this everyday! I love the bread with the salsa it comes with. SOO BOMB! I really need to make it a point to come down here!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I haven't tried anything else on the menu lol cuz I can't get over my favorite item! Maybe 1 day ;)
author: Yo M.

description: We had the lomo de mariscos.  It was really did not have enough flavor.  It was missing many of the spices and special touches that a good lomo usually has.  We also had the papa rellenas... again I was a little disappointed.  The portion was a good size but it was really greasy and again lacked flavor.  Overall the service was good and very friendly.  Maybe I will try it again and eat something different.
author: Cecilia B.

description:
I have been going to Mi Lindo Peru for the past five years, and their service and food never disappoints!  The rice alone is worth coming for.  I tend to order the ensalada mixta, cancha, pollo oreganto, and the aji de gallina (the later two not anymore since I became vegetarian).

Their food is always hot and tasteful, and I have never found anything wrong with the dishes.  The restaurant is pretty simple, but well kept and clean.  The owners and servers are kind, and are pretty responsive to their patrons.

If you want some good South American food with reasonable prices and large portions... come to Mi Lindo Peru!
author: Anonymous U.

description: I have never tried Peruvian food until my friends brought us here. Its a cute family owned restaurant in SF. They have some delicious food and we always get the pescado frito (fried fish) and lomo saltado (stir fried beef with spices, vegetables and FRENCH FRIES. A weird combo, but not a disappointment to the palate.  They also serve some bread and homemade salsa while you wait for your food. Its as awesome as all the food they serve.
author: rae m.

description: Bomb.com everything here is good. I love the lomo saltado and bistek a la pobre. The sangria is on point too. Dinner for 2 is about $30-35 which is good considering their portion sizes are legit
author: Chris P.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru is legit.  Came here last Saturday for my birthday dinner with about $7 friends and all of us left satisfied with what we ordered.  I went with the lomo saltado and it was extremely well prepared.  I've had better flavored lomo saltado before, but the crispiness of the fries and searing of the beef was much better here.  

My table also started with the ceviche de mariscos, yucca, and empanada appetizers.  Make sure you order the yucca and empanada.  They are only about $6, but well worth every cent.  The yucca comes with a cheese sauce that we ended up dipping the free bread into.  Delicious.  Empanadas sell out, so if you end up doing a late dinner, you may be SOL.  

Parking is a MF'ing pain here!  We drove around for about 20 minutes without much luck before finally giving in to the $12 lot next to the restaurant.  SMH.  Ridiculous.  Carpool if you can, I know that I will on my next visit here.
author: JP T.

description: Actually ate here a few months ago. Service really needed some work, the place was empty on a Sunday afternoon and they were still trying to rush us out. Lomo Saltado was pretty good, nice and salty. Only thing was that it had a slight taste of butane or something. My girls really enjoyed their cassava chips.
author: Soha L.

description:
peruvian food is just darn tasty and Mi Lindo Peru serves up huge portions to satisfy your craving.  The food is incredibly tasty and the staff is always friendly.  I can't ever get enough of their lomo saltado with their corn rice. Everyone that I have brought to this restaurant has become a fan.

My only criticism is that I don't think their beef is top quality, but it's still good. I've had better quality at other high-end Peruvian restaurants, but they charge twice the price for smaller portions, and i don't think the quality is twice as good.
author: Theresa N.

description: Eh, it was just okay. I've had WAY better peruvian. Plus it was FREEZING cold inside, not comfortable at all.
author: Anthony B.

description: This is my favorite Peruvian restaurant that is affordable. I have been here so many times and the food is delicious. It's not expensive and their Sangria is the best!
author: Minh H.

description: Love, love, love, this place. Ceviche good. Tallalin saltado yummy. Arroz con pollo OMG I would sell my sister to eat that all day long.  Ok, so I don't have a sister, but its still good stuff. Oh and their salsa will burn a hole in your tongue but its so yummy you just can't stop eating it. Guess I'm a masochist.
author: Kenson K.

description: Oh yeah, I'll definitely be taking my boyfriend here when he's in town in a few days! I went for dinner with a friend, and it was a very cool experience. Completely unpretentious, and though $13.95 isn't the cheapest entree in town; it was a steak. A really good steak. With a ton of flavor. And the Peruvian beer, Cusqueña, was a GREAT compliment to the meal! Loved every bite. Plate was quite clean.
author: Sean B.

description: You know gentrification is real when Latino restaurants have to take it easy on the spice to be more palatable for the White people moving in. I remember Mi Lindo Peru being one of the only places you can get an authentic Peruvian meal. Both the Papa La Huancaina and the Causa de Pollo have lost the rocotto spice they distinguishably had a couple years ago. Don't think I'll be coming here again.
author: Dessi C.

description:
Lots of fun.
Tapas menu means one can order many small plates and sample quite a few things.

Has a small "diner decor" feel to it.  The service was friendly and the food appeared freshly prepared and VERY delicious.  "Auntie" Chuchos was my favorite.  Beef heart was a first for me, and will be on the top of the list when I return.
author: Ken B.

description:
I don't really quite get all the raves for the place.

Well, mostly I was disappointed in the lomo saltado. It was just generally kind of bland, and the quality of the meat wasn't htat great.

The plantains, yucca fries, sangria, and service were all great though, so I can only complain so much.

Nonetheless, for delicious Peruvian food, I'd rather spend the extra few bucks and head up Valencia to Limon.
author: Mark A.

description:
YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS!!!!

Closest tasting food next to actually being in Peru.

Go weekdays for their generously priced lunch menu. I suggest trying the arroz con pollo. It's a heap of cilantro rice with gently pan fried chicken breast pieces. The ceviche is pretty good too, although there is no lunch price for that one. 

Plus they give you a delicious and unique style of aji to spread on your bread before the meal comes. 

Wait staff is super friendly. First time I went there I left my Blackberry on the table and walked out. I was about a block away when I heard some one yelling and running after me. It was the waiter!!! He handed me my phone with a smile. Too bad I gave all my cash for the tip otherwise I would have hooked him up. 

All around great place.
author: Mike B.

description: This is already one of my favorite restaurants in the Mission, even though I've only been a couple times. The chocolate cake is to-die-for! I've gone with a large group, and was able to try several of the dishes, even though it's not really family-style. Even the hard-to-please relatives were happy. Everything was divine!
author: J K.

description: The lomo sal tado is definitely not the best in the city. Mediocre at best. Great customer service though and overall good food. Just had my hopes set higher by all the positive reviews.
author: George G.

description:
I haven't had Peruvian food before, and Mi Lindo Peru gave off a really good first impression.

Food is deliciously well-prepared and the ambiance is great for dinner.  Not great for those watching budgets, however.  As for seating, do not plan on bringing a group larger than 4-6, as table configurations could get a little tricky.
author: Ray N.

description: The restaurant is small but warm and welcoming! Get the sangria! Very good! If your in the mood for meat.... Get the steak,prawns,rice and fried banana ! To ....DIE for!! Mmm mmm good!
author: Leah C.

description:
Since I started working 2 blocks away, I've probably averaged 3 lunches here a month for 2 years, usually with a few of the same coworkers. The food's amazing...the lomo saltado is the best (ask for a fried egg on top), the causa de pollo is delicious, the ensalada de pollo is a great light regular lunch thing, the hotdogs + french fries are deeelightful. Definitely put butter and salsa on the bread. 

And the service - I love them. Awesome people... My first Peruvian spot and still my favorite.
author: Liz C.

description:
Food is tasty.   The service is amazing.   Carlos (i think) took very good care of us.   Not sure how he did it since he appeared to be the only waiter working that night but he was efficient and friendly.

The pescado saltado was very good.   A definite must order.

I would highly recommend trying this place.
author: Aus B.

description: I love this restaurant. The food is SO good =) as is the service. My favorite is always the milanesa. It is my favorite dish to get at peruvian restaurants.
author: Geena L.

description: Pretty solid food here.  The portions are pretty big but it will cost you $20 for chinatown looking dishes.  The bread and salsa is weird but amazing.  I will definitely be back.  The loma saltado is grrreat.
author: Fatty A.

description:
We tried this place on a recommendation from a coworker, and we were not disappointed. 
The parking was fairly difficult, after driving around for 10 minutes we finally decided to park in the Bank of America parking lot and pay the $12 flat fee. 
We arrived at the restaurant at 8pm on a Saturday night, and were seated right away, the restaurant was full, but not completely packed. 
We had the ceviche which was soooo lemony and delicious, the plantains (soooo goood with the sour cream), the beef dish with the french fries, rice and egg, and steamed snapper (a little too much curry taste to it, but my husband liked it). 
We tried the cinnamon flan, and it was good, but not the best I've ever had.
The service was fast and friendly, and the atmosphere was nice and casual. 
Good authentic Peruvian food, not expensive like Limon or Fresca. Definitely recommend trying it!
author: HELEN K.

description: Love this spot. It's got great tapas, and pretty good service. I have been going to this location for years. I love how this spot fills me up and doesn't empty my wallet. They have great portion sizes in comparison to a couple of other Peruvian spots I've been to. Pretty convenient location to get to, since its right on Mission St. Only problem I found was the parking. I recommend these guys- give them a try.
author: Michelle V.

description:
the highlight was their buttery, fluffy rice in the lomo saltado. beef was overcooked in my opinion and lacked flavor. fries were soggy and the thing that saved the dish were the tomatoes. had the chicken version too in the past, but that was not memorable.

avoid the ceviche, lacked the tanginess of the lime, which means me think that it was prepared in advance and was just sitting in the fridge or something.
author: Ann B.

description:
This place is ok- nothing amazing. Definitely not the best Peruvian food I had, but not the worst either.
Food is a little too oily for my taste and the mango mouse pudding was utterly forgettable (then again, I'm not here for the desserts).
author: Blue C.

description:
So while wandering the streets on a Tuesday night hubby and I were looking for something to eat. We weren't quite sure what we were craving. As we were just about to give up hubby spots this place and says that he has been here before and they had really good food.  So in we went. 

It was about 8:30ish and the place wasn't full. There were only maybe 2 or 3 other couples. So being that I've never had Peruvian food before I had no idea what exactly to try. It took awhile browsing the menu and a couple questions before I could decide. 

I opted for the Arroz Con Pollo. Pretty darn good choice. Out came this huge plate full of rice. It was very flavorful. Buried underneath all this rice was the chicken. Chicken was decently moist and had a nice flavor to it. I could only eat a 1/4 of it because there was just so much.

Hubby got the lomo saltado which he loves. I had a bite of the meat and was surprised. Wasn't bad at all. 

We saw as an appetizer they had french fries and hot dogs. for giggles we had to get it. Okay pretty simple concept and it was amusing to see the plate come out. This would be something my 7 year old would enjoy.

They also had brought out french bread and they had this wonderful sauce to put on it. Wow I LOVED it. it was nice and spicy and delicious.

Service was impeccable. Both waiters were very attentive and friendly. Price wasn't bad especially for the amount we received. Overall very pleasurable dining experience.
author: Jenniffer T.

description: Very good customer service always give me good portions but kinda pricey, I recommend they warm the Bread you get.
author: Oliver N.

description: I have to say this Peruvian restaurant use to be good, the food is still ok but the service can be better. it took 45 minutes to get my dinner, at the time I got it I wasn't hungry anymore. They better do something  about this or they are going to lose a lot of customers.
author: Miguel P.

description:
After a bunk and somewhat pricy meal at La Mar, I was complaining to friends. They all mentioned this restaurant and said that the food is very authentic and very delicious. I had to try it. And I did! And I loved every single dish! 

I order the fried chicken in garlic sauce first. Sounds like a chinese dish right? Well it's not! It's really deliciously fried bits of chicken in a dry garlic sauce that has a TON OF GARLIC. It was SO AWESOME!! And for my main entree I had the lomo saltado and omg.. It was great! Flavorful and tender. Sooooo much better than the lomo saltado at La Mar and for 1/2 the price. 

I tried a bit of my friends dishes as well and everything was just really good. The portions are generous and the service is really great and the servers are really hot!
author: Jen D.

description:
This place is now going to be one of my go to places from now on.  Food is great!  Lomo Saltado is for sure one of the dishes you need to order when you first go there, also try the Arroz con Pollo and the epanada too!
I can go on, even try the paella.

Best of all, the portions are huge!.
author: Peter L.

description:
This place is hands-down, my favorite place in the city to go when I'm stark raving HUNGRY. I think the owners' kids tend table and are just so sweet, the food is amazing and comes in mammoth portions, and the sangria hits the spot every time. 
I've tried a good number of the dishes, but 90% of the time, I just get the Lomo Saltado and the Ensalada del Dia. Perfect. 
If you can put up with the cafeteria interior, you'll get far more Peruvian fare here than at the smaller chic joints like Fresca or Limon.
author: kt s.

description:
Most definitely delightful.  The sautéed beef with fries, onion, and tomato was delicious the first time i went there, but was noticeably blander the second time.  Both were tasty, so I say go for it.

The spanish paella was fantastic but a little bit homogenous in flavor, which was great, but just not as exciting as the beef dish.  Also, the calamari in the paella was fantastically tender and flavorful, which was great because I'm usually not too impressed with calamari that isn't deep fried.

All in all, the service was a treat, and the prices during lunch special are pretty reasonable.  4 Stars!  

WHOOP! THE'r IT ISSS!
author: Tim P.

description:
So great. Really wonderful, authentic food. 

We dropped in on Friday night; there was a wait so we grabbed a drink at the Knockout. When we returned our waiter, Carlos, had reserved our table. He was stellar the whole night. 

I'm sad that we didn't come here sooner--especially after we brought the Peruvian relatives to another establishment for crummy service and a price tag 3 times the size.
author: Laura B.

description:
Yum!  An inexpensive but tasty establishment.  I came in a little low energy and hypoglycemic, left with a spring in my step.

I had the Saltado de pollo, and was quite pleased.  Dinner was about $15 a person with tip and no drinks.
author: Ravi C.

description: One of my favorite peruvian restaurants...pricing is not bad and food is very tasty...highly recommend lomo saltado closest thing out in the bay to great peruvian food. I've been eating here for years and I've tried a lot of whats on their menu and I enjoy everything I've had  which ranges to their tallarines saltados, arroz con pollo, lomo saltado, aji de gallina.
author: Yvette I.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru is ok...I would not eat their ceviche at all, it lacks flavor and feels like you are chewing on rubber.

Their lomo saltado is pretty good, and is the main reason I didn't give it 2 stars. Sangria is pretty decent as well. Good for small groups, and is open until 10, and then they just turn off all the lights even if you are still eating. lol
author: Raquel G.

description:
Peruvian food has never really been on my radar, but when my friend told me that her brother in law owned Mi Lindo Peru, I was definitely interested in giving it a try. I really had no idea that Mi Lindo Peru was  getting rave reviews here on Yelp. 

For starters, we ordered the Empanada de Carne, which was really good, but the Chicharron Al Ajo was great. Chicken wings are marinated in garlic and then fried and tossed with more garlic and served with a garlicky dipping sauce. Yeah, it's a lot of garlic, but it's not as strong as you might expect and it was an absolutely delicious appetizer. We also ordered some fried plantains that were beautiful and brown and caramelized all over.

My entree was the Bistek a la Pobre, a top sirloin steak that's sauteed w/ onions and tomatoes and then topped with a fried plantain and a perfect fried egg on a bed of fragrant rice. My wife ordered the Pollo Oregano, a half chicken roasted in oregano and served with the same delicious rice. It was really good and we ended up using the leftovers in some fried rice we made the next day. Sooj ordered a bistek dish similar to mine sans plantain and fried egg, which she loved. This is comfort food at its finest. Their sangria is also excellent.

Mi Lindo Peru is a great place to eat and the prices are reasonable. It's a small neighborhood restaurant with a laidback vibe, and if I lived in San Francisco, i'd definitely go there more often. It's only about a 5 minute walk from the 24th Street BART station, so if I ever need a fix, at least I won't have to worry about parking.
author: Arnold G.

description:
A packed house around 7pm on a Friday night is usually a good sign - and it didn't fail me here! I have it on authority that this place is fairly authentic, and while I can't judge that, I can say that it is very delicious.

We had the ceviche de mariscos, a lovely mixture of seafood and acid, as our starter. We also had the empenada, which was filed with meat, raisins, and olives, and the tamal de pollo, which was a lot of masa to a very meager amount of chicken. However, it was thoroughly tasty. We also had the lomo saltado, which was quite delicious.

We also had the Sangria, which was quite delightful. The half liter seemed like an ample amount,  but it went down pretty quickly with the amount of food we had. The spiciness of it was just right, as well.

The staff is friendly, and helpful. I highly recommend coming here, but the caveat - be careful in at the two top nearest the door, If you are sitting faceing the winow, as I was, and there is a crowd of people waiting to be seated, like there was, you are liable to get butts on your shoulder, like I did.
author: neil c.

description:
It was time for another crazy food event with Arnold and Christel. This food event consisted of the following line-up:
1. Ferry Building
2. Mi Lindo Peru
3. Mission Pie

But having gained some extra pounds on Mom's cooking on my NY trip, I actually had to restrain myself during the Ferry Buildling portion of the event.  You have no idea how difficult this is to do around Arnold and Christel.  Here's a portion of our dialogue there:
Arnold [at Delica]: Wnat a roast beef sushi?
Me: No
Christel: Want some tofu?
Me: No
After Delica, Arnold: Do you want a Bombolini?
Me: No
Arnold: Should we go look at Reciutti?
Me: [Nothing, but thinking: why don't you just torture me instead]
Arnold: let's go look at Miette?
Me: [thinking: Actually, just kill me instead]

So, after FINALLY getting to Mi Lindo Peru, we scanned the menu for appetizers.  
Arnold: Let's get the empanada.
Arnold: Let's get this [pointing to something else].
Christel: Hey, hey, can the rest of us order?
Arnold: Sooj, didn't you want the ceviche?
Me: I want the empanada.
Arnold: I thought you wanted the ceviche?
Me: I've had to watch you guys eat for a whole hour.  I am starving.  Get me meat now.
