For appetizers, we ordered the very large empanada and Chicarron al Ajo, this wonderfully crispy chicken covered with the tastiest garlic bits.  I could have a meal of just the empanadas and that finger-licking delicious garlicky chicken...oh, you must get it.

For the main course, I was really tempted to get the Bistek a la pobre, a sirloin steak along with an egg and plaintains.  But we had Mission Pie lined up, and i was afraid of not having enough room for the pie.  So, Arnold nicely suggested that we order a plaintain sideorder, which was the real temptation for me, and I order a regular plate of Bistek that comes with rice.  The plaintains were hearty (I know, not the usual word for plaintain, but these were large slices) and the Bistek plenty filling without the egg.  Although one of these days, I will starve myself for a whole day so I can get the Bistek a la pobre.  And the sangria is a lovely accompaniment to it all.

And I must say it again: get that chicken!
author: Sooj O.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru ended up being the culprit of my "I'm so bloated I can barely breath & wobble home" syndrome. But, what a wonderful way to experience Peruvian food for the first time. A relaxing dinner out with some friends & quality eats really tops the evening off. 

The food, which was reminiscent of Spanish food was excellent! I ordered the Bisteck a lo Pobre: a Steak topped with an egg & onions served with rice, potatoes, and plantains. The portions are big & the combination of it all was very tasty! The plate was flavorful with all the right seasonings and my juicy steak was cooked to perfection. The cold sangria went well with the meal, although the small bits of fruit was a bit too mushy for me. They also serve bread with butter and salsa beforehand. 

Service was great, and the waiter was very nice & helpful. No complaints about it! He even offered dessert, which I sadly had to turn down because I overstuffed myself. 

The place is pretty clean, decent sized, and great for a date or dinner with a few friends. 

As for the bathroom, kinda creepy the window was open & across from umm possibly the kitchen window? And it sort of smelled like pee, but the fact board told me "It takes 50 muscles to swallow" Okay pee smell I guess I kind of forgive you... 

I woke up the next morning a bit more smarter knowing about the 50 muscles & how delicious the Bisteck a lo Pobre is. I will be back soon!
author: Catherine O.

description:
The Mission-Bernal is pretty well split between rising-star hipster hangouts (Front Porch, Blue Plate) and tiny family-run latin food joints (San Miguel, Pastores).  Can't decide?  Try Mi Lindo Peru, which seems to be straddling the two genres (or is on the way from the latter to the former).  It certainly has a family-run layout and menu, but the patrons look like spillover from Emmy's having a pre-Knockout dinner (or was that just us?).  The prices smack a bit of hipster tax, too (I was really tempted to dock a star for this, but I've finally realized that $15 is the new $10, and that I'm clearly on my way to becoming one of those old guys who like to mention what things cost 50 years ago). 

Unlike Fresca, which had its ups and downs, everything I tried here was great.  Both the sangria and chicha morada are must-drinks (you can get chicha morada to go at El Perol, by the way).  Fried yucca is the new french fries, especially with that amazing cream sauce.  And then there's the picante de mariscos, one of many delicious seafood-in-spicy-creamy-sauce-over-rice dishes to choose from.  There's also a decent selection of tapas if you want to go that way.
author: Wes M.

description:
Happy cows don't come from California, they come from South America. Turns out that living in grass-fed luxury in La Pampa is better than being pumped full of chemicals, who knew?

While in our fair continental neighbor to the south, given my tenuous grasp of Spanish, I looked for two main words on my dinner menus - "lomo" or "bistek." Now that I'm back at home, I still do the same thing because it hasn't failed me yet.

Sangria was a great start and a beef empanada to share as an appetizer was delicious: not your regular ol' beef in a pocket. The fella got lomo saltado (strips of beef with sauteed vegetables and french fries), and it was pretty damned good. My bistek with veggies and rice was better. I didn't get an alfajore, but they do have them here. Price wasn't bad, about $25 each, including tip.

It gets packed, but the place is so freakin' cute, you get over it pretty quickly.
author: Tara R.

description:
The Lomo Saltado had good flavor.  But slightly off, I'm pretty sure I taste coconut
 water in the rice and gravy of the dish.  It ended being a diuretic for me.  Sadly, I didnt keep the food in.  I must remember though not to ask them to remake the dish because I guess they got me good.  The first time the meat was overcooked.
Oh, well you live and learn.
author: Darlene F.

description:
OH MY GOD!

My first virginal bite.

Then three other Yelpers exclaim in unison, "Oh My God!"

Yeah, it's that good. 

I had been craving Emmy's for Spaghetti, but this was the best alternative and those Chicharrones de Pollo were like chicken crack, dipped in lemon sauce. Great food, great service, and a lot of moaning.
author: J A.

description:
12/12/06 PS- I went back here with the hubby and we ate lunch. Lets just say that I was not impressed with the entrees. I got the Saltado de pollo, which was basically a Asian-esk stir fry with french fries tossed in served over white rice. Not bad, but not great and lets face it just a bit strange. Josh got the arroz con pollo, which was a huge pile of bland cilantro fried rice. Overall it was a bit disappointing. I am leaving the stars as is because my first experience was so fabulous. I fully intend to return for tapas, apps, and of course the fried plantains. See below for the original review:

    My friend and  are both on a budget, you know with the holidays and all, and we wanted to get a quick bite to eat before running a secret holiday mission. We decided to try this place out and to our surprise it was not only great but affordable as well. The portions are huge so despite the mid-range prices, if you are willing to share with a friend it is a steal.

     The meal started with french bread and salsa. Unusual? Maybe. Tasty? Yes!!

    We had the mixed ceviche, which strangely enough is cheaper than the fish ceviche, followed by chicken stuffed mashed potatoes, and of  course a side of fried plantains. 

    The ceviche was amazing, some of the best and most interesting that I have ever had. It was served with a chunk of potato and sweet potato as well as a small pile of what seemed to be some form of homemade corn nuts. Yum!

    The mashed potato masterpiece can only be described as a chicken salad sandwich but instead of bread the chicken salad is placed between two completely smooth slabs of mashed potatoes and then topped with olives and a quarter of a hard cooked egg, which by the way didn't have a green ring. That in it's self is worth a star. I can't tell you how many high end, high priced places cannot hard cook an egg properly. This dish sounded so weird that we had to try it and it was well worth it. Although it was a bit strange it was more than a bit delicious.

    We topped our meal off with a side of fried plantains. How can you go wrong? They were delicious. We only ordered tapas plates, sides and apps because we were not super hungry, but I totally look forward to trying out the entrees, which sound equally unique to me since I am just starting to explore Peruvian food. 

I'll keep you all posted! All four people that read my totally awesome reviews. Shout out to you all, ya that's right I am a total dork, but a lovable one!!
author: Esa Y.

description:
I love the food! I dream of their lomo saltado...the lomo saltado here is like good sex; though you were quite OK without it, once you have it, you realize how much you were missing out and want to have it all the time!  

I've been here a few times in the last couple of months and although I'd love to try everything on the menu, I ended up ordering the same thing, and it  made me happy every time. I wish my stomach capacity were higher so I could try something else while I satisfy my lomo saltado cravings. It's nothing fancy but really good in a homely way. 

The service is friendly and efficient, the atomosphere very inviting and authentic, the pricing super reasonable....what more do you need from a restaurant? 

Well, their sangria is not the best, so I might try to see if they let me BYOB....
author: Nana N.

description:
Budget Peruvian food (in comparison to Limon, Fresca, etc.), but also at budget quality. Went here twice for dinner, and there will not be a third time.

Especially unappetizing was ceviche.  It was too salty and tasted weird (not to be confused with the excellent Weird Fish).

I must admit that the food was good when we went first time, so my question is -- what happened?   The restaurant was 100% empty when we walked in at 6:30pm too.
author: Mami T.

description: Love the sangria here and the food is delicious (big fan of their yucca's with the sauce and the seviche!). Could be a tad bit cheaper tho, thus 4 stars. But I keep coming back anyway :)
author: O K.

description:
Dude, this place is good! Blows Inka Grill outta the water. 

Of course, peruvian food is always pretty pricey. 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, and 1/2 liter of sangria = 80 bucks. 

The plates are huge though, so I think it's kind of reasonable.

But damn, that sangria was sooo worth it. Had me nice and buzzed for at least 2 quality hours. 

The food is very flavorful, very tasty, and the servers are extremely nice.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
if u never have had peruvian food? get ur a** to mi linda peru!!!
 ordered calamari, soltado de pollo, shrimp and garlic in a wine sauce, inca cola, and to top it off? some mango ice cream...ALL! i mean ALL! was soooo goood!!!
great portion size. u won't go home hungry, that is for sure. make mi linda peru ur first n best  experience for peruvian food...
author: Ray E.

description: This review is written 2 weeks after my visit to Mi Lindo so I don't really remember the names of the dishes we had, but one thing I do remember is that we couldn't stop eating! The food came out quickly and the service was great. We got the sangria, seviche, a rice and clam dish, a curry chicken type dish, and beef and onions. Again, sorry for the lack of names as I'm also not Peruvian, nor do I have a Peruvian friend. Everything was so delicious so try this place out if you haven't because it's definitely worth it.
author: Angelo T.

description:
The Lomo Saltado is delicious at Mi Lindo Peru!  It's not a fancy place, but the simplicity is more than made up for by their tasty food and reliable wait staff.  They have Lunch specials that are a great bargain! 

Try it, you'll like it!
author: Storm C.

description:
Very good food. the plain spaghetti that our friend's little kid ordered was the best plain spaghetti I have ever had!  The local fruit juice was spectacular, it was purple with a killer after taste.  I loved it.

I got a chicken salad which was delicious and my lady friend got the chicken with plantanes dish.  The rice was simple and the sauce was spectacular.  The service was ok but the food was simply delicious!
author: J H.

description:
I loved the food here! Our group tried several dishes but my favorites were the Arroz con polo, Saltado de beef, and some kind of spaghetti with beef and garlic. The food tasted great and left wonderful flavors in my mouth! Portions were also huge and prices were decent.

Service was also good. Our servers were friendly and definitely took care of our group.

The restaurant was also nice and relaxing. Good for quiet Peruvian meal!

I'm definitely looking forward to returning here!
author: Miss H K.

description:
-arroz con mariscos (seafood "fried rice," but way better than I'm making it sound with that description)
-tallarin de mariscos (seafood "spaghetti")
-anything saltado (lomo or pollo), which is a dish that has french fries mixed right in!
-mushrooms (find it under tapas, dip your bread in the garlicy goodness)
-sangria

Order any or all of the above.  Be warned that the portions are HUGE.  Even my 6'2" 200+ lb. hockey playing mass of a roommate can't finish one dish by himself. (Seriously, he's huge!) It's meant to be shared or taken home.  After a meal at Mi Lindo Peru, I feel like I'm also about the size of that roommate o mine, which is not good considering I'm only 5'4"...  Oh, well.  It's for the love of food.  At the end of my meal, I roll myself out the door. Good thing they have a big door.
author: jenn h.

description:
Came out for a birthday. Mid week so it wasn't too busy. They hosted a party of 12 and were really accomodating. Had the seafood soup and it wasn't bad at all. I think it was the right amount of shrimp and calamari served. BTW this was my first time trying Peruvian eats. Was I completely sold, No, but I am curious to go back for more. I should have chosen the all-time staple, steak, rice, and fries but instead I got the soup. The soup itself had the right balance of salt and spices, a little squeeze of lime gave that tartness I was looking for. Soup was a clear broth served hot, not warm, which made it even better.

I would go back to explore the menu more. I think it's the perfect spot to get to know Peruvian food. Keep it mind it's Peruvian and not a taqueria, different cuisine and the prices do run a few dollars more. That's why I think this place works because you could try the basic Peruvian eats here for alot less than the higher end spots.

Dinner for 2, about $40.
author: R O.

description:
Boo- Yah !!!!

Put any delish dish in yer mouth and chew. I bet its the best food you've had in weeks. Cough up a few extra pesos and explore the  seafood section.
author: Joe G.

description:
Can pretty much stay your lindo for all I'm concerned.  

The steak order recommended by the waitress was kind of dry and flavorless. The breaded garlic fried chicken recommended by the waitress was REALLY oily.  A couple of the pieces were deep-fried batter.  The garlic mushrooms were tasty.  

When they say something comes with garlic, it REALLY comes with garlic.  I love garlic, so it's all good for me.  May not be good for u.  

Service = the slow.  3 peeps working the night we were there, Kieu mentioned that the 3 could actually cut it but disappeared pretty often and totally off-queue.  Felt the frustration from neighboring tables, as well.  

Parking = the lose.

A tad overpriced.
author: Dong T.

description:
After 3.5 years of living three blocks from Mi Lindo Peru, we finally had dinner there. I had always heard nothing but great things, so my expectations were quite high. 

I was underwhelmed with the food. We ordered two shrimp appetizers that were mediocre. We definitely should have gone for the ceviche. I don't know what we were thinking. 

My arroz con mariscos was pretty good....lots of cilantro which is always a treat for me. Still, the flavors were a bit bland. Like my husband said, they make up for bland taste with huge portions. I could not believe my eyes when the waiter placed the enormous mound of food in front of me. I had enough food to feed a family of four. Since I was starving, I ate most of it, but wasn't "wowed." 

Part of the problem are my fond memories of a delicious Peruvian restaurant in Hartford, CT that I used to frequent. The flavors were so amazing. The food always had me raving and coming back for more. Who knew that Peruvian food in dumpy old Hartford would be superior to the famed Mi Lindo Peru? 

Three stars because the menu is huge and I have a feeling there are tastier options to choose from.
author: Abby W.

description: If you haven't tried Peruvian food, you need to! And if you have tried it, you need to come to Mi Lindo Peru! The food here is soooo legit! The portions are huge! The food is divine. The service was great and the prices are pretty standard. The Lomo Saltado here is orgasmic, make sure to ask for a fried egg on top, it just seals the deal. It's love at first bite. For those of you who dont know, lomo saltado is strips of steak in a nice brown sauce stir fried with french fries and served with rice. Also the arroz con pollo here is amazing, definitely not your typical arroz con pollo. It has huge chunks of chicken and a tastey green sauce throughout the rice. We also got the Pescado Al Ajo! This was also delish'. It's a fried fish served with a delightful garlic butter sauce on top. The plates here are about $15 each though, but it could easily feed two people for lunch and maybe one and a half for dinner. I just am in love with the food here. It's a must try for any bay area resident.
author: Kevin L.

description: Was looking for a more authentic Peruvian restaurant and stumbled upon this place. As my boyfriend and I walked in we were greeted right away. It didn't take long for the server to take our order. We ordered the stuffed potatoes, fried plantains, and pollo saltado, the food was amazing. The sangria was the best, better than cha cha I must add! I will most definitely be coming back.
author: Priscilla G.

description:
If I lived in San Francisco, I would definitely be a regular at Mi Lindo Peru.  I recently had a wonderful meal here with a friend.  Since it was my first time dining here, I wanted to sample of few dishes while I was there.  So, my friend and I decided to order a few appetizers and share an entree.  

For our appetizer choices we opted for the Anticuchos, Causa, and the Ceviche Mixto. Everything was quite tasty.  But my favorite appetizer was the Ceviche Mixto.  It's a little pricey at $14 but I think it's worth the price for the seafood you get and the quality of the dish.  It was fresh tasting and contained a lot of seafood.  The Causa reminded me of a deconstructed chicken potato salad.  Its a mixture of mayonnaise and chicken sandwiched between steamed potatoes cut into two rectangles.  It's topped with eggs and olives.  The Anticuchos are beef hearts flavored with spices and served on skewers.  

We decided to go with the Tallarin Saltado for our entree.  I've had Lomo Saltado before and love it.  So, I wanted to try something a little different.  This entree is basically Lomo Saltado but substitute spaghetti for the rice and fries.  It was good but I think I prefer Lomo Saltado.  The dish however was well seasoned and the beef pieces were cooked well.  For $8.95 (at lunch) the portions were quite huge.  

To end our wonderful Peruvian meal, we decided to get a scoop of lucuma ice cream for dessert.  I'd never had this flavor of ice cream before and I loved it.  I would describe it as orange in color with a nutty taste.  

The servers here were really nice and attentive.  And, willing to answer any questions we had about the menu.  I definitely would return here the next time I visit the Bay Area.
author: Rowena D.

description:
Was craving for some comida...the type that we all grew up with way south of the border....south of mexico that is.

Mi Lindo Peru came up on the radar screen.

Ceviche was solid....its slightly different. They use LARGE pieces of fish rather than the little cubes that my mom use to make. No complaints.

Arroz con pollo is definitely different than what im used to. I think they need to add more of the Salsa Inglesa to make it more authentic.

Also got the pescado al ajillo....the steamed one....solid all around. This is really good.

This is a casual place. Food in my opinion more substantive and authentic than its fancy counterparts - Limon and Fresca.
author: Edward T.

description:
I came here with high expectations.  On this night, I was really looking forward to Peruvian food because the last time I had it, it was in New York City and it was freakin good.  

Now this place was chosen because I had read a few "oh my god" lines from several reviews.  But I already had my doubts when I walked in on a Wednesday night and the place was not very full.  And after the dinner was over, I think my "oh my god" was related to "I can't believe I came here...It's not as good as everyone says it is."  That's putting it nicely.

We had calamaris, which were pretty regular.  But my friend ordered a steak, which had bananas and eggs mixed in.  For the most part, this dish was very watery and not very tasty--bland was more like it.  I think the dish was called "Churrasco a La Parrilla"--ny steak grilled w/ chimichurri.

I had the Lomo Saltado, lean strips of beef sauteed w/ onions, tomatoes & french fries.  It was not tasty either.

But the service was good and the people were very friendly!

So the exciting search for a good Peruvian restaurant in SF beings again...
author: Alan T.

description:
I had a really great dinner last night with a fun group.  There was no wait and the service was fine.

We had the white fish ceviche, lomo saltado, pollo saltado, marsicos saltado, steamed snapper with onion and cilantro and the seafood paella.  Obviously, we had a whole lot of saltado but that was fine.  

The ceviche was fantastic.  It was a huge piece of white fish perfectly marinated.  The snapper was well cooked and flavorful, not at all fishy.  All the saltados were also really good.  The beef and chicken were tender and well seasoned and even though I still find french fries with rice odd, I accepted and enjoyed it.  The paella felt light considering it was a rice dish and had a ton of seafood it in.  So good.

All this for about $20/person.  I couldn't complain about anything aside from the fact that we ordered too much food because we didn't come close to finishing.   I can live with that though.  I will definitely be back.
author: Seong P.

description:
Yay, unpretentious, tasty Peruvian food! The fish ceviche was just perfect, and my wife and I enjoyed their mushrooms with garlic and their saffron chicken as well. The service was friendly and very fast, and the portions were generous. You can even get a real Cusquena beer!

By the way, Pervuian food is a great bet for gluten-free folks (like my wife). All the dishes I mentioned seem to be safe). and there don't seem to be any surprise sources of gluten on the menu. Just avoid anything with the words "breaded" or "spaghetti", and there's still more than half the menu to choose from!
author: Dave M.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru is a no frills and friendly Peruvian/Spanish restaurant in outer Mission.. parking can be somewhat challenging, but if you're open to paying then cruise into the BofA lot and bring some $1's with you. 

Had a late lunch/early dinner at Mi Lindo Peru today and I'm already looking forward to my next visit! I ordered the arroz con pollo and chicha morada which were both as good as any I've had in Peru. 

I'm so curious about their Pescado a la Macho and Parihuela dishes, hopefully the next time I will be able to order them. Too bad they don't have 1/2 orders because the amount of food is SO MUCH, seriously... even for me!
author: Nenette Y.

description: Peruvian & Spanish Cuisine, had the Tapas Shrimp & Mushrooms, fresh Baked bread and a Negro Modello. Delicious, will be happy to return
author: Jim W H.

description:
Just Go Here

EVERTHING on the menu is good (I haven't actually had everything on the menu, but close)

garlic fried chicken and ceviche tapas
arroz con pollo, shrimp chowder and fried snapper
sangria
more sangria
carmel cookies and cream soda


Damn im hungry now
author: Scotty B.

description:
This restaurant serves the best food! I've been here plenty of times so I've tried a lot of the items on the menu. They rarely disappoint, but my fave is the spaghetti dishes. The Chi-Cha drink is GOOOOD. I don't know what the hell is in it, nor why it's purple, but it's oh-so-delicious! The bread with that spicy ass dip is yummy too! I've been tempted to ask for that dip, to go!

The wait staff is friendly and the prices are fair. The portions are huge so you totally get your money's worth. The Sangria is also good too!

All in all, fantastic restaurant and the owner, Carlos, is a great guy! 

Oh, parking can be a b*tch though...
author: Freckles H.

description:
Friday evening around 6:30pm. Considered going to Front Porch which is around the corner, but my BF wanted to go here and since the only peruvian I've eaten is from Fresca or his familia's casa I agreed to check this place out.

We walk in. Seat ourselves. And wait. And wait, with no water being given. We wait for 10-15 minutes, which is long when the place is NOT busy, and we wait before deciding to eat someplace where they will at least give us water. 

We chose the taqueria across the way down the block. Mi lindo Peru is not my kind of place.
author: Eclectic C.

description: This place is amazing! Not only is the food amazing but the service is amazing. The staff is super friendly and cheerful.  The price is reasonable too, I had lomo saltado- delicious!
author: The A.

description:
This place has a nice hole-in-the-wall atmosphere. You get in, sit down and relax. Everything here is delicious with a comforting home cooked feel. Everyone is friendly.

Pescado Al Ajo fills the void. Mmmmmm.
author: David D.

description:
Ok, I had to throw in my 2 cents for this place. 
I've been coming here forever - so long that I think I've met the whole family who runs the place - parents started it and then their children, brother and sister, have taken it over...but I digress.

If you eat meat: TRY THE ANTICUCHO... don't ask what it is (it's lean and delicious) then have the Ceviche, the Lomo Saltado and the Champiñones al mojo de ajo. Finish it with a Peruvian beer or wine or have some Inca Cola if you're on the Wagon. 
Yes, the place is not as fancy as Fresca, Limon, et al., but the food is good, plentyful and the service is good. Plus, no "Fusion" here as in the previously mentioned eateries. I ebven tried Inka's up the street and I always come back to this spot. I mean, I even love the french bread with that hella spicy salsa thing.
author: J H.

description:
i am a newborn chicha morado fan. actually, i love just about anything purple hahahaha. so refreshing, light, and sweet. 
another thing i'm a big fan of is the marisco paella. i crave it. 
i remember the very first time i had their seafood paella. even though i was still recovering from food poisoning, i slathered the aji sauce all over it and suffered. it was worth it.
and when i get it for lunch, i rub it in my other coworkers' faces. 
but when we go together, it's the best.
the employees are super nice too. 

the paella is a huge heaping amount. if you eat it at the restaurant, it comes out on a plate. it looks like a dinky amount but DO NOT BE FOOLED. you get a TON of paella! so generous. 

es muy delicioso~!!!
author: Susy C.

description: I'm possibly the pickiest person on the planet. I ALWAYS get the same thing to eat whenever I go somewhere for fear of trying anything new. If it has a funny name or looks funny, I'm not eating eat.(I'm still 3 years old btw)  So when Carina G. suggested we eat here I was a little worried. The place was packed when we got there but well worth the wait! The Sangria is sooooooo yummy! They put fresh fruit in your glass then pour the sangria over it, which was nice because no one likes mushy fruit. The chicken wings(with garlic on the side) are sooooo good! And I scarfed down my steak, french fries and rice before she was even half way down with her plate. Could it be because I'm a piggy or is it that really good? I'll let you decide.  I can't wait to bring my honey here. He's going to love it! Thank you Carina for bringing me here!
author: Angelina M.

description:
I have a problem with Peruvian food. Why you ask ?(Or not, I'm still gonna tell you!) It's that the first time I ever ordered Peruvian food, I ordered the Lomo Saltado. The problem? It's so freaking good, that I always order it and never try anything new.

However, I must have turned a new leaf because I ordered something just as delectable. I don't know what it is called but it had steak, a fried egg, and the best part: fried plantains (or platanuos as my cute friend says using her limited spanish!)

All I can say is GIMMIE SOME MORE! I hear the sangria is good, but so is the peruvian beer Cusquena. My taste buds are watering. You know what? I'm changing my rating from 4 stars to 5. Yeeeaaaah bitches
author: Molly W.

description: When it comes to Peruvian food, this place is the real deal, es chévere (cool, great, awesome). It really has that authentic feel to it and everything is delicious. The people that work here are so nice and the service is great. Wherever you go in SF, Peruvian food is expensive, here its decent. I would always take it to go for about $12, but was a big meal. You must try the inca kola, lomo saltado with their amazing bread, empanadas, and ceviche. I wish this place was not so far out, if not I'd want to eat their for lunch everyday!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
My first time trying Peruvian Food and I must say that I was impressed. Everything we ordered was very good with lots of garlic flavor. The Sangria was very good not like Cha Cha Cha's. 

I would definitely recommend this place and I will be going back for some more. The only bad thing is parking but everywhere in SF is bad.
author: Deb C.

description:
I've never had Peruvian food before, and to tell you the truth, we only went in because we were too lazy to walk up the block to another restaurant.... but man am I glad I'm a lazy ass! This place is fantastic!!

I had the steak with the rice and plantains.... MMMMM, who knew plantains and steak went to well together!?!? The 'Cristal' beer was great also. It wasn't the 'pour some Crisssttaaalll down some hoes' boobs while they grind their asses on my Hummer' kind of Cristal, but I'm definitely liking Peruvian beer.

Come here for the delicious food, the HUGE portions, drop like 20 bucks and its a guaranteed good time. Next time I'm trying the ceviche also. There will DEFINITELY be a next time.
author: Rocky K.

description: Meh. I've experienced better... exactly what I was thinking when I was eating it.  The servings are big with lots of rice, so if you are looking to get full, enjoy.  The chicken was very good, but the rest was just so so.  I won't be returning.
author: James B.

description: Great service, food, & ppl. Love the lomo saltaldo & beef hearts.
author: Johnson H.

description: The cerviche  mariscos was really really really good, very comparable to La Mar.  I thought Lomo Saltado was better at La Mar.  The Tallarin de Mariscos was fantastic - perfect "al dente-ness".  The best part is being able to support your local neighborhood restaurants.
author: Sequoia S.

description: My favorite Peruvian restaurant. The atmosphere is great, the waiters are friendly, and the food is superb. I usually have saltado de mariscos but I also love bistek a lo pobre. The tamales are excellent and the ceviche is also delicious. Parking is usually found on the side streets.
author: Carlos L.

description:
Really solid good food.  I can sometimes be a creature of habit when it comes to latin-ish food.  Mi Lindo Peru broke me out of my comfort zone...although I still get squeamish about chicken on bone.

Don't go expecting flash and a dog n pony show.  Very bare decor.

Take the 14 bus...just easier than dealing with almost non-existent parking.
author: Diego S.

description:
HUGE portions you may want to share. 

Lomo saltado is tasty. 

Their Bernal Heights location is kind of ghetto so if you want a nicer environment head for the Marina location.
author: A B.

description: I could just eat the bread and salsa from here and be happy. I worked in the neighborhood a long time ago and fell in love with the food here.  We'd come in for lunch specials almost every day. The Lomo Saltado and Paella are my favorites. My wife and I occasionally come for a meal when we are in town. The food is still excellent. You can get take-out too.
author: Larry T.

description:
First time eating Peruvian food and this place was delicious! Mi Lindo Peru is a relatively small place. I would guestimate about 10 tables. The service is excellent. The staff are super nice and let my group enjoy ourselves to chat long after they have cleared our table. 

My favorite on the menu is the fried Plantains. The ends are super crunchy and it did not taste like bananas at all. They have appetizers, soup & salads, Chicken, Beef, Tapas, and super delicious seafood. I absolutely love their homemade Sangria. It taste like a good mixture of red wine & juice. 

My friends and I had the following:

Paella Marinera - your traditional seafood Paella w/ saffron rice. It was pretty good but B44 does it better with the cast iron plates. 

Arroz con Mariscos - peru's own paella. It was just ok. Taste like seafood mixed with rice. Pretty much the same as the Paella Marinera and I think the Paella Marinera is a little more flavorful.

Pescado al Ajo - Red snapper topped with butter & garlic. When they said topped with garlic they weren't kidding. The fish was loaded with garlic! It was really good though.

Lomo Saltado & Bisteck a lo Pobre. Between the two get the Bisteck a lo Pobre. They are pretty much the same dish except the Bisteck comes with fried Plantain and fried egg. The Bisteck is SOOO GOOOD.  Another difference between the two dish is that the Lomo is lean strips of beef while the Bisteck is top sirloin steak. Both are sauteed the same way with tomatos, onion, and french fries. Yes the dishes are sauteed with french fries! It gives it a unique flavor and so fun to eat!

I would go back to Mi Lindo Peru just to eat the Bisteck a lo Pobre.

FYI - majority of the dishes come with rice. Beware when you share because it's A LOT of rice. Another thing they don't take reservations after 7pm.
author: Terry D.

description:
ahwwwwwwwwafhsff!  :sound effect for longings to return here:

sangria. sangria. sangria.

my girl Claudia took me here for my bday.

I am positive ANYTHING I'd order woulda made me drool-hard. 
Being a veggie, fish-eater... I was delightfully pleased with the under-the-sea selection: red snapper, ceviche, fried garlic fish... 

such rich, memorable flavor.. and plaintains! mm. haven't had since in Afrique so it felt so comforting.

Great for groups, long tables.. and feast-worthy food.
hard to go here just with no special reason, cuz its such celebratory like food.. lets come up with an excuse to party and go! who's b-day is next?!!
the night could easily be topped off with dive bar mission visits and dancin in the streets..
author: christina h.

description:
I went here this past Friday night with 4 friends. The sangria indeed, was good, a little too sweet for my taste but the itty bitty fruit was tasty.

We ordered a mixture of tapas and platos. The garlic shrimp was very good but dont order if on a date. The carne empanada was dry and not noteworthy. The lomo saltado, my standard at Peruvian spots, was just right and half the price than Limon, et.al...

This place has a "home-style" feel and is very very casual..it's good and the price is right.
author: Hilary H.

description: Downhome, decent Peruvian food and a friendly family like atmosphere. The decor is pretty much past this prime, so I wouldn't really recommend it if you want to impress somebody. The inside kind of looks like an Italian/pizza joint to which they added some Peruvian decor. The food is a little heavy, so I wouldn't recommend it if you are on a diet. The lomo saltado, for example, is a little bit oily but tasty nonetheless.The portions are generous and well cooked, nothing fancy, but at the same time the prices are better than other Peruvian or Peruvian fusion restaurants in the city.  One exception on the pricing; the ceviche is very expensive, and not as good as the ceviche at Limon, La Mar, or Fresca. Parking is a huge pain in the butt; you would think it would be easy in this part of town, but it's really difficult and there are no public lots in sight.
author: John S.

description:
This place is a Family owned business and therefore will always have mine.  The food is excellent with no "frills" or "tricks".

  The "Lomo" with beef is really my favorite and encourage you to try that.   There's also this noodle soup in red broth (name escapes me)  that's always worth it. The free bread is always fresh and the sauce for it is interesting because it has an almost "Korean" spice quality to it.  (Love it) 

 The Waitresses are awesome; friendly, always smiling, and constantly check on you.
author: Jubei K.

description:
This little Peruvian restaurant really grabbed my attention because simply how nice it was a change from your average everyday Mexican food places. Overall, the service here was really nice and the people were surprisingly friendly despite how busy and the rude groups of people who were coming in and out of the place. 
If you are in the area and want to try something new, stop by here.
author: Jon-o G.

description:
Where can you eat warm french bread, yummy rice and steaming potato chunks all in one meal??
Kicking salsa(?) served with bread and butter..
I usually enjoy the Pescado Saltado, Pescado Al Ajo ..or another fish dish I can't remember the name of.. tomatoes and onions cover it, though!
Their sangria was good; calamari too.
A friend ordered a battered steak once, and it covered the entire large oval plate!
Kiss your buttons good-bye with fried plantain to end your meal!

Sometimes there is a wait.. parking can be difficult (become a pedestrian!).. Staff very friendly.
I look forward to every visit~
author: Lorraine L.

description:
tuesday Dinner...for A visiting guest....seveN pm reservatIons and party of nEar thirty...over haLf earLy...another helping with coordination....dinner at Mi lindo peru...tAbles aRranged and seaTing exact...arrIvaL of others running smooth....water and menu placed....simple white sliced bread and sauce complimentary...majority of main dishes pre-ordered for efficiency....many new and some old faces...ready to feast....

starting with favorite...a dish served last....perfect golden fried snapper topped heavy with fried minced garlic...."garlic snapper" for simiplicity...quite heavenly....sampling of dishes for such large crowd....simple plated paella with subtle balanced mix of seafood flavors infused into rice excellent....would only improve if served on a hot iron skillet for rice crust....beef and fries with rice, lomo saltado....a lean tough cut of meat....slender strips mixed with fresh golden fries....chew of beef complimented by crunchy fried potatoes a good match of texture and flavor...a change with ceviche...smaller platter of seafood refreshing....not too sweet, not too tangy, ceviche just right....non-fried snapper served moist in light liquid saucing also great....healthier twist from fried....fork flake and non-dry....snapper being a dryer firmer flakier white fish...a friend offering a taste of chicha morada...bLack corn, cInnamon and pineapple drink sippinG...sweet And non-fruitY tAsTe....unable to describe flavors...just recommend an order!....above mentioned self top choices...

other dishes had and remembering....green pesto rice and chicken breast...breasts slightly overcooked....little bland for personal taste...small plate of plantains sweet, soft and decent....appetizer fried chicken overfried dark...zesty tangy lemon sauce for dip....plenty of sliced onions....compliments well...skip on sangria this night for driving....overall an amazing dinner and top peruvian dinners....an amazing dinner for under $thirteen per person finding unbelieveable....
author: Hen A.

description:
Hmm Hmmm Hmmmmmmm! 

I always look forward to my visits here.   Mi Lindo Peru serves the best Lomo Saltado I've ever tasted, coupled with their delicious homemade sangria and breaded yucca.  The arroz con pollo is also one of my favorite dishes.  

Aside from the food, I'd have to praise their service here.  The waiters are always friendly and helpful in recommending new dishes.  The pleasantries of their staff makes my dining experience even more delightful.
author: Cmaecia C.

description:
Good Peruvian food is hard to come by so if I want some, I go to Mi Lindo Peru.

I've tried the sopa a la criolla, saltado de pollo, lomo saltado, saltado de mariscos, pescado a lo macho and the pollo al jerez. I will only tell you to skip one item. . . the pollo al jerez. This plate looks like it would be awesome since it's chicken breast in a saffron and sherry wine sauce with potatoes, mushrooms and peas. . . but it's bland, has no flavor and I wouldn't recommend it.

Everything else is good! 
The soup is creamy and delicious with nice chunks of tender meat and noodles. Very comforting. 

The saltados are all good!
My favorite is the seafood just because I love seafood. Medley of prawns, mini shrimp, mussles, clams, and calamari with some fries and a tasty sauce served with rice mixed with some corn. The chicken and beef saltado have fries and the tasty sauce as well. They can be a little salty but the rice compensates for it. 

The bread and butter are ok but what makes it addicting is the salsa they put with it. I want a jar for personal use as I'm sure I would put it on everything. The sauce had chunks of onion, cilantro and other stuff in a spicy red sauce. I take the bread, butter it up and put a spoonful of the salsa. It's awesome and I would have it everyday if I could. 

Don't forget to start with some Inka Kola (taste like melted gum) or some chica morada (purple corn drink). 

The plates are big enough for two or for lunch the next day if you have light to moderate appetite. You can eat the whole plate but you will need a nap I'm sure. 

The staff is usually really good about explaining the menu if you've never had their food. They will give you recommendations and refill your water without asking. The bread you sometimes have to ask for though. But you don't want to fill up on bread, fill up on the food and ask for a togo box. Don't forget to ask for extra salsa and take that to go too. I do.
author: Margo G.

description: the fact that I am Peruvian and I know about Peruvian food, I was very dissappointed with this restaurant. I don't know if it was just a bad day but the food was awful. I ordered something simple like lomo saltado de meat was dry, fried plantains were burned and the rice had no taste.  I heard good reviews about this restaurant so I wonder that it was just a bad day
author: Marita R.

description:
I've never been to Peru, but this place strikes me as the real deal.

From the aromas emanating from the back, to the low-lighted decor, to the casual but friendly attitude of the servers, Mi Lindo takes me back to my days in Argentina last year, when steak and wine were staples.

Speaking of, I didn't try much more than steak and wine here. We ordered a half-liter of sangria (with ice, which doesn't bother me so much) and an empanada de carne for appetizer. The simplicity of the empanada really struck me, especially when I realized how delicious it was. Beef, black olives, and sauces and spices filled the pastry, and it was accompanied on the place by a simple mix of tomatoes, onions, and cilantro.

For the main, I ordered lomo saltado, which comes mixed with French fries. My god, South Americans know how to cook potatoes. Lomo is thin strips of beef, so the dish was visually appealing, too. The beef was a little tough, but not enough to discourage chewing. It tasted heavenly, and the alternation of bites ... well, writing about it next morning makes me want to eat it again, if that says anything.

Tara R., my dinner companion, ordered a bistek (the name escapes me at the moment), which is more of a steak-steak. Its taste blew the lomo away, and that's saying a lot. Just perfectly tenderized so that it really absorbs the spices and juices, and what a treat on the taste buds.

The prices are reasonable ($12 for most entrees), and, like many places in SF, the main drawback is the wait. That said, we got in on a Friday around 7:45 after about a 15-minute wait. Not bad.
author: Jeff H.

description:
We are always looking for new dining experiences and new cuisines to add to our lunch or dinner choices.  We had never had Peruvian food so we thought "why not."

We ordered the fried chicken appetizer and the Lomo Saltados.  The fried chicken appetizer was bland.  The breading had no flavor at all.  I didn't like the dipping sauce because it was too sour for me but the wife liked it.  I really did like the very spicy salsa they served with bread in the beginning of the meal so I doused the chicken with that, even so the chicken still need to have salt in the breading.  Unless that's the way that it is supposed to be made, but I think that all cuisines use salt right?

The Lomo Saltados was very well spiced and seasoned and would have been a winner but the skirt steak was over cooked.  Skirt steak is a very finicky cut of beef and in order for it to be tender it really needs to be cooked perfectly.  Unless you are using "USDA Prime" or it's equivalent, when dining in other countries, the margin for error with this cut is zero.  The skirt steak was at Mi Lindo was a little bit over cooked making it chewy.  

Prices were definitely on the high side as well.  For what you get it's not a value.  Skirt steak is one of the cheapest cuts of beef, rice, potatoes, and the occasional vegetable make up the Lomo Saltados and to charge 14.95 for the dish you really have to make it perfectly, or have amazing ambiance, or amazing service, or all three.  However that was not the case.  Even if I was in the area I wouldn't go back.

All in all we spent around 35 bucks for 2 beers fried chicken appetizer and a cheap beef entree with rice and potatoes.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
This place serves good food, decent prices, and as authentic as you can get here- as it is confirmed by my Peruvian co-worker who is from Lima. 

Anyhow, the portions are generous. We couldn't finish all 4 different dishes we ordered. But, let me tell you... I love the deep fried fish topped with fried garlic. OH so YUMMY!! I also enjoyed the beef heart.. its very tasty and its chewy, so if you don't like chewy food, I suggest not to order it. All the dishes are flavorful including Lomo Saltado and Pollo Saltado. They are so GOOD. The homemade sangria is very good also.. sweet, easy to drink... dangerous!  

All four dishes we got with the portions given and 1/2 liter of Sangria plus 4 glasses of Peruvian beers.. just about $100 with tax. Not bad. I'd go back!
author: Daisy S.

description:
I've never been to Peru but this place serves the best peruvian food I've had.  Generous, varied, and flavorful!  What else can you ask for?  I took my parents here and they loved it as well.

Everything was done well except the veggie paella, which we found on the bland/dry side...

Most definitely good enough to warrant "Go-To" status.
author: Calvin N.

description: Have been here a few times and have always enjoyed it.  I always seem order the same thing (Tallarin Sattado De Pollo) because it's something I've never had anywhere else.  The garlic mushroom appetizer is also pretty tasty!
author: Mike S.

description:
I just love it....
I really recommend this place for a new experience of flavors...
Try the 
Appetizer: Chicharron chicken
entree: Lomo Saltado
MMMMMmmmm...
enough said...
author: Florio M.

description:
Peruvian food is awesome and I love going out to eat Peruvian partly because me and my mr. went to Peru for our honeymoon a few years ago. Needless to say, I was very excited to finally go here after hearing great things.

We started with the ceviche with mixed seafood. And it was perfect. Not too sour, the squid was perfectly tender. Served with yams, potatoes and roasted kernels made it authentic.  Then we split the lomo saltado. The combo of fries, onions, steak, and rice is just too tasty. A bit greasy, but in a good way.  We also got a fried plantain appetizer to round out the meal. Service was friendly and timely. Mi Lindo Peru was everything I had hoped for and more and I can't wait to go back to try more stuff on the menu.
author: Nima K.

description:
My better half and I had dinner here for the1st time tonight and it was quite satisfying. I had deep fried snapper with fried potatoes, a side of beans and a side salad. This is not refined food but it's tasty, hearty and the portions are plentiful. For desert we had fried plantain (I was just in a fried food mood tonight - normally I'm a health nut) with Peruvian ice cream - it was delicious.

Bottom line - I will eat here again and in a city with so many good restaurants that statement in and of itself constitutes an above average recommendation.
author: Rex W.

description: Maybe I'm just biased by my love for Peruvian food, but this place is  home-cooked goodness! Love the Yucca a la Huancaina appetizer! mmm it was worth breaking out my lactaid for this dish.  They also make a solid Lomo Saltado and ceviche de pescado.  The flan with the notes of orange and cloves is a perfect way to finish up a dinner here :)
author: Nicole P.

description:
This place was great.  We got there at 7pm, and it was empty, so we got a good table.  Within minutes, every table was taken.

I had the steak, with the platano on top and  a fried egg (can we say YUMMY?  OMG!!!).  Anthony had the Loma Saltado, and Melissa had the Loma Saltado as well, but the  chicken version.  

Everything was seasoned so well, just the way I would do it at home....so flavorful.  I enjoyed every bite.  

I look forward to going back and picking a new dish to try.
author: Gretchen F.

description:
As a Peruvian i have very high standards, and this place is that good! Its a hole in the wall homey feel very peruvian like place!

All their dishes are delicious and the lomo saltado is probably my favorite! VIVA PERU!
author: Genevieve G.

description:
I went a few months ago with some friends and I think about this place.  I should have written a review back then but I still remember what was so yummy.  If parking were easier, I would have been back already.  

When I go back, I need to go with some more friends so we can order more and try more things.  Definitely need to get the Ceviche Mixto, Lomo Saltado and Aguadito De Mariscos among other things...  anyone in?
author: Michelle S.

description: If you are in the mood for great ceviche at a good value, this is the place. And their seafood rice dish is a can't miss.
author: anil b.

description:
I am Peruvian and I lived in SOCal for 12 years (i still do, I'm just here inSF for school).... And I can tell you that food is bad! The first time i ordered the Lomo Saltado which was just ok. My friend ordered Aguadito de Mariscos (seafood soup). Hers was awful!!!!! Uneatable! Seriously!!! It was not fresh and tasted bad as if the seafood had been sitting there for weeks. So I gave it a second chance and went back there with my bf. He ordered the lomo Saltado and he also thought it was just ok. I ordered Tallarin Saltado de Pollo ew! It tasted like vinegar and it was super salty ! Couldn't finish and I obviously didn't take the rest home. We also ordered papa a la huancaina that was bland. 
What a disappointment! Ive been in SF for a year and still can't find a decent Peruvian restaurant! Nothing like So Cal! :/
author: Anali V.

description:
Great Peruvian food.  The fish dishes are great and many to choose from.  I recently had the Peruvian fried rice, which was very tasty and a huge portion was served.  Very comfortable, homely environment.  Not too expensive either.

If you have never tried it before, I highly recommend trying the 'chicha morada'.  It is a non-alcoholic beverage made from purple corn.  It is sweet, refreshing and delicious.  Mi Lindo's chicha is quite authentic.
author: daniel g.

description: Terrific service and delicious food.  We ordered the Lomo Saltaldo, fried chicken with garlic sauce and fried red snapper with seafood.  Everything was so good!  Our waiter recommended the mango pudding for dessert.  Warning: mango pudding was huge.  Will definitely be coming back!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I like this place....it has the ability of being a real cornerstone of the mission area... I went there on a night out with a lady friend and we both had a good time...the food was good...not amazing..the flavors didn't pop how I would like but it was good enough..but the Sangria??...awesome!! I would go back...
author: Mr E.

description: With their unpretentious services and delicious food such as arroz con pollo (chicken, rice, & peas, sautéed in cilantro sauces), gambas Al Ajo (prawns sautéed in a garlic sauce. served with seasoned rice),sangria and chicha morada (purple corn drink), Mi Lindo Perú is fast becoming my favorite neighborhood restaurant.
author: May L.

description:
Worst ceviche I've had. I am sure the fish was old. Would not go back again. My friends and I didn't finish our dishes. Wonder why?

Sorry to the owners but I think they need to bring fresher ingredients to the plate.
author: Jackeline O.

description:
Latinos EVERYWHERE are not shy with color, and this Peruvian restaurant is no exception. Sitting down you are treated to a feast of color.   The restaurant is a matte rainbow of warm and bold colors.  The waitress is friendly and patient as you read the two and a half page menu.  Then brings your order hot and yummy in big colored plates.

They have plenty of seafood tapas and a few with the California staple, avocado.  The entrees are huge and will be enough for a huge appetite or to take home for lunch the next day.   I had fun eating here... seriously the food is fun, the whole place is fun.

Soo much food....and it's all goood. Mmm.....
author: Jay H.

description:
Yummy.  I can't for the life of me tell you what I ordered, or what anyone else ordered, but I know it was all good- delicious!  

Most of the plates here feature lots of rice, and french fries thrown into the mix.  For instance with the beef stir fry came fries mixed in, same with the stew, and seafood rice and everything else.  I think they think of it as potatos, but to me it looked like french fries.  Either way it tasted great.  

Order several dishes to share and come in a group so you can try several things, it's all so flavorful!!   Note: the meat wasn't the best quality, but for these prices, I don't mind a little bit tougher steak.  It was still well flavored and hit the spot.    

Decor was clean and simple but nothing trendy or alluring.  It's like going to someone's house for a home made dinner.  Service though was great!

Next time I'm going to study the menu and choose my orders carefully I want to try everything!!
author: Denise B.

description: Mi Lindo Peru is delicious. We came here for brunch and were starving. Fans of La Bolempie, Limon Rotisserie or Santa Cruz's Cafe Brazil will be into Mi Lindo Peru. I had the lomo saltado and it was delicious. Strips of sirloin, onions, tomatoes, french fries over rice and I ordered a fried egg on the side. It was perfection. Instantly cured my hang over and hunger on a Sunday morning and I've been craving it ever since. While parking can be difficult since it is in a busy neighborhood; at least the food is served very fast  I imagine this place to be fun for dinner since they serve sangria. I will definitely be back for more lomo saltado real soon.
author: Kristy H.

description: Saltado...my new favorite word. Local, chill spot, family friendly, big portions. Ceviche so fresh. Pescado Saltado (red snapper) so good! Accompanied by a light Peruvian beer. Oh yum.
author: Jessica G.

description: This is an authentically yummy Peruvian spot that has a local/neighborhood vibe.  I always get their lomo saltado, and their sangria is pretty tasty.  Be prepared to wait a little bit since it's a small spot and can get crowded.  Friendly staff, and not expensive.
author: Christina V.

description:
Fresca eat your heart out! This place has tastier food and larger portions at smaller prices. Truthfully, the atmosphere in this joint is somewhat sparse and uninspired but Mi Lindo sports some incredible service (good lookin' too).

PS - Don't order the Sangria unless you plan on staying sober. Tastes great though~
author: insipidphishie P.

description:
Excellent family run atmosphere with delicious food.

I can't seem to ever order anything other than the "Arroz con pollo" but my friends tell me the Paella is delicious.  I also love "Papas al Huancaina" as an appetizer.
author: Gusty S.

description:
I have very dear memories that involve Mi Lindo Peru...

Back in Peru, when it's someone's birthday you cook the dish they like the most. Here in the US, my mother started the tradition of taking us out to eat to a Peruvian Restaurant to celebrate our birthdays. We went to Perol (I think it was)  for a while until they closed :( Best Panes con chicharron I ever had. Sniff...

But on my 20th birthday she took me to Mi Lindo Peru.
I was resenting her for taking me there and not protesting for Perol to reopen :(
But once I ordered my Lomo Saltado, I forgot I was mad.
It's so bomb!
The Adobo de Chancho is also great.
And my new favorite: Bistec a lo pobre. Only to be consumed if you are really hungry. It's a whole lot of food!
The chicha does not disappoint.
The servings are real (Not like a certain Peruvian restaurant on 24th st. which serves you half the food for twice as much) The plates are big and they are not stingy :)

I also love the atmosphere. It is so homey in there, it takes me back to  my childhood days when we used to eat out  in Peru...

The waiters are very friendly and excellent with children ( I took a 2 year old once and they were super nice to him!). The place is always clean and warm.

I love Mi Lindo Peru :)
author: Miss E.

description:
I liked Mi Lindo Peru at first. 

The portions are gigantic, prices are low, everything tastes, well, tasty. 

But then I took a friend there for dinner, and afterwards she felt ill. 

What could the matter be? 

She's allergic to MSG. 

But surely they don't use MSG at Mi Lindo Peru??

I went back in and asked them. They do. 

So if you're MSG sensitive, you may want to avoid, or at least ask them to lay off it. 

But maybe the MSG is why their food always seemed so... tasty.
author: Jacob L.

description:
Keeping it simple...

Great food, GREAT sangria, big portions (I just had my second half for lunch and am stuffed again), wonderfully warm staff.  We had our toddler with us and they kept him very entertained and were very helpful.

My husband had the steak and shrimp, I had the steak with the plantain (which was delicious).  

Only negative, steaks were a bit overdone for both of us.  But the shrimp were yummy!
author: Karie V.

description:
I love the spicy salsa? dish that came out with the bread. The server was very nice and he even helped my white ass pronounce the names of the dishes that i ordered.... which was fairly painless. 

portions were enough for me to have a great lunch the next day too!
author: kevin C.

description:
Hello and Welcome to the Francisco Pizarro show,

Tonight, my amigos y cristianos, I proudly announce that after many expeditions to find "El Dorado's Lomo Saltado" it has been found by me, "el gran conquistador". I always knew that Ponce de Leon and Hernan Cortez had nothing on me and Mi Lindo Peru is my crowning achievement in discoveries!

I have gone up and down, Destino, Fresca at Fillmore, and an arrogant Essencia. Mi Lindo Peru takes them all and shows them how Peruvian is done. Now let's hear to what my reviewers, "The Ambiguously Garcia Duo" have to say:

MLP's 'ceviche de pescado' is simply drenched in splendor and the fish is so delicious, we wanted to get naked and rub it all over us, but that is just to get you going. We must also squirm in such delightful maritime wetness with a nice sangria and why not, an Inca Kola. However, just when you think you had the best girl / guy in the ceremonial Machu Picchu orgy, the stunning Lomo shows up and things get interesting. The way they make their food is REAL, is how it is done. If you are a 'health nut' or a hippie vegan or a 'had sex with a spanish girl/guy so i know all about spanish culture now' person...walk away, go to Destino, while very good, it is safe for 'your kind'... *wink*. It feels very folkloric in here, which is a good thing. You hear real spanish people, NOT any of the:

"Well, Jen, during my last trip to Peru and feel the real people, I perceived a sense of impoverishment that inspired me, their struggle permeated my thoughts  so much, that on my first-class trip back I was looking at some pictures I took with my iPhone of some real indigenous people. I have them on my new hi-def display at home...you should come over"

"Oh sure Bob, you are sooo cultured, I want to have sex with you over the llama skin your purchased"

No, no pretentious pompous people here! This is heaven for us!!!! Also, make room for the flan. It's probably one of the best in the city. We have to admit, we need a couple of more rounds to Fresca and Destino (hit or miss place sometimes).

This is authentic, very very good sizable portions, great service! Absolutely love it and the price is just simply excellent. It is very very cheap, not like Essencia's faux  and overpriced peruvian
author: Jesus G.

description: very good tasty food , i got a saltado de lomo it was very fresh the location is ok .. inside its very cute and cozy lil place i will definitely come back
author: Monica M.

description:
Nice, quaint restaurant with modest Peruvian decorations.  Everything I ordered was excellent.

Ceviche Mixto - Great limejuice variety that the seafood was marinated in.  It was very tangy, slightly salty. It reminded me of a Thai salad dressing that I've eaten before.

Lomo Saltado - Mmm...just thinking about it makes me drool.  Steak and french fries mixed together? What a great combo! Who ever thought of it was a genius.  The steak was very tender and the sauce was delicious.  The seasoned rice served with the steak and fry mixture complimented together nicely.

I also recommend trying the chica morada beverage and the inca kola (tastes just like bubble gum).  

I tried my friend's dish, the Pollo al Jerez.  It didn't taste very good to me.  It was very bland and watery.
author: Ingrid L.

description:
yum! 

beautifully crisp yucca, wonderful cheese sauce. overcitrusy ceviche, but still edible -- gently-approached paella. i can't speak to the authenticity, but saw a lot of signature beef offerings, which i hadn't tried. nicely done tapas -- champignones were beautifully garlicky. and good bread, too!

portions weren't huge, but not bad.
author: Annie W.

description: Very underwhelming. I followed other reviewers and we got the beef saltado, the seafood (mariscos) and chicken saltado spaghetti along with fried calamari and mixed ceviche appetizers. The ceviche had a very tangy juice but the seafood all seemed bland. The only way I can think this is possible is if the seafood was pre boiled or steamed then added to the ceviche juice. The fish had the most flavor. The squid, mussels, shrimp...bleh and meh. I think its pretty impossible to start a ceviche raw (the correct way) in the acidic juices and not have the seafood absorb the flavor  The fried calamari was lightly breaded and had a slight crisp which is fine, though I do prefer more crunch myself. The aioli was just mayo and ketchup. No garlic. The saltados were both under seasoned and cooked to death. Their descriptions mentioned some sort of special herbs and seasoning. It was nowhere to be tasted. The spaghetties had no special sauce. Just oil and salt n pepp. I hate to say it but I think the salsa was the highlight. It came with the free bread and butter. Absolutely mediocre bread. Waiter was nice. Absurdly overpriced, particularly the ceviche. 15 bucks! As much as each of our entrees and very disappointing. I don't understand the hundreds of 4 star reviews here... Lies I tell u!
author: Eugene H.

description: First time trying Peruvian food and it was quite tasty! The Bistek was juicy & savory, served with rice. It had a unique flavor and provided the comfort of homecooking.
author: Robin H.

description: Hands down, my favorite Peruvian restaurant. So much better than Fresca.  Went here after having a few drinks and ordered my regular: ceviche (can't remember which one, but they are all good) and the arroz con pollo. With my stomach full,  I left with a smile...
author: Marck N.

description: Huge portions, great prices, all manner of surf and turf, appetizers like papas huacaina (potatoes in a creamy spicy sauce) and all the standards like lomo saltado and ceviche. mmm, mmm good
author: Vanessa H.

description: This place was fantastic!  Very authentic and excellent ceviche.  Will be going back!
author: Sin F.

description:
EVERY PERUVIAN RESTAURANT SHOULD TASTE THIS GOOD!

Great food, & good size portions (several years ago they gave more, but still alot)

My favorite is the Saltado de Camarones (shrimp). Oh yeah...I love any of their dishes with meat, fries, and their special rice with corn. YUMMMMMM!!!! I've tried other things here and most items were unlike anything I've ever tried.

Several years ago this was my first Peruvian restaurant. One of my closest friends and her hubby introduced us to this place. Since then I was open to trying  more Peruvian restaurants only to find all other peruvian restaurants don't do it like Mi Lindo Peru. 

Parking in the mission can definitely be a B*THCH pending on the time of day you go. They atmosphere of this place can definitely be improved as their nothing fancy. BUT WHO CARES....FOOD HERE IS AMAZINGLY DELICIOUSO

We held many b-day dinners including friends, my sisters', and yes even my Mom's.
author: Cathy D.

description:
I love that no matter how yuppied-out vanilla the customer,  the staff will only address you in Spanish. If you plan to dine in Peru, you better speak the language! Though my Spanish is almost non-existent, and the b/f had a question mark permanently etched in his face each time the waiter addressed us, this didn't deter him from speaking in Spanish, and Spanish only. This only added to our experience.
The food was wonderful. The paella could feed a family of 10, so if you order paella, don't order much else. We went overboard and ordered a salad, plantains, beef skewers and paella for 2 people. All this cost less than our standard dinner at any other restaurant and could have fed an entire 5th grade class.
author: Michelle D.

description: What can I say.  Killer unique salsa and delicious everyday Peruvian food.  Fulfill your taste bud without the slightest hint of being pretentious.  Something the french restaurants can work toward.
author: Wa W.

description:
Food with zing!  Service with refreshing no-nonsense style.

They basically serve seafood, chicken, or beef over rice or spaghetti.  Sounds boring right?  Bzzzt!  Wrong.  This is the tastiest stuff on earth. The meats are well marinated and spiced.  You gotta love a place where you find french fries mixed inside the entre.

My only gripe is that some many months ago, they stopped using safron in their rice.  It's now plain white rice.  Darn, but still mucho tasty.

Speaking of mixing french fries into your entre, Ali Baba's lamb shwarma on 19th and Valencia is mucho yummers as well.
author: Jason Y.

description: Good, Homey feeling, Fresh, and tasty. There is so much flavor in their dishes down to the free dip they give you with soft yummy bread. I've had the beef saltado, plantains, Paella, sangria!, and ceviche. If you like peruvian food in a non hipster place with the non hipster prices, you know what I mean, then this is a good place to try.
author: Karen T.

description: Giving it three stars because my little brother really liked it. I wasn't too into it (and I normally love Peruvian) but maybe it's because it was our second dinner. We went to this overpriced little sushi place first and racked up a $100 bill before deciding we were still hungry and then popped over here.
author: Kay P.

description:
I have been here a few times with my wife and her sisters because it's close to their house and usually has seating available for walk ins.  It's got all of the makings of a good hole in the wall place but without the awesome tasting food.  It's an old and small storefront building in SF.  It's also reasonably priced.

We usually find their food somewhat bland and overly greasy.  I do like their papa rellena. They also use instant chicha morada which is a lot like drinking instant iced tea.  Blea.  The service is middle of the road and the bathrooms are pretty nasty.  Cleanliness in general could be better.  Like everything in SF it's parking jihad.  Be prepared to walk 2-3 blocks and feed the parking meters.
author: Bobby K.

description:
The sangria is SO good.  THE best I've ever tasted.  I swear!  Tastes like fruit juice with a hint of communion wine (is that sacrilege to say?).  I didn't realize that I had so much until I felt myself get warm.

The food.  It was rather tasty.  I had the platanos plate which was OK.  I wish they were a bit crisper.  Is that even possible?  I like my platanos to have more texture rather than mush (1 star deduction).  Had the calamari which is good.  Has some of my BFs food and it was delish!

Service was good and I will come back again.
author: Theresa M.

description:
Friends: We're hungry!  Where's the food around here??
Me:  Hold up!  Lemme Yelp it!
Result: Mi Lindo Peru

It was a Sunday night around 7.  We walked over thinking we could sail right in, but no can do!  Not here anyway!  We waited for a good 45 minutes to get a table (we were a party of 6) and there was a party of 5 in front of us and a part of 3 behind us.  The line was getting longer.  We almost left a couple of times, but these tantalizing smells kept wafting outside when the front door opened.  It was enough to keep us standing there (though a few of us went around the corner for a beer).  

We finally get seated.  They're out of just about everything steak.  Damn.  I got a glass of sangria to drown my sorrows (mmmm, good stuff!).  Everyone ordered something different, but the highlights were the empanadas (ground beef, olives, raisins, and onion relish on the side . . . delish!), arroz con pollo (rice, chicken, LOTS of cilantro - tasty!), and the paella (yeah, i know, it's spanish not peruvian, but still really good!).  I saw a couple tables with some flan that looked mighty fine, but the portions are huge here.  I'd have to grow another stomach to fit in the flan (and if I could've, I most definitely would've)!

So it's four stars, only cuz they were out of steak and the wait was more than my growling stomach wanted to handle . . . but totally worth it!
author: Amy C.

description:
They got some good stuff up in here.  The portions were big and the food was really good.  Tasty Steaks and appetizing appetizers.  They even had a Peruvian Beer called Cusquena on their beer list so we were able to get a true Peruvian experience.  Their spread for their bread was good too though to me not on the level of Fina Estampa's bread spreads.    

But I think I like Mi Lindo Peru's food better than Fina Estampa though.  It's pretty much a tie though if I had to decide between the two.  Here, it seems more crowded since it is smaller so a little more festive but over at Fina, they have the high ceilings and you can sit back and relax more.....  

Peruvian Food tonight?  Decisions, decisions.......
author: Mark W.

description:
This place has the best Peruvian food in SF.

I love the calamari here and the Saltado.

BY RENEE
author: Ate quel l.

description: This place is great! We had the calamari appetizer. Crunchy and salty. I ordered the Arroz con Mariscos. It was full of shrimp, calamari, and mahi mahi. Very good dinner it was!
author: Paul C.

description: Traditional, homey, Peruvian food. Fresh corn nuts, great calamari, the shredded chicken in Andean sauce was great. Very reasonably priced as well. Very friendly service as well. I admit I was looking for that green aji sauce (didn't have it) but I can tell this place is really authentic.
author: Steven H.

description: I've been back to this place a number of times, and I have to say that the kitchen consistently turns out really delicious food and the table service is about as friendly as it could be. A neighborhood eatery doesn't get much better than this, so I'm adding a star.
author: David K.

description:
I'm not an expert on Peruvian cuisine, but this place definitely topped the other Peruvian places I've been to. The lomo saltado was delicious. The meat was juicy and tender and the portion was huge! 

The restaurant was fairly clean and the staff was very friendly and accommodating. Prices are decent too.
author: Jason L.

description: One word. AMAZING. The food here was so good. When you sit down they give you a bread basket with butter and this really delicious salsa. The salsa isn't too spicy but if you like onions, you will definitely like it.  I went with a friend and we ordered the 1/2 liter sangria. This was hands down one of the best sangrias I have ever had. It was sweet but not too sweet and the fruit was actually really tasty, so much so you wanted to actually eat it after drinking the wine. For an appetizer we ordered the calamari. The calamari was SO GOOD. I usually am not a big fan of calamari but my friend loves it so we decided to try it. Needless to say, I passed on the little pieces with tentacles (ew), but really good nonetheless. It came with a little mayo type dipping sauce which had a mild spice to it. For our entrees we ordered the arroz con pollo and the saltado de pollo. The arroz con pollo was really different, it was rice with chicken sauteed in a cilantro sauce. It almost tasted like an Indian chutney was doused all over it. The chicken in the dish was really tender and overall I liked this dish a lot. The saltado de pollo was good, but it definitely was not as good as the dish I had at Isabella's in San Jose. The chicken was a little on the dry side and there wasn't much sauce. I really like it when there's a lot of sauce with the chicken. We asked for a side of hot sauce, which was really spicy. If you can't handle spice I wouldn't ask for it :) The hot sauce gave the saltado de pollo a little bit more flavor. The service was good, whenever we asked for something we got it right away. Also, the portions are HUGE. The two of us couldn't finish the food so we got it packed and took it home. Definitely enjoyed it the next day. Overall, if you like Peruvian cuisine, this is worth a try!
author: Neha H.

description: Love it. This place reminds me of El Pollo Inka in Socal. The lomo saltado is exactly what I expected- a mountain of beef, onions, tomatoes on crispy fries. Beef was slightly overcooked but the crispy fries made up for it. 5 stars if the meal came with soup or salad.
author: B Y.

description: I been to Mi Lindo Peru alot of times. Their service is good and fast. I love the food..my favorite is Pescado Saltado. I usually go there for lunch and the prices are good...dinner:  the prices are more.....but it's good food!!
author: Angelica C.

description:
i had heard this place was amazing so my husband and i went for dinner tonight. the place was packed with couples and families and had a real nice, comfy vibe. i ordered the yucca a la huacaina which were like upgraded french fries with awesome sauce and some moist, seasoned rice. my husband got the chicken milanesa, which he liked but he thought it tasted a little off. 

they have AMAZING chicha morada...a must-order!

we had the flan and an alfajor for dessert. both were incredible and not too sweet. 

all in all, we really liked our food. there aren't tons of things for a veggie (like me) to eat, but it was a tasty meal!
author: Mina A.

description:
My wife is so obsessed with this place. And, with good reason. Their food is absolutely amazing. 

It used to be that every time we had friends visiting from San Jose or some other faraway land, my wife insisted on taking them here for dinner. Now, when these people come to visit us, they insist on going to Mi Lindo Peru for dinner.

This place is like crack. We're doing our best to spread the addiction to everyone we know. 

Perhaps this is Mi Lindo Peru's desire? They have a nefarious plan to take over the world one person at a time. I, for one, welcome our new Peruvian overlords.
author: Mark G.

description:
Mediocre at best. We each got a dish, one fish, one prawns and both were super greasy and tasteless. We asked for their recommendation and they told us those two were excellent...NOT! 

Hey Toro E. Like in America, there are a lot of people of Japanese background live in Peru. Not simple food- simple Japanese food reason.
author: Lo F.

description:
Wow, sounds like everyone loved their sangria but me.  It was all right, ours was really more winey than juicey.  Which isn't normally a bad thing but I just wasn't feeling it that night.  Fortunately one of my friends loves the stuff so we ended up ordering 2-3 pitchers.

The rest of the food was AWESOME.  The six of us shared a bunch of entrees and tapas and everything was rather good.  The place is packed for good reason, and the prices are fairly reasonable.
author: Diana C.

description:
Oh mi lindo peru, the first and only Peruvian restaurant I have tried and absolutely LOVE.

My brother took us here because all he can think about was the bisteca he had when he first came with another friend. And I must admit, even though I hardly eat meat, this shit was great. Juicy med-rare steak, plantains, potato chunks, rice and fried egg on top, with a cilantro herb sauce (hold the cilantro if you don't like cilantro like me) you must try it.

We family styled everything...definitely try the empanadas as an appetizer, we also ordered chicken saltados, avocado salad, seafood paella, and don't forget the SANGRIA. The best sangria I've had (personally I think it's better than ChaChaCha's) with perfect amount of crushed ice, lil chunks of fruit and oh so delish.  We had to top it off with Peruvian ice cream because we've never tried, but it was a little strange for my taste buds - the flavor reminded me of chai tea and the mouthfeel was slightly gritty. Probably wouldn't order the ice cream again, but it was worth the try.

Overall, very comfy casual atmosphere with excellent service. Prices very reasonable. Parking around the mission sucks ass, but nothing can be perfect.

GO...NOW!
author: Angela L.

description:
It's so hard to decide on a last-minute restaurant on a Friday night.  You want to try something fun, something good, something different, but you know most popular restaurants require reservations and it's a bit late to start calling at 7:30 pm when you want to start eating at 7:30 pm.  So my boyfriend and I relied on good ol' Yelp and picked Mi Lindo Peru to try.  Great reviews and doesn't take reservations!

The place is not glamorous.  It's like a little local mama n papa restaurant with not so many tables and plenty of space.   People took their time to eat and sat around despite the crowd building up near the door.  There is no list to sign, but catch the waitress' eyes and she'll remember you are next.
