They probably should've invested in more 2-person tables rather than 4-person tables, because a lot of diners (at least on a Friday) seem to be on dates.  But the wait staff is in no hurry.  Contrary to a lot of typical busy restaurants, they were more into taking care of the seated diners than to seat the people waiting as quickly as possible.  You will enjoy that kind of attentive and pleasant service when you are the seated ones, but probably will feel hungry and impatient as the latter kinds. 

We ordered steak, paella and a side of plantains.   The bread came with butter and some salsa-like hot sauce.  Pretty tasty, but pretty hot!  My boyfriend loved the steak.  Thought it was extremely tender and juicy and the best he's had in a long time.  My paella was also very tasty, came in an enormous quantity with generous amount of seafood.  We both couldn't finish our dishes and had to take them home.  They make excellent left-over the next day, by the way. 

Mi Lindo Peru is not a restaurant with extravagant decoration or romantic ambiance, but it has solid food with fair prices.   We will probably come back again pretty soon.
author: Candice B.

description:
I love love love south-american food, specifically ecuadorian food.  Peruvian   and colombian cuisines are the closet to ecuadorian since they are all in the same region.  

I went to Mi Lindo Peru with high-high-high expectations.  I must say their dishes are very authentic, but something-something is missing.  

This place is certainly much better than all other claimed "peruvian tapas" restaurants.  If you really understand peruvian cuisine, they certain don't eat "tapas" - meaning in small portions.  

Here in Mi Lindor Peru, the portions are standard in Peru. It's great! This is what I call REAL peruvian cuisine!  : )
author: N. C.

description:
This hole in the wall is a little gem in the rough. Not ever having tried Peruvian food before, my friend took me to Mi Lindo Peru a couple years ago and it's now one of my favorite restaurants in the city. 

The food is sooo good. Try the ceviche de pescado or the crab dip. Also, my favorite is their home-made sangria (which you'll like if you're a fan of a sweeter version than usual). Every friend I've eaten with there has agreed that they were satisfied with the food. 

The service is not bad for a family owned and operated restaurant, they're pretty fast and the waiter even speaks to you in a little Spanish then translates to English. I like it so I can also practice. 

The atmosphere is cozy and both families and hipsters seem to feel at home!
author: Tai M.

description:
this place is incredible... almost everything on the menu is 5 star.. the only con is that it is a small restaurant so you might have to wait but it is always worth it.. i wish  i didn't live so far away. 

an ex girlfriend took me there and i am glad she did because this is easily one of my favorite restaurants and anytime i am close i always wanna go..

just fantastic food and good servers.
author: Richard C.

description: For a casual place...the food is so yummy ,my favorite is the paella seafood. I tried their beefsteak n shishkabob  all great!
author: cecille p.

description: Consistently (for over 5 years) delicioso for lunch and/or dinner.
author: Lisa C.

description: My first Peruvian experience. I got the lomo saltado, which is french fries with beef and onions along with rice. The fries were kinda soggy and the beef was kinda dry. The dish basically tasted like beef stir fry with cut potatoes.  I probably will try something different next time due to the lack of originality. They also gave us bread in the beginning with butter and salsa so thats a plus. The lunch specials are priced around $10 so a couple of bucks more than the usual prices but for now not worth it. I am open to trying this place again as this was my first time and I might have ordered the wrong thing.
author: Robert Y.

description: My husband and I came to this restaurant and he had gone here a lot often when his co-workers go out for lunch.  I really love the Garlic Chicken, you dip it into this lemon dip. I ordered the Paella (seafood one).  I was in heaven!  My husband said that everytime he comes here it has been a heavenly taste bud experience.
author: Hilda M.

description:
Wowza! This was my first venture with Peruvian cuisine and it will definitely not be my last. The scene was meeting up with my prima and my play cousin. We couldn't decide on what to eat but we knew we were pupusa'd out so I said let's try the place next door! And we are so glad we did. 
What we ordered: 
*empanada (large portion, tasty) 
*sirloin kebab (perfectly cooked, also came with potato) 
*plantains (perfectly ripe served with sour cream) 
*salads (yum) 
*gallina entree (lightly flavored with potatoes and pretty addicting) 
*fried red snapper (perfectly crunchy) 
All these items have cool Spanish names but I can't remember them. Anyways everything was delicious, the salad was so good with avocado and potatoes and a wonderful Italian like dressing. The red snapper was also yummy, we really enjoyed their version of curtido, picked onion. The entrees came with some yummy rice, at first I thought boring steamed white rice but no it was buttery with corn kernels in it. There was also a surprising hot sauce that was so good we had to ask for more. The prices are super reasonable all this food plus drinks and a liter of sangria was under $100! I am already thinking of when can I make it back to Mi Lindo Peru... Minus one star for the service, our waiter wasn't the friendliest person and did not find humor in us asking questions about what and how items were prepared.
author: La C.

description: Solid 4 star place. Great food, amazing (!) service. The foods are very flavorful and unique - every single one. Peruvian food at its best.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Awwwww, this place was so CUTE! The atmosphere was great, the service was super friendly, and the beer was goooooooooooooood. The food wasn't what I had hoped for, it was still good but a bit bland. We had the empanada (good but like a British pasty which I've had a lot at home), the ceviche was not as flavorful as I like, but the beef kebab did rock! 

So I'm giving it 4 not 3 because the people were so nice.   I think they need to be a lighter on the onions though. 

Still so glad we tried it, because it was one of the best nights with my girlfriend.
author: rhiannon B.

description: Solid and affordable Peruvian restaurant. Neighborhood is a bit sketchy, but not too bad, parking is pretty bad though, but not entirely impossible. Service is usually great and food is consistently good. Large portions. They also have the Inca Cola which is basically cream soda that is kind of good too. You can try parking on the Safe Way lot, but they do tow away sometimes.
author: Andrew S.

description: My boyfriend and I love this place! The owner is every nice and friendly and everything we have ever ordered was delicious. Everyone I brought there likes the restaurant so far. Also, I have had my birthday dinner there 3 years straight cuz it's that good ^__^   The place is a little small and they don't take reservation but they do make an exception when you have large number of people. As long as I love in SSF, I don't think I'll eat peruvian food anywhere else but here!!!
author: Chantanee S.

description:
I've lived in the neighborhood for almost 3 years, and have gone to this restaurant only a handful of times.  That's because the food isn't a knockout, it's just OK.  What I've ordered has tended to be rather bland tasting, even the seafood dishes.  Nothing I've ordered has been something to write home about. 

The plus side is the portions are huge (one dish can basically serve two people), so you get a lot for the money.
author: Ramon C.

description: I had their ceviche, fried plantains and some sangria. all were fairly good but not excellent. i've had better tasting ceviche elsewhere in the city, although their portion is very big. the sangria needed some more fruit and the fried plantains were a bit too greasy. i would definitely try this place again sometime, but for peruvian food, i already have another favorite.
author: Kerri B.

description: Now I'd never had Peruvian food until I came to this joint, so I wanted to wait until I came a few times until I gave my review and man.. this place is BOMB! Every single time I'm here I come out stuffed, with leftovers, and with a pleased look on my face. I always get the lomo saltado as my entree but I've tried a few of the appetizers and they're ALL delicious. OMG I want my leftovers now :| I left them at my friends studio, grrrrr. I STRONGLY encourage everyone to here as much as possible lol NO JOKE!
author: Nancy R.

description:
Liked the Arroz con mariscos as entree. Cute sign. Hey Pad Thai moved across the street from them a couple of years ago?  Wondered where they moved to.

Friend liked this place and got a small group and just had fun, but closed kind of early so had to sceedadle to another place for more drinks and partying.
author: miriam b.

description:
I love this place!!!!

The atmosphere is awesome, the servers are friendly, but most of all, the food ROCKS

Must try: Arroz Con Pollo!!! (It's Chicken, Rice, Cilantro and a lot of other good stuff.)

I love the french fries they serve with the garlic rice!!! My own culture is awesome with garlic rice, but Peruvian has the best non-Asian rice, I've ever tasted!

The lunch specials are only $6-7 each. Bring coins for parking. Bring an appetite. Classy place, but good food.
author: Alexander D.

description:
Pretty darn good Peruvian food. 

My Girlfriend and I happened upon this place randomly when we just decided to drive in a direction to find something to eat. We parked down the street walked past the place and decided that this was the best food idea since we went to Good Fricken Chicken last week. 

All food items were tasty...chicken tamale was heavy on the chicken! The Lomo Saltado was better than other places I have been, and the Chicken with saffron and cherry wine was not overwhelmingly saffron flavored! Saffron dishes are really good when the saffron is just an undertone and this one was cooked well. 

Service was great. We would definitely make a return visit, if we happen to randomly end up in Bernal Heights again!
author: Nick V.

description:
I have been here multiple time. This is my FAVORITE Peruvian restaurant in SF. The food is good, and the service is good.

I highly recommend it!!
author: Fabian M.

description:
I really like this place!  It's small and cute, and the menu is just about the right size.  I've been to Peru once, but I'm no expert, but the food here seems pretty authentic.  The champinones al ajillo starter was VERY good.  it could have been a little better with less salt, but the garlic/oil sauce was just the right consistency so it wasnt running all over the place.  

My wife and I shared the lomo saltado entree, and it was very tasty.  the fries were very fresh and were exactly how I remembered eating them in peru.  the servers were very nice, and the place was nice and mellow and not too loud. 

my wife has been there a couple times since we went the first time, and she has enjoyed it every time, so we will continue coming back!
author: Brian S.

description:
you will never go wrong coming to this place! its a cozy atmosphere and they have great food! 

appetizer- deep fried calamari!

entree- lomo! its rice meat, vegetables, and fries. yes i just said FRIES!

drink? sangria or if your not in the mood for that must try inca cola!
author: Tina D.

description:
my all time love, peruvian food.  it has been too long since our last encounter.  but we picked up where we left off...deliciously and sinfully scrumptious.  visited mi lindo peru for the second time with a peruvian food virgin and, of course....i turned him out!  i love taking people out to try new cuisine!  makes me happy!  every dish was so new to him.  i like seeing people so eager to try it...but being the more experienced one, i think i was more excited to see him try everything for the first time ;)  there was a slight wait when we went but once seated, the wait staff was attentive & gave me a chance to practicar mi espanol & feel a little exotic.  

paella marinera, anticuchos, papas a la huancaina y sangria were on the table for our eating & drinking pleasure!  i'm grinning just thinking about the wonderful flavors!  the anticuchos are a favorite dish for me - it has a slight smokey flavor, very tender & not gamey.  i wished that there were at least a foursome or more, so we could have shared more dishes, stories & laughs!
author: Vic S.

description: Scrumptious delights with a warm, home-styled atmosphere.  You really can't go wrong here.
author: shojua p.

description: I had the Bistek a lo Pobre and it was absolutely delicious!
author: Tony M.

description: So I had the Pollo Oreganato and it was DIVINE! The rice was so good. My friend had the lomo saltado and it was also delicious. The bread and butter were also fresh and perfect as a free appetizer. We had the platanos fritos con helado. I will definitely return to this latin food gem on the mission.
author: Genaro R.

description: Decent food and good portions. But how about a bigger plate just so I have more freedom while playing w my food?
author: Vince A.

description:
I've been here a couple of times but this time I got to go with a  true Peruvian and was happy to hear that he approved the place.  The setting is not over the top but the food definitely is.  

The waiter recommended the halibut ceviche which was an awesome choice.  It was so tasty that we we pretty much inhaled the dish.   I ordered a seafood platter with included french fries and rice mixed with corn.  It was quite good.  To wash down my meal, I had nice cold Peruvian beer.  I also got to sample yucca with a creamy egg sauce, shimp chowder and the Peruvian style arroz con pollo which my friends ordered.  Everyone at my table raved about the arroz con pollo so I highly recommend it.   We ended our meals with a Peruvian ice cream which reminded me of a mellow caramel ice cream. Not overbearingly sweet which was a good ending to our meal.

The food is very tasty and a little bit on the pricey side but well worth it.
author: Jay A.

description:
Fantastic food- love everything. 

The dining room is a bit casual, but hey, the food is a bit from the heart.

I give it 4 stars only in that it's not 'fabulous'- but if it were, it probably would lose it's touch!

Love it!
author: Chuck H.

description:
My former co-workers and I used to come all the way from downtown SF to this place for lunch. It's not lavish in decoration or anything, but clean and nice staff.

My favorites:
Tallarin de mariscos
The bread and spicy Salsa ( it's just sooo good)
The Cilantro Seafood Soup. ( It looks weird, but tastes really hearty and savory...squeeze in some of the lime they give you)
The best calamari and the sauce that goes with it.
The Garlic Fish Filet
Anticuchos ( yes, this is heart, but it's tender and flavorful)
Lomo Saltado 
and of course THE SANGRIA.

Parking is a bit hard after 6 around this area. So come early. The Bank Of America lot turns into a private lot at night, they charge about $7.00 but spaces here are limited as well.
author: Kat T.

description:
A friend of mine found a new BOOO so lately he's been dinning out.  With that being said he recommended that I try this place.  

When entering the restaurant there about 8-10 tables occupied, but we were seated right away.  Our waiter was very nice and asked us if we wanted any drinks.  Our friend was running late so we order a pitcher of Sangria and proceeded with business.  The Sangria was excellent . Not to strong and I personally like the mini chunks of fruit.  I could definitely enjoy this on a nice warm day.

Once our friend arrived we  proceeded to order.  After a reviewing the menu we all agreed that the Bisteck a lo Pobre with egg was standing out. A juicy  Steak topped with a fried Egg, Onions served with Rice, and Plantains.  YUM MM...  That sounded hella good but I wanted to try something different since everyone else was going to order that dish.  I went with the Milanesa de Carne which is there take on chicken fried steak which came with rice and 2 golden potato's.  The Chicken was alright a little dry for my taste. It could use some lemon or some sauce.  

Overall the food is pretty good and the plates our huge.  The staff is friendly and speak in the native language.  

I'll be back be 4 shizzle
author: Robert M.

description:
I went there after reading some good reviews on Yelp -thanks everyone! My friends and I had a great meal. We started with the yummy sangria (some of the best I've had). The ceviche de mariscos was delicious.

The lomo saltado was fantastic. The only less than stellar dish was the arroz con pollo. It was surprisingly bland and I'm not one for salt.

Overall, a great meal that I would definitely recommend.
author: B S.

description: Lomo saltado was really good. We had platanos maduros which were really good except the appetizer consisted of about a half of one plantain. It's a banana! This isn't fancy french food, small portions of platanos are ridiculous. The ceviche pescado was fantastic as well. Can't wait to come back.
author: Mark R.

description:
Pick a soup, any soup, any soup on the menu... No vegan options, but for those times when I eat seafood, I want to make sure it's absolutely delicious - and the seafood soups here fit the bill!

The atmosphere is a little blah - the warm-colored walls are nice and the gentle music was cheerful, but the place in general is very quiet - yet too brightly-lit to be romantic in its quietness. I wouldn't call this place "cozy" - more utilitarian. I prefer a more bustling, exciting dining experience so I've knocked off one star for vibe. But the sangria, I agree, is great. And I will definitely be ordering soup to-go in the future!
author: Andrea D.

description:
My girlfriend Gena and I visited MLP last night.  Having arrived at 4:30, and 30 minutes before the restaurant opened, we strolled to the corner where we found a local bar, Club 3360.  Colorful Mission Street dive but the beers @ $4 each during happy hour were a little higher than I thought they should be.  

At 5P, we left the bar and walked to MLP.  The two of us love to eat early.  Good food makes a restaurant popular.  Popularity makes a restaurant noisy.  We think 5-6P is the perfect time to get good food at a popular restaurant without all the noise.  Additionally, the restaurant staff is delighted to see us at a time when there are so few patrons.  

"What's your signature beef entrée?", I asked the waitress.    She replied that we might like to try the Bisteck a Lo Pobre, a sirloin steak sauteed w/ onions & tomatoes topped w/ fried plantain & egg.  Between the two of us, we ordered the above entrée for one, the anticucho appetizer (marinated beef on skewers), the spicy tomato spaghetti soup, and lastly plantains tapas.  Gena had water and I ordered a glass of sangria.  

We got off to a good start; the bread came out with butter.  Gena gets annoyed when the restaurant doesn't bring butter with the bread.  In addition, the bread came with a thicker than usual salsa which was spectacular; different in flavor from other salsas we have gotten at other So American/Mexican restaurants.  No chips.  

Consistent with reviews below, the anticucho was very nice.  Nicely marinated and cooked the way we like, medium rare. 

Although "spaghetti" does not sound terribly Peruvian, the soup was delightfully spicy.  Knowing that there were two of us, the restaurant smartly split a single portion into two bowls.  It always confounds me why more restaurants don't do this for couples who cannot or do not want to eat to excess.  Many of us dine for the experience.  The offer of such a simple extra service will invariably be reflected in the tip.  

The Bisteck entrée was tasty and generously portioned.  So much for not eating to excess.  The extra side of plantains were as good as dessert if not better.  Not too sweet. Not too filling.  The sangria was in a medium sized glass with bits of apple, which I found to be a refreshing touch.  

The bill before tip came to $49, a fair amount to pay for good food and friendly service.  With all the great choices to dine in the Bay Area, it is rare that Gena and I will go to the same eatery twice.  ML Peru however is definitely a place that we can return.
author: Matt G.

description:
this might be the best lomo saltado i've ever had!  healthy portions, and the sangria was good too.

note: we came in at 8 pm on a sunday, and there was plenty of space.  however, as it neared 9 pm (which is their closing time), it became more and more crowded.  i don't know if this is typical, but 8 pm on sunday was a good time to go, just fyi!
author: Jill k.

description: Finally getting around to writing a review. I had dinner here with one of my sisters and my  nephew when they came for a visit back in May. It was my first time eating here and I loved their Lomo Saltado. My sister had the shrimp dish (I think) and my nephew had the the fried chicken dish and we also had the ceviche ( my memory must be going because I can't remember some of these dishes) and we also had an empanada. The empanada was o.k.. The side, marinated onion slices (?) was better than the empanada. I'd would definitely come here again for lunch or dinner....and I'll make sure to write down the names of the dishes I'll eat =).
author: Neni E.

description:
Of all the Peruvian restaurants in town, this one strikes me as the most like a comfort food place.  I imagine if you grew up on Lomo Saltado, this would be the place you went to for some of that back home feeling.

Of course I'm not Peruvian, but I enjoy it just the same.  It's a nice change of pace from the other restaurants on this street.  And Bernal Heights is hopping more than ever, so you might well end up here once in a while.
author: Danny H.

description:
I keep coming back to Mi Lindo Peru time & again determined to try a new-to-me entree, but am seduced once again by the "muy delicioso" Pescado Saltado (strips of red snapper sauteed w/ onions, tomatoes, AND french fries).  So I force myself to order a different appetizer every time!  So far my fav is the yummy garlic soup w/ croutons . . .

I love this friendly, affordable, and unpretentious place - considering how most other Peruvian restaurants in SF are so fancy-pantsy as to bill themselves as "Fusion Peruvian" or "Contemporary Peruvian" or even  "Nouveau Peruvian"  . . . To call Peruvian food "fusion" is not only an oxymoron but tantamount to an insult to the Inca, Spanish, Basque, African, Sino-Cantonese, Japanese, Italian, French and British contributions to the more "authentic" Peruvian cuisine!
author: RichiePoo B.

description: Hands down this is the best Peruvian food in the bay area. I love this place, when I lived in the city I would go at least 2-3 times a week, now I live in Concord so I can't go as much :( I have never tasted a dish that I did not LOVE from here. Some of my all time favs are: lomo saltado, pescado saltado, chicharon de pollo, ceviche and well I could honestly list the whole menu. Sometimes the service is hit or miss but the food is so good it really doesn't matter.
author: Lani R.

description: I used to go to the location in the Marina but that one closed down.  The sangria is great!  Get it by the carafe.  The salsa stuff is sooo good.. a little butter on the bread with the salsa to top it and I'm set.  I would say the main entrees are better than the tapas. The food and service is actually much better when the owners (or at least I think they are the owners) are around; I agree with earlier reviews there.  Last time I was here the owners were around so it was extra yummy!
author: Tabitha S.

description: Went for a walk with my man and found this spot right by my house and it was so so good! We got some steak dish that came with french fries in it. Sounds strange but it soo soo good. We also got the chicken and rice. Was also really good but needs a little salt. They have great bread and some kind of great sauce that goes on it. This place does not look so great from the outside and the ambiance is lacking but it is really a great spot. Cheap and tasty! I highly recommend this spot if you are in the area or are looking for a great Peruvian spot!
author: Samantha R.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru is located in the culinary haven that is The Mission South of Cesar Chavez, or MiSOCC as I like to call it. You heard it here first. That acronym is mine. Bucky Created The MiSOCC or BuCT MiSSOC.... 
I call this area a culinary haven, because you can get great food at an incredibly reasonable price. And Mi Lindo is no exception to this rule. Every time we go we end up spending about 30 dollars and that includes sangria and a beer, AND we always have leftovers. the portions are pretty sizable here. This doesn't apply to their tapas obviously, but when their entrees arrive it is almost embarrassing when they drop that large steaming plate in front of you. I mostly stick to their version of fried rice that has rice, egg, and peas in it. Cusqueno is the perfect accompaniment to that...mmmmmm. Service is always good and on most nights there is a small line for a table. A great addition to the MiSOCC!
author: Bucky K.

description:
I've been to Mi Lindo Peru a few times, and every time it's been pretty good. It's not the best Peruvian place in the city, but no matter what you get it will be good. Even though I prefer a a seafood mix cevice, the fish ceviche here is delicious. Mine wasn't "too salty" like other reviewers said. I could eat the ceviche from this place all day.

The paella de mariscos is a little "dry" (which is a relative term, I guess), and I wish there were more clams in it, but the flavors are all there. I wish they would add some spice to their paella, like Fresca does, but like I said, delicious nonetheless.

Beware, though. After eating 3/4 of the paella and all of the ceviche, I was dropping bombs over baghdad all over the place, and I think I nearly killed my Dad's dog from the smell. Watch out if you get gassy easily.
author: Alexis C.

description: Fantastic!! Delicious, large portions, very affordable prices. Try the red snapper ceviche and beef heart appetizers.
author: Dan T.

description: Food was top notch - as other yelpers have mentioned.  First time having Peruvian and if it's like Mi Lindo Peru than I will be forced to say Peruvian is my new favorite food.  Great meal - recommend the steak, shrimp and rice.  We had a few other wonderful appetizers and the only issue with the food was that our stomachs couldn't handle more, though we wished we had the room.  Without a doubt we will be back and this will be the golden standard that restaurants will have to compete with for service and food in SF.
author: Colin S.

description: I constantly fall back in like with MLP.  The service is so friendly, the food is so good, and it's now only a 10 min walk away from my place.  So much goodness there.  Favs: Lomo Saltado,  Tallarin Sattado De Pollo (the spaghetti equivalent of the Lomo S), Arroz Con Pollo.  Recently tried the Picante De Mariscos for the first time b/c I was trying to replicate a dish I had in Peru, and while tasty, it wasn't quite there.  This will not deter me, though, from returning time and time again ...
author: Melinda C.

description: This was my first time at Mi Lindo Peru and the whole experience was great!  I had their specialty, the bistek, which was covered with onions, yummy seasonings, a plantain and fried egg!  Their ceviche is also yummy and different, served with yams and potatoes.  My kids shared an appetizer of fries and sliced hotdogs.  I know, sounds really unappealing, but it was actually really tasty!  We had to have a liter of sangria, of course, which is homemade, but not as good as you'd find on the other side of Mission at Cha 3x's!  The service we got was excellent, and even though the atmosphere seemed cozy and intimate, they were still very kid-friendly!
author: Jeralyn K.

description:
I wish I could pick this place up and plunk it down the block from me in Oakland.

Hadn't had Peruvian food before I came here, but my first visit nearly six months ago made me search in vain for a suitable substitute in the East Bay - finding a place that served a seafood + rice + fries-type of entree proved impossible, however.  I've heard great things about Inkas and may try that at some point, but summoning up the courage to try a new Peruvian restaurant within a stone's throw of Mi Lindo Peru is going to be difficult.
author: Christina S.

description: Tallarin saltado de pollo is great here.  It's a heaping pile of spiced spaghetti, and strips of lean chicken.  I can't speak about the other things on the menu -- I can be a creature of habit.  I go there for this dish.  One night I shared a bottle of sangria.  I think it was good, but I had been drinking before I got there.  The lunch and dinner menus are pretty similar, but the lunch prices are lower.  I think it cost like $5 or $6 and it was huge.
author: Emilio O.

description: When you marry a Peruvian, you get spoiled.  When her mom comes to visit, you get pampered AND spoiled.  I'm talking authentic Peruvian comida every night.  It's not likely any Peruvian eatery is going to impress these taste buds.  But while on a business trip to SF, CA a few years ago down by the Marina district something caught my eye while walking down the sidewalk.  Mi Lindo Peru.  Wow.  Okay, I had to go in and check it out.  Well, long story short- I was so blown away with their Lomo Saltado I called my wife back in Texas on the spot.  I started reading the menu to her and realized I was torturing her rather than having her share in my excitement.  Lets get real, there are no Peruvian restaurants in Austin, Texas worth speaking about.  That was then and this is now.  That location closed and moved down below the Mission district.  On my last visit, I rode the Bart and walked several blocks in unfamiliar territory- all for a Cusquena and Lomo Saltado.  I turned a corner and Viola!  There it was, with a new sign and everything.  Slightly larger area and the food was oh so excellent- even mama Rosa would have been impressed back in Lima.  Now- they don't know me from Adam, but I know them.  I'm a fan and I tell 'em everytime I visit- that someone in Texas loves them.  I'll be there again in late May 2010.  Maybe I'll get papas a la Huancaina or cicha morada or... hmmm.  Arroz con pollo or Ahi de gallena.  The list goes on and my mouth is watering already.  Ahhh mi lindo Peru en San Francisco.  Te amo mucho.
author: randar m.

description: Fantastic food, great prices.. I just read the MSG Comment and my husband, who is pretty sensitive, didn't have a reaction so perhaps they don't use it on all of their dishes?? Anyhoo, their ceviche was plentiful, fresh, and flavorful and i wish i knew what the crunchy corn things on the side were called... like inverted popcorn. yum.  Their entrees are within the 10-16 price range, which makes for a perfect budget meal. Family friendly and neighborly, it's a favorite... I used to live across the street and we used to love it then, now that we live across town it's become one of our favorites! Only drawback is that it can get crowded if you go late, so go early if you can. We had the cilantro chicken rice (and believe me, i do not even like cilantro) and the cherry wine/saffron chicken, which was amazing.  I even had it for lunch today and can't wait to go back.
author: M'ia K.

description: A low-cost, good alternative to the better tasting, higher end venues like Limon or Fresca, but you definitely get what you pay for here. Well the quantity of food is bountiful, the quality is less appetizing than the fare you might receive at Destinos. The wait staff is attentive, and the ambience it ok. I generally love Peruvian food, but found myself ordering fried shrimp over the lomo saltado, as it wasn't appealing to me. The other folks I was with last night quite enjoyed their food, and will most likely return to Mi Lindo Peru. I on the other hand will save me pennies and try INKAs up the street the next time out.
author: Jaime R.

description: I've been going here close to 10 years now, and never once did I feel like the food or service was "off"! I've tried a number of different items on they're menu, and all of them were great. I think my favorite is the "Mar Y Terra" (they're version of Surf & Turf), the steak is cooked with this "silky" sauce of some kind, it's so good, I always order a bit on the side to pour over my rice! There is also this interesting appetizer that I always get too, I don't know the name of it, but it is like a shrimp salad spread over thinly sliced avacado, oh my god I think I will have this tomorrow, no joke!
author: Tone K.

description: I give this place 2 stars, the ceviche was honestly the worst I have ever had. The Ceviche had no flavor and gave no option for it being spicy and any Peruvian will know that it is not real Ceviche unless it is spicy. The location was average and the staff was somewhat attentive but I guess it would be due to me being the only person there. If a restaurant is going to serve Ceviche they must do it right or don't offer it at all as I was disgusted with the poor excuse for Ceviche they presented to me. I honestly have had better Ceviche from a white girl who read it off a recipe website than this place and that is saying a lot. I will try out more Peruvian Ceviche restaurants in SF but this place gives the worst excuse for Ceviche and should rethink their recipe as what they presented was not Ceviche at all and if anyone begs to differ then you have honestly not tried authentic Ceviche and as a Peruvian I find this as an insult that anyone would even present me flavorless Ceviche.
author: Anthony S.

description: I came here for the first time with my coworkers for a Friday lunch.  I had never had Peruvian food before and had no idea what to order.  I ordered a lomo saltado and was blown away.  It was a mix of fried rice (yum) and french fries (yum) and it was the most delicious yet oddest thing I ever tasted.  I gulped it down and was delighted to see my check came out to only $12.  A great meal a great price earns this restaurant 5 stars.  Plus, you get free bread!
author: Edmund Y.

description: That mushroomy garlicy appetizer is insanely good - WOW!  Mi Lindo Peru is a favorite for friends from out of town...especially people from Santa Barbara and Sacramento...where they don't get much good Peruvian.
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
This past weekend, I took my girlfriend and a friend to Mi Lindo for their first Peruvian food experience.  Now, I am half Peruvian, so of course I believe I am an expert in this matter.

We were all really excited, Mi Lindo was to be my first Peruvian tasting on the west coast as well, and it seemed to be more authentic than the other restaurants that matched similar search queries.

My friends let me do all the ordering, and I knew exactly what we wanted.

Two Cusquenas (I prefer it over Cristal) and an Inka Cola.  (My girlfriend does not drink)  Inka Cola however, is my favorite soda, and I would like to mention that they have the real one, not the Ecuadorian version that has less flavor.

To start, I ordered the Ceviche Mariscos (Mixte), Papas a la Huancaina, and the beef anticuchos.

The Ceviche was top notch, great flavor, the best I've had in the US.

The Anticuchos, which are basically beef hearts on a stick, also had the exact flavor that I remembered from Peru.  Very tasty, very tender.

The Papas a la Huancaina were ok, My father makes the sauce much better.

At this point we order three Lomo Saltados, as it IS a dish descended from above, and decided we better order some more ceviche as well, it was just that good.

Out came the Lomo Saltado, my dining mates ooh'd and awed, it was a perfect moment.

Of course they loved it.  I however, was a little disappointed.  It didn't explode with flavor like I expected it too.  It seemed to be specifically missing a bit of lime and the aji amarillo.  Still very good, and we left the place barely able to walk.

Highly Recommended.
author: Adam C.

description: All of the food was excellent.  I especially liked the paella and ceviche.  Oh yeah and the fried plantains.  And the cassava.  And the salsa was really good.  And the bread.  Hell, even the water was delicious.
author: Dave M.

description: I can't understand what the rest of you are thinking about. My two visits here featured bland, fatty quasi-Mexican food, notable for the enormous portions and the generally very large size of the patrons.  Ugh!
author: Jane M.

description:
Okay, I may be Peruvian and, therefore, a little biased. But, let me tell you. If you want to have pretty close to home-cooked food from Peru, then, pack everyone in the car and head to Mi Lindo Peru. Nestled along Mission Street's Bernal Heights neighborhood, this place offers traditional Peruvian cuisine (and some Spanish cuisine as well). Being from Peru, I only come here for "my food". For those on a first visit, for appetizers, stick with Papa a la Huancaina -- delicious potatoes on a bed of lettuce in a sauce that is not hot (like it is supposed to be) but creamy and delictable nonetheless. Also, try the Causa Limena -- cold mashed pototoes (they ARE good like this) sandwiches seafood and avocado --- mmm, mmm, delicioso!  If you want to really taste Peru, ask for their Anticuchos - cubed beef on a skewer. The meat is perfectly seasoned with a blend of new mexico chile and other spices; indeed, the meat seems to melt in your mouth. 
       For dinner, the  Lomo Saltado (pan fried beef strips in herbs and spices, mixed with french fries) is served alongside some of the best rice you have ever tasted. This is Peru and as traditional as you can get without boarding a plane. It is served in large portions and steaming hot. If you are still hungry after all this, ask for a cup of joe and an "Alfajor" - the best cookie you will ever have in your life. Period. Oh yes, during dinner don't forget to ask for Inka Cola - tastes like bubblegum soda, but it is really good. The restaurant is not very large but it's worth the wait. The service is spotty at times but that is because there is usually only two people serving so many diners at once. In any case, they are excellent folks once you flag them over. Que aproveche!
author: Sal T.

description: Mi Lindo Peru serves average Peruvian food. Not bad but not like the food I had down in Glendale at Mamita's. The service is great and they have a great variety of dishes. If you're going to try Peruvian for the first time, this is a good place to start. I couldn't believe that Fresca got voted the best Peruvian in the Bay Area by the Bay Guardian. Fresca is okay but it's hardly authentic. If you want the real deal, head down to Mi Lindo Peru.
author: L. L.

description: This is the best casual Peruvian restaurant in the city.  I have been coming here for years and love the hot salsa they bring with the bread.  Staff there are friendly and service is pretty quick.  Parking sucks though and that is why I don't go there as much as I used to.  I somtimes try to sneak into the Burger King parking lot  to get my takeout but would not advise.  The fried rice (chicken or seafood) and mussel appetizer are all delicious.  They have an extensive menu. Seafood is not that fresh so would not recommend the ceviche.  I am stuffed every time I leave this place.  Be prepared, dishes are on the salty side so drink plenty of water during and after.  It is a good family owned restaurant.
author: Jac C.

description: I had just got back from a trip to Perú and was still craving their food. I checked out Yelp to find a Peruvian restaurant, this one was right around the corner from my friend's house, who I also wanted to discover Peruvian cuisine. I got the Arroz con Mariscos and she got the Lomo Saltado. My dish was heavily flavored with cilantro, which I like, but I also didn't have anything like it in Perú. It was great, don't get me wrong, but I wanted to get the flavor of what I was eating in my time south of the Equator, so we'll move on to the Lomo Saltado, which is ubiquitous in Perú. First thing right off the bat was that it was different tasting carne then the real thing (I ate it at least once every other day), not in a bad way, just different. Also, it wasn't spiced as strongly, which is no fault of the materials available, just a fault of the chef. It was still really good, and I will return, but to get that authentic Lomo Saltado flavor that I enjoyed so often down South, I think I'll just try cooking it myself. I recommend trying this place, although, if you're coming from Perú, like I was, paying 5x the prices of Lima is a bummer. Aw, how I miss it already...
author: Michael V.

description: My girlfriend and I  ate here the other day. Considering myself an avid Peruvian food consumer, this place is legit. We just moved here recently so I can scratch this place off the list. My only complaint was the salsa seemed overly saturated and oily, besides that the food is really good. We will be returning here soon I'm sure.
author: James H.

description: The lomo saltado was deceit and still uncomparable to the El Pollo Inkas in Torrance.  I was slightly disappointed that the meal did not come with awesome the green sauce.  Overall, still a deceit meal but I'm comparing to the best.  If you're craving for Peruvian food, I still would recommend this place.
author: Yvonne L.

description: Every culture has comfort food, and apparently in Peru, it's sliced steak or shrimp with tomatoes, onions, and french fries. This is a great place to go for simple and tasty food, with no attitude. The portions are large, so come hungry.
author: Ellie P.

description: I'm somewhere between 3.5 and 4 stars here. I met some "Peruvian" friends here this week and was pleasantly surprised. When they told me to meet them at the Peruvian place in the Mission I thought we were going to Limon... but Limon is closed... for good. Anyway, I finally found out where it was exactly. Sketchy neighborhood and the restaurant is a little worn but in a cozy sort of way. Same great Peruvian flavors and decent sangria. We all shared different things like ceviche and Picante Mariscos. Like I said, it was cozy. The prices weren't cozy though. It was about $15 a plate and with sangria, apps, dessert, and tip we ended up spending quite a bit. Service was very friendly as well. All in all I thought it was a great alternative to Fresca and Limon, the other Peruvian restaurants in the City.
author: Hunter G.

description: The food is tasty and generously portioned for the price.  The service is friendly and relatively fast.  The ambiance and the decor and the visible "cleanliness" leave a fair amount to be desired.  I would not come here if I was not drunk from too many  happy hour drinks at El Rio.  Having said that, keep in mind that my taste buds were drunk too, so the food may have been worse...or better than I remember.
author: Nilu r.

description: Delicious! The sangria here is amazing the the waiters are all so friendly.   Luckily we got here right before the crowd came so we didn't have to wait outside the restaurant.  The food is really good and simple.  The portions are very decently sized.  We had three tapas and a paella and could not finish everything.  The paella is delicious as well as their ceviche. Definitely will come back!
author: Sarah T.

description: One of our favorites in the city...if you like Fresca for it's food then you'll love this place. Don't expect a fancy shmanzy place, it is a whole in the wall, but it's the real thing!
author: Reza E.

description: I always love this place.  It is great Peruvian food but not trendy so the prices are reasonable.  I usually go with the same core group and we like to order Anticuchos which are skewered spiced beef heart.  When newcomers find out that it is beef heart they are usually reluctant to try it, but once they do they usually enjoy it.  To me, it tastes like steak but with the texture of liver.  The other appetizer we started with was traditional Peruvian Ceviche with halibut, toasted corn, onions and sweet potato.  Then I got the Pescado Saltado which is fried strips of red snapper, french fries, tomatoes and onions sauteed together and poured over rice.  It was good but I was jealous of my friends big steak with onions, plantains and yucca. If you want reasonable and tasty Peruvian food, definitely go to Mi Lindo Peru!
author: Stacy R.

description: one of my fave peruvian restaurant in  SF. if you want inexpensive flavorful peruvian food, go here. the civeche is seasoned just right, i always order the stir fried beef with french fries ( i order it so many times but i keep forgetting what it's called), it always taste the same, the one with chicken is good too, but i still like my beef. it's pretty darn good here, portion is just right too, not too little, not too much, service is good too! they are very friendly. if you pass by it, it's worth a stop for a lunch. try it out! you mind as well go here than frescas, i think it's overpriced there and it taste almost the same.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: Been to this place 4 times (in the marina on scott) and I enjoy it everytime.  Love the mussels, and hearts, sangria, and everything else.  You have to have seafood.  Service is great too.  Parking is difficult there so make sure to go early. It is tapas but they're huge.  Trust them when they tell you that you've ordered enough.  And if you've never had peruvian food, just ask the servers. Good place to bring your friends...
author: D W.

description: I have eaten here a couple of times and have been impressed with the food.  It is uniquely flavourful and hasa nice clean quality about it.  The portions are quite ample and you will leave with a full belly.  The staff are accomodating and seem to actually care that you enjoy your meal.  I will be eating here again.
author: Scott A.

description:
Mi Lindo Peru, mi lomo saltado.

Every time I come here, I open the menu, peruse all the delicious sounding dishes that I'm going to try, pick one...and then order the Lomo Saltado.  There are a dozen dishes I would like to try, and when I open my mouth to order, out pops "Lomo saltado, please."  It could be because the lomo is so tasty, and delicious.  It could be that I only go to Mi Lindo Peru when I have a huge craving for Lomo.  

In either case, you can't go wrong with the lomo.  You can get it with fish or shrimp if your red-meat-averse, but I never do.  The service was friendly and warm, the decor is homey but not kitschy, and the sangria is delicious.  I love this place.  One day, I will order a different dish and I'll probably love that one too.
author: Catherine P.

description: It's a good thing i've had much better peruvian food before.  Otherwise i would cross Peru off of my travel list.  The every piece of seafood in the mixed seafood dish was overcooked to the point of chewy or dry and the sauce was bland.  The fried rice was also bland with overcooked chicken.  The margarita was really good though.
author: LT B.

description: Wow, what a pleasant surprise. Great food, nice portions, good value, excellent service. I had the surf and turf -- uh, Mer y Tierra -- which featured a huge flank steak cooked just right to a succulent medium rare, prawns drenched in a mouth watering garlic herb marinade, and a green salad big enough to be an entree unto itself. we started with the meat emenada, which had a sweet corn taste, and a tamale that was more tender chicken than it was dough. a soft chocolate cake with a caramel sweet whipped cream and toffee bits finished off one of the more satisfying meals we have had in quite some time.
author: Eric P.

description: Just randomly popped in here after a visit to the Palace of Fine Arts.  The chicken a prawns were excellent and the wait staff was very helpful.  I'll surely be back.
author: Tessa M.

description: I'm a big fan of Peruvian food, and when I found out about this place I had to come and check it out. I Had the Arroz con Pollo and some fried calamari -all topped off with a cusquena (Peruvian beer) it was all delicious, and I look forward to coming back soon!
author: Sobhi M.

description: Tired of paying outrageous prices to get your Lomo Saltado fix at places like Limon and Fresca?  I'm sure that the Peruvians don't have to pay an arm and a leg for their food, so why should we?  I love both those places as much as the next guy, but when I'm craving some Peruvian and a cozy, laid back, unpretentious atmosphere, I go here.  The portions are ridiculous (trust me you'll have enough for lunch tomorrow) and the food is good.  The prices of entrees don't go higher than $15.95.  Agree with another reader that a pitcher of sangria for $20 is a bit steep.  But it definitely hits the spot with all the ceviche, grilled meats and fried plantains you'll be scarfing down.
author: Dave L.

description: Huge portions, friendly service, and french fries mixed in with the rice and entree (yum!).  If you're looking for edgy, artistic, or even particularly healthy cuisine, this isn't the place.  But if you're looking for a laid-back and affordable place to go with a friend or a small group of friends and enjoy some -- okay, a LOT of -- latin'ish comfort food, you'd do just fine here :-)
author: Adam L.

description: My girlfriend and I came across Mi Lindo Peru by accident while trying to find another Peruvian restaurant. I have never had a better Peruvian experience other than the restaurants I visited while in Peru. The place is small and has a very inviting atomsphere. It's very casual so no need to dress in your Sunday best. If you're into appetizers make sure to order Papas la Huancaina (a cold potato dish served in a spicy sauce, olives, lettuce and eggs) and  Prawns with garlic sauce. Yummy. As a main course, Lomo/Pollo Saltado is always a winner and the sea food soup one of the best I've tried. Wash it all down with Sangria. I'm a fan of deserts especially those from other places so try the Lucuma ( a native Peruvian fruit) ice cream. Great food, great prices and Awsome service. Thanks for reading. Silvia
author: Silvia S.

description: How can you not love Mi Lindo? This is absolutely one of my all time favorite restaurants in San Francisco. In fact, I was just there on Wednesday. The restaurant is family-owned and operated. When I was a regular (several times a month), the son always new my order. Since I'm not as frequent a visitor, seems he's forgotten my face. :(  My favorite appetizer is the calamari. It comes with a delicious onion-type salsa. My favorite dishes are the saltado varieties--pollo, lomo, pescado--sauteed meat with onions, tomatoes, and potatoes with rice and corn. Oh, and the bread along with the spicy red sauce is a keeper as well!
author: Felicia P.

description: came here first for a group dinner, then returned for a fun date night - mi lindo peru is great for both!  very friendly atmosphere, yummy food (and sangria). would definitely get the pescado saltado again (better than the lomo saltado - less dry) and the garlic mushroom appetizer (so good with the bread!), and the sangria (a little sweet, but i tartened it up with some lemon).  would skip the breaded chicken steak (entree) - strangely, it wasn't seasoned at all, so very, very bland.
author: Joyce L.

description: Wow! The Saltado is my favorite but then again everything on this menu is my favorite. The generous helping of everything keeps me coming back for me. The ceviche, NOW THAT'S CEVICHE (Front Porch, you need to go around the corner and get some lessons from these folks)! Have you ever had peruvian beer? It's good! Very malty, just the way I like it. In my opinion this restaurant blows Limon out of the water. Its cheaper and more homestyle. I definitely recommend.
author: Cat B.

description: Only been here once and it was OK. Nothing special. I went with 4 girlfriends and we each ordered a different plate. My favorite dish was the pollo salteado, it's basically chicken sauteed with a lot of onions, cilantro, and french fries. It was very well seasoned maybe a bit on the salty side. Their homemade sangria is delicious. The prices are really descent. The service was OK.
author: Karen T.

description:
Maybe it's hype ( a good friend calls Mi Lindo Peru the one meal she misses most in SF, and yelp give 4*'s), but we were supremely disappointed, and again, I try to be pretty forgiving, but I just don't get it...  off night?  main chefs were off that night?  Who knows?  But I couldn't even think of giving this place more than 2*s.  Bland food.  Drab setting.  Not that cheap for what you get.  

Head to Piqueos instead.
author: N G.

description: I totally LOVE this place.  The seafood paella is the best & the portion is huge!  Not only is the food scrumptious & well priced, their service is super duper friendly.  The past few times I came here for dinner, the place was packed but the wait wasn't too bad (not like the 45 minute to hour and a half  wait I usually endure at Cha Cha Chas - hmph!)  Parking sucks so definitely get here early.
author: Ali S.

description: I debated between giving 3 and 4 stars.  I would say the food is about a 3....tasty, but not other worldly. I had the empanada appetizer and then the steak with the Plantain and Egg specialty.  This tasted to me like typical Latin American food -- hearty and filling but not exactly what you would call an explosion of flavors. The Chimmichurri (I know I spelled it wrong) sauce was very, very tasty.  Why would I make this a 4*?  The prices are very very good and the portions are huge. And I agree with someone else who said the service was great.
author: Eugene W.

description: Go early or you will have to wait... but its worth it!  start w/ chicharron de pollo, lomo saltado a must or try the pescado al ajo..  order a side order of the plantains too..  YUMMY...
author: E. G.

description: I have returned twice in the past 2 months after my disappointing 2008 visit, and both times have been awesome. Their lomo saltado and several of their shrimp dishes have been amazing. Bumped back to the 5 stars that I would have given them from my first visit way back in 2002!
author: Rudy S.

description: Mi Lindo Peru has absolutely delicious food. Seriously, it's tasty. Atmosphere is casual, friendly service. But the food is what separates this restaurant. Highly recommend it.
author: C M.

description: This restaurant is one of my favorite places. I love so many dishes there. Thinking about the food is making salivate as I type this review. I love eating the chicken appetizer, the garlic prawns, the garlic fish, the lomo saltado, and the tallarin. The soup and salad is good as well. Mmm...and the bread and the sauce that goes with it. *drool* Haha...everytime I go there with my friend she gets her happy juice. I dont drink alcohol but I've heard the sangria is really good there, too. I can't wait to go there again. Hopefully, I have some free time to go there soon. Yum!
author: Michele L.

description: The food is great here!  While your dining here....you must try the Ceviche mixto and the Chaufa.  The Chaufa plate is rice, peas, meat(chicken or beef or a mixture of both)!  An oh so delicious array of aromas and flavors that I cannot simply write down.  You must try for yourself.  Prices are pretty reasonable.  Parking sucks, it is in the mission.....so you can never find parking!  OPTION #2 order take out!
author: Victoria S.

description: Huge fan been here occassionally for years. I'm all over the spicy salsa and bread given as a compliment. Medium sized place with good service. When ever I  crave Peruvian food I go here. Everything is good.
author: Larry L.

description: I love Mi Lindo Peru!  Very delicious, great sangria, and very sweet and attentive service.  We usually go the tapas route as opposed to the entrees, and some of my favorites are the calamari, the prawns in garlic sauce, the crab/artichoke dip, and the garlic fried chicken.  My boyfriend refers to the sangria as Koolaid, but it still gives a lightweight like me a buzz, and is so tasty that the alcohol content hardly matters.  Prices are really quite decent, especially when you go for the pitcher of sangria at $20, which yields around 8 tasty glasses.
author: Tanya N.

description: This is it! For the longest time peruvian joints in SF were either fru-fru fusion places too upscale to feel comfortable -or- they were simplified recipes that tasted more central american than anything. Mi Lindo Peru is perfect Peruvian comfort food! This is what the food is supposed to taste like... the lomo saltado, papas la huancayno and the ceveche are spot on.... and make sure to wash it down with a chicha morada. So happy when I stumbled on this place (two locations in SF), this is an affordable, traditional, no nonsense dinner, great! the only downside (besides the burps!) is a boring room... who cares, I come for the food!
author: Michael V.

description:
"Hey, we're going to some peruvian place.  But if you wanna go, we're leaving now."  I hopped out of bed and put on some clothes I wore yesterday (glad no one noticed), and dashed to the car.  It was raining outside, so I had to grab my jacket.  Found that Wong would be driving us in his Jetta.  I offered to drive, but he really wanted to drive.  And he needed to get gas.  So, we conceded.  Along the way, my brother realizes we have to pick up Mike as well.  Hmm, we'll have to pack some of this stuff in the back seat in the car, but, no problem.  Then, we miss the Avalon Dr. exit, which is the one to take to get  cheap gas on Westborough.  Oh well, guess we'll just fill up at the Hickey exit.  We get gas, then drive over to Mike's.  By now, Len, Lars, and Yian have already gotten a table at Mi Lindo's.  Doh!  So we're already 20 minutes late.  Then at Mike's, Fran enters the car... err, where's Mike?  He pops in a minute later.  Crap... 5 people in a Jetta.  Not comfortable, to say the least.  Oh well... note to self: don't let Wong drive next time.  

Fortunately, we get there in pretty good time, not too much traffic up to the Cesar Chavez exit, and lucked out on some street parking just 2 blocks away.

First thing I thought as I entered the place was: wow, this place is tinier than I thought.  Fortunately, it wasn't very crowded at 8pm on that rainy Saturday night.  Our mates had already ordered some Ceviche de Pescado, which was very tasty, with a tad of lemony sour kick to it.  The bread on the table sated any hunger pains that might be due to eating as late as 8.  The fried plantains were nice.  I ordered the Lomo Saltado (salted strips of steak cooked with tomatoes, onions, french fries and served with rice).  I have to say, I didn't know this was what Peruvian food was about.  It was sorta like Chinese or Vietnamese rice plates, but cooked differently.  The Lomo was delicious - I finished every single bite.  There happened to be a serendipitously appropriate ratio of rice to entree in every bite.  The slices of meat were chosen selectly and cooked to a juicy tenderness.  Only $12.  Len had the Lomo a lo pobre - that looked like an excellent choice as well, topped with an egg cooked overeasy.  Yian ordered the green fried rice - green from a barely detectable silantro sauce, but oh-so-gobbleable.

Also had the flan, but I found it a bit thick for my taste.  I might try their special ice cream next time (yes, I will be back!).  In fact, I really hope to return, I found the food very unpretentious and satisfying - ie, most excellent grub!  4 stars ****

PS, luckily for the group, Larry's car could take another, so we could split up our full selves 4 to a car (instead of 5), and so the ride back was much less cramped.  What a relief.
author: Gerald C.

description: After reading the reviews listed on yelp I  decide to try it.  Very very good food.  The muscles were very tasty as well as the ceviche.  My husband really enjoyed the steak and prawns he said the Peruvian BBQ sauce was amazing.  If you do not care about atmosphere and just want really good food this is your place.  We will defiantly be going back.
author: Michelle M.

description: We ate here for the first time with a big party of 21! This place is off the HOOK! The food was soooo good. THe service was AWESOME...the the place was comfortable. They have the whole package going on...definately somewhere to check out , even if you have to travel to get here!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jill T.

description: I am a regular here.  I love their lomo saltado...yummy.  I am bad with names but they have 2 soup dishes that both my boss and I really like.  The ceviche salad is small but good.  We like the spaghetti dish with meat...very tasty.  The calamari isn't bad too.  I love the sangria here.  Very good.  The service is great but its always crowded.  Make sure to arrive around 6:30 or so because by 8 its packed and the close early.  Can't go wrong for some real good food and lots of it.
author: lori c.

description:
I'm not too familiar with Peruvian food, but every time I come here, I always over eat, and would still want more. I don't remember ever not enjoyed something from the menu.

The only complaint is that sometimes I still smell the restaurant on my clothes after a meal here.
author: B N.

description: Went here on Monday night and it was packed with a mixed crowd, but two tables with large families I think who were Peruvian so that was a good sign of the good food to come! We ordered the lomo saltado-basically a large heap of peruvian rice, fries, thin slices of beef, onions, tomatoes, and this very delcious mix of herbs and seasonings. It was SO GOOD! My BF had th paella, as recommended by the waitress with all kinds of seafood, mussells, clams, calamari, shrimp, fish, etc...it was a large order and we both ended up taking our food home for the next day for lunch...and it actually even tasted better then! I will definetely be back for the ceviche next time...price are about $13-1$17 for an entree which can feed about 2 if you get tapas on the sides...great choice!
author: Petri Y.

description: Standards like Lomo Saltado are done right and the steak is cut thick enough that it remains tender after being stir fried. The Lomo Mariscos and Lomo Camarones were also really good. It's nice to have a restaurant that serves the entire squid and not just the julienned body. The wait staff are very nice though they can be a little slow at times.
author: Andy L.

description:
this place is popular on the weekends, so expect a wait.  you can nourish a cocktail at the knockout across the road until your table is ready.

they serve salsa that comes with a sliced baguette that is pretty tasty.

not much of an exciting selection for a vegetarians standpoint.  you can pick from some tapas, or order from 3 main dishes: spaghetti with mix veg, mix veg and french fries w/rice, or veg paella.  the waiter suggested the mix veg w/rice, but i should've stuck with my gut and ordered the paella.  my dish was carrots, bell peppers, onions, and a sliver of mushroom here and there with french fries mixed in, accompanied with rice.  i mean it taste okay, but not very exciting.

everyone else at the table enjoyed their dishes.  steaks, seafood, chicken, etc., they all loved it.  i think this is a more meat oriented/focused place.  

the service was great, and they even through in a flan with a candle for our birthday girl.
author: Sheri N.

description: So I've been here many times and have tried some of their dishes, I just happen to question what's so special about lomo saltado? It's like majority of yelpers just eat whatever fellow yelpers eat I guess.  I steered myself from it since it's like beef steak with fries. I ordered the Bisteck a lo pobre since I just got off from the gym. Good combo food- it already has the meat, the plantain and the eggs! Also, if you like seafood, order the saltado de mariscos and just sprinkle that lime on the rice...very good.  They give big servings, which I also like. For appetizers, get the anticucho...it's a tasty beef skewer, just don't read what is...it's just good.  While you're at it, get some sangria as well.
author: JB L.

description: I'm peruvian, and it was refreshing actually getting some good peruvian food at a Restaurant in california.  The Ceviche was tasty and pretty fresh, and la papa la huancaina was pretty tasty.  Price is ok, and has a good setting with friendly waiters.
author: Luis G.

description: Real hearty Peruvian food. The rice and the lomo saltado is so good. There is another seafood dish I like with green colored rice. Everything there just so tasty, especially their specialty cookies that melt in your mouth.
author: Judy L.

description:
the dishes we tried were flavorful but a tad bit too salty.
it's a good place to stop for some lunch if you're in the area.

nothing special in terms of decor.  it's just tables with chairs... a little run down
author: charlotte s.

description: Not what I was expecting.  The fried plantains were just that, fried.  No sauce or sugar or anything.  I was expecting robust flavors and spice.  The salsa was fiery and full of flavors I can't make out.  It was my favorite item on the table, next to the sangria which I had too much of by the end of the meal.  The "fried rice" was just like any other Asian fried rice at a take out place, but I wasn't expecting Asian fried rice!!!  The other yelpers seem to love this place so I will give it another shot and order some different dishes next time.
author: Jeanne C.

description: A solid "meh".  Nothing stuck out as particularly bad, but nothing stuck out as particularly good either.  Food was interesting...but it didn't go beyond that into "wow" territory.  Sangria was acceptable and had a bit of a kick -- not watered down like in some places.  Decor and atmosphere were pretty meh too.
author: Eugene F.

description: Many years ago we frequented the now closed branch on Scott St.  Good to know they are still here. Love the mixed ceviche, anticuhos, and paella.
author: Ye W.

description: Food is pretty good and different there. Peruvian food with a lot cinnamon type of spice used here. Still in search for the best paella in town but this one ain't too bad i guess. When the bill comes, everyone was happy -  let's just say the damage (to our wallets) was in control..
author: Angela H.

description: Te amo Mi Lindo Peru
author: Colleen B.

description:
I"m not Peruvian, but I wish I was.  On my never ending quest for the ultimate Lomo Saltado, I ended up here one Thursday night (yelping night).  We ordered the empanada which was very good, flaky, and juicy seasoned ground beef, and some tangy sliced onions which I am told is a staple of Peruvian cuisine.  The atmosphere isn't that great, but it's the mission, and I don't really care about atmosphere.  The Lomo Saltado definitely was tasty but it was not perfect.  The meat was very good, tender, and juicy.  The rice was not sticky rice like I am used to (or I at least prefer it sticky, I'm not sure of the true traditional Peruvian way), and it had corn in it.  The rice can really make this meal, and I found it to be too light and tasted like it was made in a huge batch.  The dish was good overall, but the major problem that I had was that there was not enough sauce or juice in the dish.  I prefer there to be more stock/wine/soy sauce so that you can dip the rice and onion and fries and steak into it.  Otherwise it was very good, I give it a four stars, I'm just rather neurotic when it comes to this dish, because it happens to be my favorite. 

This place has good beer selection, and a good location, definitely a return visit and a recommendation for anyone interested.
author: Tom O.

description: I agree, their saltado is great. The spicy dip they bring with the bread is kickin' spicy. It's a great place for groups--we had 10 people plus 2 kids on a Monday night, no problem. The service is lovely. Big portions. I could seriously just eat the rice. Definitely get the saltado (any of them) and the paella.
author: Joyce L.

description: Really good food, ceviche was excellent and the service polite and friendly.
author: Alex A.

description: I love Peruvian food! This is my favorite casual Peruvian restaurant in the city. There are so many selections on the menu and everything is so yummy! All of the flavors are different for the dishes but still wonderfully enticing to my tongue... For the price you pay and the portions you get, it's definitely worth it to eat here. If I lived closer, I would definitely frequent here more often...
author: Bernice C.

description: This a great place for yummy cheap eats. The servers are friendly and the portions are huge. I love supporting family owned restaurant. We would definitely be back!
author: Joiera C.

description: I've been here about 5 or 6 times and love this place for their wonderful Peruvian food. I just wish it could be a bit more affordable as a regular dinner place. Lunch is good and cheaper at about $10 though and with almost as much food (if not the same amount) as dinner. Marc really likes their Tallarin with beef and I love their Arroz con Mariscos and their version of Paella. I wasn't too fond of the fries they use in some of their dishes though - it came out kind of dried and I've had it much better at other Peruvian places. Other than that, I've loved everything else I've ever had here. I would definitely come here a lot more often if there was a better parking situation and if the prices were a tad lower. Oh and you have to get the Inca Cola and M says you should get the Cristal or Cusquena beer with your meal. The staff here are also super friendly and it's got a comfy but sort of chic atmosphere.
author: Samantha H.

description: Good solid food.  The beef steak was excellent and tasty, but the prices are on the high end.  The flan was delish with hints of clove.  The service was very friendly, but the ambience was lacking.  There are better Peruvian restaurants for the price in West Portal.  Go there if you're in the neighborhood and have an itch for Peruvian food.  The meat played havoc with my stomach the next day, but that may be because I rarely eat meat and that much garlic.
author: Neil F.

description: Absolutely declicious.  Great Sangria, great tapas, very yummy.  Get here early though.  Parking is hard.  However its worth it for the food!
author: Sonya T.

description: I've been telling everyone I can about how good of meal I had at Mi Lindo, so of course I had to write a Yelp review!  We had dishes from each section of the menu:  appetizers, chicken, meat, tapas, and seafood, and it was all delicious.  I had no idea I liked Peruvian food, but I do after eating here!  The wait staff were super friendly and they kept tabs on our bread and drink needs even though they were busy.  All around a great meal out.
author: Denise G.

description: Excellent food. I had chicken breast in a saffron/cherry wine sauce and it was perfect. Service is really good as well. Very friendly and attentive staff. We got there just as they were about to shut the kitchen down, but they didn't hurry us up and even give the slightest hint that they wanted to close up and get out.
author: Riz N.

description: If I had had food like this while I was in Peru, I would still be there.  A definite culinary gem -- do try their Spanish style tapas with a group of friends.
author: Tim G.

description: The first time I came here I didn't know what to expect but I was pleasantly surprised.  I've been going there ever since and the food is great!
author: May A.

description: Oh, hells yes! This place is so proper, it makes me wanna cry just thinking about it. Everything I've ordered has been great (and I've been there a few times). I mean, damn! Is there an old Peruvian grandmother back there whipping up each dish? Fuck it, I'm going there right now...
author: Vinnie E.

description: Yes, I've been to Limon and Fresca and have liked my experiences there.  Sure, their ambiance is fancy but their food, though excellent, is more Peruvian-inspired (translates into - less authentic).  Mi Lindo Peru was where I fell in love with the real deal Peruvian cuisine.  There are no tricks, no bells and whistles to their dishes.  Their service is really friendly and fast.  The highlight though is knowing that I can still remember the taste of their Lomo Saltado and their cerviches long after I've eaten here.  Mi Lindo Peru - you give good lovin.
author: Jean A.

description: I've tried other Peruvian restaurants and this place was ok. I'll come back again whenever I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Rose E.

description: I was expecting a little bit more of "Mi Lindo Peru". To me the food was too similar to Mexican. I couldn't see anything among my choices or my friends' ones that caught my attention to claim excellence. But on the other side, the price is reasonable and the portions are big.
author: Javi V.

description: Great Peruvian restaurant in outer mission.  Not fancy, not a lot of curb appeal.  But great food, great service, and amazing value.  We've been going for about 5 years, and never had a bad experience.  Note it is not the absolute best Peruvian in the city, but to get that, you are going to pay double or triple what you pay here.
author: John W.

description: While the Sangria is over priced usually costing the same amount as the rest of dinner the food is quite good as are the non-alcoholic Peruvian drinks.  Primarily a fish restaurant is all has the standard fair of plantains and fantastic beans and rice.
author: Ian H.

description: everything was delicious in this place! sangria was great, and seafood was very good - especially their stew and mussel appetizer. Great place to bring group of friends! Family friendly restaurant.
author: ji k.

description: It doesn't look like much when you walk in, but this place has incredibly good food and huge portion sizes, at really reasonable prices, served up by some of the friendliest staff I've ever seen.  What more could anyone want?
author: Stacy L.

description: Ceviche was ok but not outstanding.  They messed up my dinner order but were nice about it and made me the right dish.  Overall, I thought it would be better based on other yelpers comments.  There's a far superior Peruvian place called Estampas Peruanas in Redwood City that ya'll should check out if you can.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Pretty decorations and very quiet on a Monday night.  Wonderful service, but not really enough for me to overlook the prices compared to the quality.  For some reason everything tasted more lemon-flavored than I really wanted to.  Still, everything was very fresh and I would go there again if I could order a different dish.
author: Alex C.

description: I hope the shiny red paint job outside will lure more people here. Peruvian restaurants are becoming trendy, but most are so expensive that I feel that I'm paying for the boring, minimalistic decor. Mi Lindo Peru may not have the greatest interior design either, but without putting on airs it offers heartier portions, the menu spells ceviche correctly, and the place overall feels cozy. You can kick back and enjoy genuine Peruvian food without the high-pressure attitude of some other places. Down with $20 plates of ceviche that you can gobble in several forkfuls! Mi Lindo Peru instead gives you a giant, full plate of succulent, lime-soaked seafood. The staff is so nice. Great sangria and lucuma ice cream too.
author: elsa m.

description: Mi Lindo Peru was my first encounter with Peruvian cuisine and I have to say I enjoyed it very much.  It's a great casual joint to eat some home style,just like momma used to make cooking (even if yo momma isn't Peruvian). Everything was fresh and the service was prompt. The decor is not great but it feels like you are in someone's kitchen or house. There was plenty of seating even at 8pm on a Friday, no wait, no hoopla. Sangria was pretty good yum! Mi Lindo is a great place for anyone who wants to try Peruvian food for the first time.
author: alexandria a.

description: I decided to try to restaurant because I heard so many great review about it. They were right! The service is simply the best and the food is truly delicious. I love this place. I wish I can give this place 10 stars! Try their lomo saltado and paella. YUM!...
author: Tess C.

description:
My peruvian friend took me here for lunch years and years ago. I was excited because then it HAD to be authentic and yummy. And it was, it really was. 

Over the years I've settled on camarones saltatdo as my favorite dish, but lomo (beef) saltado is amazing as well - if you like beef. 

The portions are huge and tasty and pretty reasonably priced. The ceviche is also really good. It's just all really really good. In fact, I think I am gonna go there right now.
author: A K.

description: This deserves 4.5 stars but I will round up because they were so nice.  VERY good Lomo Saltado.  Large portions.  Delicious Sangria.  All this for a reasonable price.  Definitely the best Peruvian I've had up here.  Definitely better than Limon and much better prices.  Not as fancy, though, but worth the 15 minute walk from the BART.
author: Erick Z.

description: Whoah this place is delicious!  Perhaps the best fried shrimp in town. Very generous portions of super fresh Peruvian classics ever so slightly tweaked keep me excited for each return visit. Try the Arroz con Pollo and wash it down with an icy cold Peruvian beer. I strongly recommend anything fried. It's so f*%cking tasty and never leaves you feeling heavy sluggish or greasy. The closest you'll get to South America without a passport....but then again....I've never been to South America.
author: Joe T.

description:
Been here several times on weekends and never disappointed.  The prices are reasonable, the food is fantastic, and the people are friendly.

I think the Sangria is great!  Get at least a pitcher...

Stop reading and go there now to eat!
author: Dave S.

description:
Fun neighborhood restaurant. Lomo saltado, empanadas and yucca fries are always great and they give you a really tasty dip for your bread. 
They also have take out.
author: r e.

description:
i've been trying to find a peruvian place up here since a friend of mine introduced me to the greatness that is lomo saltado from mario's peruvian and seafood in LA. [http://www.yelp.com/biz/marios-peruvian-and-seafood-los-angeles#hrid:XfgfIjp32EUmVa3YhVh0TA/query:mario's]

although i like mario's better, the lomo saltado at mi lindo is satisfying enough to keep me from driving 400 miles south to get my fix.

the service was great too.. we were a party of 10, and i swear all of our orders came out within 5 minutes. maybe since we all ordered the same thing. i split it with a friend (blasphemy, i know) and the server brought it out on two smaller plates, as if a "half order of lomo saltado" was on the menu.

and they were good on refilling our waters with, get this, brita pitchers! haha. that was a big deal to me
author: Erik S.
